text:
The absurd refers to a type of modern Philippine play influenced by the theater of the absurd of Samuel Beckett, Eugene Ionesco, Jean Genet, and others, whose situations are purposely exaggerated to prove a thesis and whose characters tend to become types rather than individuals.

The term was first used by Martin Esslin in his discussion of the type of drama associated with Beckett, Ionesco, Genet, Arthur Adamov, Harold Pinter, and other avant-garde writers in Europe and the United States. A product of post-World War II disenchantment and a reaction against “middle-class realism,” this is theater based on the premise of a world that is, in Ionesco’s words, “devoid of purpose,” and the human being lost because “cut off from his religious, metaphysical, and transcendental roots,” and thus engaged in actions that are “senseless, absurd, useless” (Esslin 1972, 2-3). It is theater that presents the absurd in concrete images and situations.

 

The theater of the absurd reached the Philippine stage through translations of some of its landmark works: Beckett’s Waiting for Godot and Ionesco’s The Bald Soprano.The Beckett play, translated by Rolando S. Tinio as Ang Paghihintay kay Godot, was first performed by Ateneo de Manila students in 1967. Ionesco’s The Chairs was performed in English in 1970, while The Bald Soprano was adapted in Filipino by Isagani R. Cruz under the title Ang Tatay Mong Kalbo, 1969. Both were performed by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) and later by many other groups. Other plays of this nature performed by theater groups in Metro Manila in the 1970s and 1980s are Jean Genet’s The Balcony and The Maids, Beckett’s Endgame, Vaclav Havel’s The Memorandum,and Edward Albee’s Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf? Through these plays, the “sense of metaphysical anguish at the absurdity of the human condition” (Esslin 1972, 23-24) reached playwrights and audiences who saw a related absurdity in Philippine poverty and oppression.

In 2014, Dulaang UP, in collaboration with UP Dulaang Laboratoryo, staged Haring Ubu (King Ubu), a Filipino adaptation of Alfred Jarry’s Ubu Roi. In Oct 2014, the PETA hosted The Imaginarium: A Festival of the Absurd, a four-day multi-arts festival centered on the absurd, which showcased some of the best works in theater, such as The Sandbox Collective’s production of Michael Kooman and Christopher Diamond’s Dani Girl, Michael Lluberes and Joe Maloney’s musicale The Boy in the Bathroom; Guelan Varela Luarca’s Mga Kuneho (The Rabbits); and Sipat Lawin Ensemble’s The Return of the Comeback of the New and Improved Newly Scented Haring +Ubu-L! Now in 6-D!, an adaptation of Alfred Jarry’s Ubu Roi, among others.

Elements of the absurd were first expressed in the works of the young playwrights of Ateneo High School’s Dulaang Sibol; for example, Paul Dumol’s Ang Paglilitis ni Mang Serapio (The Trial of Old Serapio), 1968, in which beggars indict one of their own for caring (this being against federation rules, since it reduces effectivity), and blind him—to make hima better beggar. Although the high school playwrights could not be said to have experienced the “divorce between man and his life, the actor and his setting, [which] truly constitutes the feeling of Absurdity” (Esslin 1972, 23), they saw the absurd in the meaningless actions of grown-ups around them.

Panday Sining, a pre-martial law political theater group, wrote and staged Hukumang Tuwad (Kangaroo Court), 1971, which presented in an absurd fashion the litigation of the Progressive Class (Proletariat, Farmers, Workers, National Minorities, Students, Teachers, Gangsters, Prostitutes). They are accused of different “crimes” by the Reactionary Class (American Imperialists, Landlord-Compradors, Bureaucrat-Capitalists), who in the end are unmasked as being responsible for society’s unjust structures. Rey E. Dela Cruz’s Kumbensyon ng Mga Halimaw (A Convention of Monsters), 1971, is a satire on the 1971 Constitutional Convention wherein creatures from Philippine folklore gather to discuss the Philippine Constitution and Kabaong ng Kalokohan (A Coffin of Nonsense), 1972, is described as a “journey through the theater of the absurd,” where two cross-dressing lunatics discuss different ways to die. Al Santos’s Ang Sistema ni Propesor Tuko (Professor Gecko’s Way), 1980, presents rebellious students under a tyrannical teacher, who moonlights as a waiter, in an absurd educational system characterized by authoritarianism and colonial mentality. Joshua Lim So’s Joe Cool: Aplikante (Joe Cool: Applicant), 2012, demonstrates the struggles of a man to secure a job through a rather outlandish application process, while dealing with a difficult receptionist. In 2015, Tanghalang Ateneo staged Godot5: Five Ruminations on Samuel Beckett’s ‘En Attendant Godot, ’ wherein the characters are framed within five sets of adaptations—namely, “Men Waiting,” “Women Waiting,” “College Graduates Waiting,” “Queer Folks Waiting,” and “Old Folks Waiting.” These and other works demonstrate the influence of the theater of the absurd on Philippine theater, especially in techniques of characterization. Although not full-blown in the European sense, the anguish in Philippine absurdist theater is both metaphysical and concrete. Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

text:
The balagtasan is a poetic debate usually mounted on stage for the public audience. Although some scholars would classify the balagtasan as a poetic form, it is actually intended as a theater event with the key elements of the actor, audience, text, space, and context present. The usual process of staging the balagtasan covers many phases: agreement on the topic, writing of the script, memorizing the script, presentation of the balagtasan, and selection of the winning mambabalagtas (poet debater). The core actors include two mambabalagtas and a lakandiwa (mediator; lakan is a title of nobility, and diwa means mind). The audience is referred to as bayang matino’t makapangyarihan (righteous and powerful people) since, traditionally, it is the viewing public that delivers the hatol (verdict or judgment) and declares the winner of the debate. Some of the criteria expected to be used in judging are taas ng diwa (intelligent arguments), linaw ng katwiran (clarity of reasoning), and sarap ng salita (beauty of the language) (Zafra 2000, 307).

The balagtasan text is in the form of a script prepared by the two debating mambabalagtas. Sometimes a poet writes the entire script to be delivered by young or unskilled participants. The script centers on a single paksa (topic), usually on sociopolitical concerns or current issues. The topic is developed by enumerating and elucidating on several katwiran (reasons or arguments), which makes the balagtasan a form of pangangatwiran (argumentation) or labanan ng katwiran (battle of reasons). The katwiran may be based on anything—“maaaring sumaklaw sa lahat ng dako ng buong daigdig” (can cover anything in the world)—as long as it is delivered in poetic form and does not use inappropriate language (Zafra 2000, 305).

 

 

The debate proper usually follows this flow: the panimula (introduction) by the lakandiwa who introduces the mambabalagtas, the topic or layunin (objective), and the batas na paiiralin (rules to implement); unang bulasan (first attack), the delivery of the first set of arguments; sagutan (exchange of arguments), the series of delivery of arguments and rebuttal; and paghahatol (judgment). Sometimes, reminiscent of the panawagan (plea) of the duplo in which participants would make a plea so the hari (king) would allow him/her to enter the circle, a mambabalagtas, coming from the side of the audience, might make a similar plea for the lakandiwa to allow him/her to go up the stage. This is done to create that impromptu atmosphere of the debate.

During the height of its popularity, the balagtasan was mounted in major theaters, like the Olympic Stadium, Opera House, and Teatro Zorrilla. In the succeeding decades, the grandstands in town plazas or platforms in schools became stages for the balagtasan.

Contrary to popular belief, the form was not created by Francisco Balagtas, the foremost Tagalog poet, but was actually conceived in his honor. The balagtasan was born in a meeting on 28 Mar 1924 of the Kapulungang Balagtas, a society of writers and advocates of Tagalog, held at the Instituto de Mujeres, which was formerly located in Tayuman, Tondo, Manila. In the meeting, Lope K. Santos suggested the holding of a modern duplo to commemorate the birth anniversary of Balagtas. However, it was pointed out that staging a duplo would be inappropriate since it was more associated with death rituals. Patricio A. Dionisio suggested naming the presentation after Balagtas, but it was Jose N. Sevilla who coined the word “balagtasan.”

The first balagtasan script was believed to have been written by Dionisio, who used the byline “Ibig-Sumali-Kung-Maaari” (One Who Would Participate). Titled Balagtasan, it was published in the weekly Bagong Lipang Kalabaw on 5 Apr 1924 to serve as a model for balagtasan participants. There was a call for veteran and young poets alike to join the balagtasan event for the Balagtas celebration. There were three pairs of poets who responded and squared off against each other. Of the three, the pair of Jose Corazon de Jesus and Florentino T. Collantes, who debated on the topic Bulaklak ng Lahing Kalinis-linisan (Flower of the Race Most Pure), was the most popular since both were accomplished poets, and de Jesus was the president of Ilaw at Panitik while Collantes was the head of Bulalakaw.

The first balagtasan on stage was mounted at Instituto de Mujeres on 6 Apr 1924. De Jesus took on the role of Paruparo (Butterfly) while Collantes was Bubuyog (Bee). They were joined by Lope K. Santos as Lakandiwa and Sofia Enriquez as Kampupot (Jasmine). Also in the panel of judges were Rosa Sevilla-Alvero as Lakan-Ilaw (Grand Light) and Iñigo Ed. Regalado as Gatpayo (Noble Adviser). The script of Bulaklak ng Lahing Kalinis-linisan was written by de Jesus and Collantes. They took turns in writing each side of the topic. This account proves that unlike its predecessor, the duplo, the balagtasan is scripted. Nevertheless, there is partial truth to the perception among audiences that it is extemporaneous. This happens when the topic has been tackled many times over by the same team of mambabalagtas such that the poets have already built an arsenal of arguments which they can readily draw from and use during the balagtasan even without much preparation.

The first staging of the balagtasan was well received by the public. The column Sariling Kuro of the newspaper Ang Watawat (The Flag) noted that the modification done on the duplo would greatly help in the development and propagation of the language of Balagtas. Such was the success of the De Jesus-Collantes tandem that the two poets debated again in public. After the first balagtasan, they argued on the topic Magdaragat at Magbubukid (Fisherman and Farmer). This balagtasan, in honor of Marcelo H. del Pilar, was staged at the Opera House in Avenida Rizal. Collantes defended Magdaragat and De Jesus, Magbubukid. Benigno Ramos served as Lakandiwa. One account states that this battle resulted in a rift between De Jesus and Collantes. In some part of the balagtasan, when Collantes was delivering his stanzas, De Jesus recited some lines that were not in the original script: “Kung hindi lang sa nariritong marilag na diwata/disin sana ang mukha mo’y inabot ng aking sipa” (If not for the presence of these beautiful muses/I would have kicked your face). This remark drew applause and laughter from the crowd, spurring Collantes to think of a rebuttal. He replied to Batute: “O, kataka-taka’t kahima-himala/may kabayo palang marunong tumula” (Oh, what a great surprise/a horse who can recite a poem). This drew more cheers from the audience. But despite the reception, Jesus and Collantes entered into a silent feud that lasted for three months. It was reported that a number of balagtasan invitations were turned down because of this disagreement. Since they needed to engage with each other for succeeding duels, they decided to reconcile with the help of writer friends. This is further proof of an element of spontaneity in the performance of the balagtasan despite the presence of a script, an element which can be expected from a form that belongs to the oral tradition.

De Jesus and Collantes debated again on the topic Panganori’t Alapaap (Sky and the Cloud) staged at Teatro Zorrilla in Azcarraga, now Claro M. Recto Avenue. Next was the Dalagang Pilipina: Noon at Ngayon (The Filipina Maiden: Yesterday and Today) balagtasan, considered the biggest and the most popular among the poetic debates between De Jesus and Collantes. De Jesus defended the Filipina of Yesterday while Collantes, the Filipina of Today, with Manila Representative Francisco Varona as the Lakandiwa. It was staged at the Olympic Stadium on 18 Oct 1925. The audience included General Emilio Aguinaldo, senators, congressmen, and officials of Malacañan and universities. There were also delegations from Tayabas, Laguna, Cavite, Bataan, Rizal, and Bulacan among the audience. Newspaper reports estimated the crowd at 8,000 to 15,000. This balagtasan was adjudged by the audience, who voted for their favored poet by clapping. In this duel, De Jesus was honored as the first “Hari ng Balagtasan” (King of Balagtasan). The practice of bestowing the title “Hari ng Balagtasan” began with this encounter. It is important to note that the first Hari ng Balagtasan was chosen by the audience, which attests to its central role in staging most balagtasan.

After the balagtasan at the Olympic Stadium, De Jesus and Collantes battled again several times. In the Panulat at Sandata (Pen and Weapon) balagtasan, Collantes attempted to seize the title from De Jesus. The duel ended in a draw. Collantes succeeded in capturing the title when he defended the side of Anti-coalition against De Jesus’s Coalition in the Koalisyon at Anti-koalisyon (Coalition and Anti-coalition) balagtasan. This happened in 1927 when political groups were debating on the issue of forming a single political party. In 1929, De Jesus regained the title in the Ginto at Bakal (Gold and Metal) balagtasan, in which he argued for Bakal against Collantes’ Ginto. Collantes sought to reclaim the title but all attempts to have another duel failed, until De Jesus fell ill and never recovered.

At the height of balagtasan’s popularity, almost all of the well-known writers took part in the balagtasan. Pedro Gatmaitan and Benigno Ramos fought over Kung Sino ang Dapat Mahalin ng Anak: Ama o Ina (Who Should the Child Love: Father or Mother); Ramos and De Jesus over Independencia Laban sa Autonomia (Independence versus Autonomy); De Jesus and Gatmaitan over Sino ang Mahalaga, ang Nars o ang Maestra? (Who Is More Important: Nurse or Teacher?); and Gatmaitan and Collantes over Demokrata vs. Konsolidado (Democrat vs Consolidated). Even women poets engaged in the balagtasan. On 6 Sep 1925, the Samahang Bulakan sponsored a balagtasan titled Ilaw ng Bayani (Light of the Hero) to celebrate the birth anniversary of Marcelo H. del Pilar. It was mounted in Teatro Zorrilla. Epifania Alvarez defended Liwayway (Dawn), while Beatrice Pablo defended Bituin (Star). The script for this balagtasan was written by Collantes and De Jesus respectively (Gener 1948, 43). But the breakthrough balagtasan of women poets was enacted on 21 Mar 1926. Filomena T. Alcazar and Pilar Mayot debated on the topic Bulaklak at Bituin (Flower and Star).

Because of its popularity, the balagtasan spread to other Philippine language groups. The Kapampangan developed the crissotan, named after Juan Crisostomo Soto, considered the Father of Kapampangan Literature. In the 1930s, the Ilocano had their own version of the balagtasan—the bukanegan, named after Pedro Bucaneg, considered the “Father of Ilocano Literature.” As early as 1926, there were already reports of balagtasan events in Cebu using the Visayan language. The rapid spread of the balagtasan to other regions can be explained by the presence of a vibrant tradition of poetic jousts in many parts of the country.

The balagtasan was adopted even by Filipino writers in foreign languages. Jesus Balmori and Manuel Bernabe, using the Spanish language, debated on the topics El Recuerdo y El Olvido (Memory and Forgetfulness), El Hombre y La Mujer (Man and Woman), and La Ilusion y El Desengaño (Illusion and Disillusion). Analyzing these balagtasan pieces written by Filipino poets in Spanish based on the poetics of Balagtasismo, Coroza concluded that the balagtasan in Spanish is not only an evidence of the popularity of the form but also of Filipino writers’ appropriation of the Spanish language (2010, 25).

Although the balagtasan is meant to be mounted on stage, it reached the newspapers and magazines since many of the mambabalagtas were also writer-journalists. The most significant of these balagtasan on print media was Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas (Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow) which appeared on the weekly Sampagita, from 10 Aug 1926 to 17 Dec 1926. Julian Cruz Balmaseda, who argued for Bukas, overwhelmingly triumphed over Iñigo Ed. Regalado (Kahapon) and Benigno Ramos (Ngayon) through votes sent in by the readers.

In 1937, the Compania Elizalde, a pro-Filipino commercial house, sponsored the balagtasan on radio. This project, which lasted until 1941 and was revived from 1946 to 1956, was initiated by Pedro E. Teodoro, the director for publicity of the company, and Fernando B. Monleon, the proponent. Emilio Mar. Antonio won the first balagtasan on radio with the topic Sino ang Higit na Dapat Mahalin: Ina, Asawa, o Anak? (Who Should be Loved Most: Mother, Spouse, or Child?), besting opponents Monleon and Francisco Pano.

After the death of Collantes in 1954, Antonio and Nemesio Caravana fought over the title Hari ng Balagtasan on the topic Alin ang Lalong Mahalaga: Buhay Kahapon o Buhay Ngayon? (Which Is More Significant: Life Yesterday or Life Today?). Antonio was crowned Hari ng Balagtasan by the Taliba ng Inang Wika.

In the next decades, the balagtasan continued to be performed in schools, town fiestas, and in the celebration of the Buwan ng Wika (National Language Month), as well as on the radio. For example, on Oct 1987, the issue of whether the money received by the Philippines from the United States for using its territory for the latter’s bases facilities was aid or rent was the main topic of the balagtasan written by Gregorio Victoria. This balagtasan, aired over DWRV Radio Veritas, was part of the radio program Kultura ng Bayan, sponsored by the Cultural Center of the Philippines, which featured a weekly balagtasan discussing relevant social issues.

The balagtasan is one of the preferred traditional theater forms used by sectoral groups and nongovernment institutions in clarifying social issues to the public. In 1991, for example, a bodabil-like show titled Nagalit ang Bulkan kay Uncle Sam (The Volcano Got Mad at Uncle Sam) was staged at the Amoranto Multi-Purpose Hall sponsored by the National Council of Churches in the Philippines, Metro Manila Ecumenical Fellowship, Philippine Collegian, Bugkos, and Galian sa Arte at Tula. The highlight of the show was a balagtasan debating on the advantages and disadvantages of retaining the US military bases in the Philippines. In 1995, after the death of Flor Contemplacion, the Filipino domestic helper sentenced to death in Singapore, a balagtasan was held in Manila to examine whether the government was remiss in its role of protecting overseas Filipino workers. Even the underground movement recognized the effectivity of the balagtasan. Manahimik o Mag-aklas (To Keep Silent or Protest) was written by Manuel Salva-Cruz and published in Magsasaka: Ang Bayaning Di-Kilala (The Farmer: The Unsung Hero), 1984, an anthology of poems, songs, stories, and illustrations of farmers and cultural activists. It was published by the Kilusan sa Paglilinang ng Rebolusyonaryong Panitikan at Sining sa Kanayunan. In this balagtasan, Juan Giting and Juan Kimi debated on what to do in times of extreme poverty: to keep silent or to protest?

In 2009, the University of the Philippines Sentro ng Wikang Filipino, together with the Department of Education, sponsored a National Balagtasan Competition for high school students. The four teams that were carefully selected through various levels of competition from school level to the national level provided meaningful arguments to explain relevant topics, such as Dapat Bang Magkaroon ng Uniporme sa Paaralan? (Should Wearing School Uniforms Be Required?), Dapat o Hindi Dapat Dagdagan ng Isa Pang Taon ang Hay-iskul (Should There Be an Additional One Year in High School?), and Sa Lumalalang Sitwasyong Pangkapayapaan sa Bansa, Sino ang Dapat Sisihin: Ang Tao o ang Pamahalaan? (Who Is to Blame for the Worsening Peace Situation: The People or the Government?). The competition was held at the 2,100 seating capacity UP Theater, filled with an audience comprising mostly teachers and students who would at times get excited and interrupt the mambabalagtas in the middle of their argumentation. The project successfully recreated the spirit that made the balagtasan a very popular theater event.

In 1988, a project was undertaken by the ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information (COCI) to document and preserve various forms of cultural traditional media in ASEAN countries. In the Philippines, the cultural and traditional medium chosen was the balagtasan. The Philippine research group, headed by Nicanor G. Tiongson, aimed to “explore the possibilities of using a cultural and traditional form as a vehicle for development messages as well as measure its impact and effectiveness on the audience” (ASEAN COCI 1991, 103). For five Saturdays in Oct and Nov 1989, and in Feb 1990, a group formed by the Cultural Center of the Philippines presented a balagtasan in six towns of Bulacan. Cresenciano C. Marquez Jr, who is also a mambabalagtas, was commissioned to write a balagtasan script on the topic Ano ang Ugat ng Ating Kahirapan, Sistema ng Lipunan o Pananaw sa Buhay? (What is the root cause of our poverty, the social system or our worldview?). Poet Alberto Suallo of Taytay, Rizal, argued that social structures and systems are the causes of poverty among Filipinos, as well as other related problems such as corruption, prostitution, insurgency, and drug addiction. On the other side, poet Teo T. Antonio of Bulacan argued that worldview is mother to all these economic and social problems, and a change in the people’s worldview and attitudes can alter structures and systems. Yolanda Rambuyon of Biñan, Laguna, acted as the Lakandiwa.

A group of teachers and students from the UP College of Mass Communications, headed by Delia R. Barcelona, was employed to evaluate the effectiveness of the balagtasan in conveying developmental messages to the audience. Using a pretest/posttest approach of the survey method, the research was designed to measure the effects of the balagtasan on three aspects: cognitive, which refers to information learned by the audience about the topic; affective, which refers to the emotional response of the audience to the balagtasan as a medium; and behavioral, which refers to the course of action that the audience intends to take immediately after witnessing the balagtasan. In general, findings showed that the audience’s awareness of issues related to poverty increased after exposure to the medium. The study proved that the balagtasan has a great potential as a medium for disseminating developmental messages (COCI 1991, 130).

Another interesting development of the balagtasan is its transformation into another form—the flip top. The term refers to the rap battle contest participated in by underground or amateur rappers. In this contest, two rappers are pitted against each other in a battle of a cappella rap. In freestyle rap, throwing an insult back at a challenger is called a “flip.” In most cases, each battle is composed of three rounds, and the winner is determined by a panel of judges. Similar to the traditional balagtasan, rappers are allowed to write the lyrics of their rap. One of the reasons behind the flip top’s popularity is the use of Filipino in its lyrics, which is loosely structured and rhythmic and delivered in freestyle. Filipino vulgarities and cuss words are common elements of the lyrics, utilized to attack the opponent while debunking his arguments.

The flip top battles gained prominence through the video-sharing site YouTube. The group called FlipTop, an events and artist handling company founded on 6 Feb 2010 by Alaric Riam Yuson, sponsors the Philippine Flip Top Battles and uploads videos of the battles on its official YouTube account “fliptopbattles.” Flip top has gained prominence not only in social media but also in the barangays and schools though interbarangay and intercollegiate competitions.  Written by Galileo S. Zafra

article.value: The balagtasan text is in the form of a script prepared by the two debating mambabalagtas. Sometimes a poet writes the entire script to be delivered by young or unskilled participants. The script centers on a single paksa (topic), usually on sociopolitical concerns or current issues. The topic is developed by enumerating and elucidating on several katwiran (reasons or arguments), which makes the balagtasan a form of pangangatwiran (argumentation) or labanan ng katwiran (battle of reasons). The katwiran may be based on anything—“maaaring sumaklaw sa lahat ng dako ng buong daigdig” (can cover anything in the world)—as long as it is delivered in poetic form and does not use inappropriate language (Zafra 2000, 305).

article.value: The debate proper usually follows this flow: the panimula (introduction) by the lakandiwa who introduces the mambabalagtas, the topic or layunin (objective), and the batas na paiiralin (rules to implement); unang bulasan (first attack), the delivery of the first set of arguments; sagutan (exchange of arguments), the series of delivery of arguments and rebuttal; and paghahatol (judgment). Sometimes, reminiscent of the panawagan (plea) of the duplo in which participants would make a plea so the hari (king) would allow him/her to enter the circle, a mambabalagtas, coming from the side of the audience, might make a similar plea for the lakandiwa to allow him/her to go up the stage. This is done to create that impromptu atmosphere of the debate.

During the height of its popularity, the balagtasan was mounted in major theaters, like the Olympic Stadium, Opera House, and Teatro Zorrilla. In the succeeding decades, the grandstands in town plazas or platforms in schools became stages for the balagtasan.

Contrary to popular belief, the form was not created by Francisco Balagtas, the foremost Tagalog poet, but was actually conceived in his honor. The balagtasan was born in a meeting on 28 Mar 1924 of the Kapulungang Balagtas, a society of writers and advocates of Tagalog, held at the Instituto de Mujeres, which was formerly located in Tayuman, Tondo, Manila. In the meeting, Lope K. Santos suggested the holding of a modern duplo to commemorate the birth anniversary of Balagtas. However, it was pointed out that staging a duplo would be inappropriate since it was more associated with death rituals. Patricio A. Dionisio suggested naming the presentation after Balagtas, but it was Jose N. Sevilla who coined the word “balagtasan.”

The first balagtasan script was believed to have been written by Dionisio, who used the byline “Ibig-Sumali-Kung-Maaari” (One Who Would Participate). Titled Balagtasan, it was published in the weekly Bagong Lipang Kalabaw on 5 Apr 1924 to serve as a model for balagtasan participants. There was a call for veteran and young poets alike to join the balagtasan event for the Balagtas celebration. There were three pairs of poets who responded and squared off against each other. Of the three, the pair of Jose Corazon de Jesus and Florentino T. Collantes, who debated on the topic Bulaklak ng Lahing Kalinis-linisan (Flower of the Race Most Pure), was the most popular since both were accomplished poets, and de Jesus was the president of Ilaw at Panitik while Collantes was the head of Bulalakaw.

The first balagtasan on stage was mounted at Instituto de Mujeres on 6 Apr 1924. De Jesus took on the role of Paruparo (Butterfly) while Collantes was Bubuyog (Bee). They were joined by Lope K. Santos as Lakandiwa and Sofia Enriquez as Kampupot (Jasmine). Also in the panel of judges were Rosa Sevilla-Alvero as Lakan-Ilaw (Grand Light) and Iñigo Ed. Regalado as Gatpayo (Noble Adviser). The script of Bulaklak ng Lahing Kalinis-linisan was written by de Jesus and Collantes. They took turns in writing each side of the topic. This account proves that unlike its predecessor, the duplo, the balagtasan is scripted. Nevertheless, there is partial truth to the perception among audiences that it is extemporaneous. This happens when the topic has been tackled many times over by the same team of mambabalagtas such that the poets have already built an arsenal of arguments which they can readily draw from and use during the balagtasan even without much preparation.

The first staging of the balagtasan was well received by the public. The column Sariling Kuro of the newspaper Ang Watawat (The Flag) noted that the modification done on the duplo would greatly help in the development and propagation of the language of Balagtas. Such was the success of the De Jesus-Collantes tandem that the two poets debated again in public. After the first balagtasan, they argued on the topic Magdaragat at Magbubukid (Fisherman and Farmer). This balagtasan, in honor of Marcelo H. del Pilar, was staged at the Opera House in Avenida Rizal. Collantes defended Magdaragat and De Jesus, Magbubukid. Benigno Ramos served as Lakandiwa. One account states that this battle resulted in a rift between De Jesus and Collantes. In some part of the balagtasan, when Collantes was delivering his stanzas, De Jesus recited some lines that were not in the original script: “Kung hindi lang sa nariritong marilag na diwata/disin sana ang mukha mo’y inabot ng aking sipa” (If not for the presence of these beautiful muses/I would have kicked your face). This remark drew applause and laughter from the crowd, spurring Collantes to think of a rebuttal. He replied to Batute: “O, kataka-taka’t kahima-himala/may kabayo palang marunong tumula” (Oh, what a great surprise/a horse who can recite a poem). This drew more cheers from the audience. But despite the reception, Jesus and Collantes entered into a silent feud that lasted for three months. It was reported that a number of balagtasan invitations were turned down because of this disagreement. Since they needed to engage with each other for succeeding duels, they decided to reconcile with the help of writer friends. This is further proof of an element of spontaneity in the performance of the balagtasan despite the presence of a script, an element which can be expected from a form that belongs to the oral tradition.

De Jesus and Collantes debated again on the topic Panganori’t Alapaap (Sky and the Cloud) staged at Teatro Zorrilla in Azcarraga, now Claro M. Recto Avenue. Next was the Dalagang Pilipina: Noon at Ngayon (The Filipina Maiden: Yesterday and Today) balagtasan, considered the biggest and the most popular among the poetic debates between De Jesus and Collantes. De Jesus defended the Filipina of Yesterday while Collantes, the Filipina of Today, with Manila Representative Francisco Varona as the Lakandiwa. It was staged at the Olympic Stadium on 18 Oct 1925. The audience included General Emilio Aguinaldo, senators, congressmen, and officials of Malacañan and universities. There were also delegations from Tayabas, Laguna, Cavite, Bataan, Rizal, and Bulacan among the audience. Newspaper reports estimated the crowd at 8,000 to 15,000. This balagtasan was adjudged by the audience, who voted for their favored poet by clapping. In this duel, De Jesus was honored as the first “Hari ng Balagtasan” (King of Balagtasan). The practice of bestowing the title “Hari ng Balagtasan” began with this encounter. It is important to note that the first Hari ng Balagtasan was chosen by the audience, which attests to its central role in staging most balagtasan.

After the balagtasan at the Olympic Stadium, De Jesus and Collantes battled again several times. In the Panulat at Sandata (Pen and Weapon) balagtasan, Collantes attempted to seize the title from De Jesus. The duel ended in a draw. Collantes succeeded in capturing the title when he defended the side of Anti-coalition against De Jesus’s Coalition in the Koalisyon at Anti-koalisyon (Coalition and Anti-coalition) balagtasan. This happened in 1927 when political groups were debating on the issue of forming a single political party. In 1929, De Jesus regained the title in the Ginto at Bakal (Gold and Metal) balagtasan, in which he argued for Bakal against Collantes’ Ginto. Collantes sought to reclaim the title but all attempts to have another duel failed, until De Jesus fell ill and never recovered.

At the height of balagtasan’s popularity, almost all of the well-known writers took part in the balagtasan. Pedro Gatmaitan and Benigno Ramos fought over Kung Sino ang Dapat Mahalin ng Anak: Ama o Ina (Who Should the Child Love: Father or Mother); Ramos and De Jesus over Independencia Laban sa Autonomia (Independence versus Autonomy); De Jesus and Gatmaitan over Sino ang Mahalaga, ang Nars o ang Maestra? (Who Is More Important: Nurse or Teacher?); and Gatmaitan and Collantes over Demokrata vs. Konsolidado (Democrat vs Consolidated). Even women poets engaged in the balagtasan. On 6 Sep 1925, the Samahang Bulakan sponsored a balagtasan titled Ilaw ng Bayani (Light of the Hero) to celebrate the birth anniversary of Marcelo H. del Pilar. It was mounted in Teatro Zorrilla. Epifania Alvarez defended Liwayway (Dawn), while Beatrice Pablo defended Bituin (Star). The script for this balagtasan was written by Collantes and De Jesus respectively (Gener 1948, 43). But the breakthrough balagtasan of women poets was enacted on 21 Mar 1926. Filomena T. Alcazar and Pilar Mayot debated on the topic Bulaklak at Bituin (Flower and Star).

Because of its popularity, the balagtasan spread to other Philippine language groups. The Kapampangan developed the crissotan, named after Juan Crisostomo Soto, considered the Father of Kapampangan Literature. In the 1930s, the Ilocano had their own version of the balagtasan—the bukanegan, named after Pedro Bucaneg, considered the “Father of Ilocano Literature.” As early as 1926, there were already reports of balagtasan events in Cebu using the Visayan language. The rapid spread of the balagtasan to other regions can be explained by the presence of a vibrant tradition of poetic jousts in many parts of the country.

The balagtasan was adopted even by Filipino writers in foreign languages. Jesus Balmori and Manuel Bernabe, using the Spanish language, debated on the topics El Recuerdo y El Olvido (Memory and Forgetfulness), El Hombre y La Mujer (Man and Woman), and La Ilusion y El Desengaño (Illusion and Disillusion). Analyzing these balagtasan pieces written by Filipino poets in Spanish based on the poetics of Balagtasismo, Coroza concluded that the balagtasan in Spanish is not only an evidence of the popularity of the form but also of Filipino writers’ appropriation of the Spanish language (2010, 25).

Although the balagtasan is meant to be mounted on stage, it reached the newspapers and magazines since many of the mambabalagtas were also writer-journalists. The most significant of these balagtasan on print media was Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas (Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow) which appeared on the weekly Sampagita, from 10 Aug 1926 to 17 Dec 1926. Julian Cruz Balmaseda, who argued for Bukas, overwhelmingly triumphed over Iñigo Ed. Regalado (Kahapon) and Benigno Ramos (Ngayon) through votes sent in by the readers.

In 1937, the Compania Elizalde, a pro-Filipino commercial house, sponsored the balagtasan on radio. This project, which lasted until 1941 and was revived from 1946 to 1956, was initiated by Pedro E. Teodoro, the director for publicity of the company, and Fernando B. Monleon, the proponent. Emilio Mar. Antonio won the first balagtasan on radio with the topic Sino ang Higit na Dapat Mahalin: Ina, Asawa, o Anak? (Who Should be Loved Most: Mother, Spouse, or Child?), besting opponents Monleon and Francisco Pano.

After the death of Collantes in 1954, Antonio and Nemesio Caravana fought over the title Hari ng Balagtasan on the topic Alin ang Lalong Mahalaga: Buhay Kahapon o Buhay Ngayon? (Which Is More Significant: Life Yesterday or Life Today?). Antonio was crowned Hari ng Balagtasan by the Taliba ng Inang Wika.

In the next decades, the balagtasan continued to be performed in schools, town fiestas, and in the celebration of the Buwan ng Wika (National Language Month), as well as on the radio. For example, on Oct 1987, the issue of whether the money received by the Philippines from the United States for using its territory for the latter’s bases facilities was aid or rent was the main topic of the balagtasan written by Gregorio Victoria. This balagtasan, aired over DWRV Radio Veritas, was part of the radio program Kultura ng Bayan, sponsored by the Cultural Center of the Philippines, which featured a weekly balagtasan discussing relevant social issues.

The balagtasan is one of the preferred traditional theater forms used by sectoral groups and nongovernment institutions in clarifying social issues to the public. In 1991, for example, a bodabil-like show titled Nagalit ang Bulkan kay Uncle Sam (The Volcano Got Mad at Uncle Sam) was staged at the Amoranto Multi-Purpose Hall sponsored by the National Council of Churches in the Philippines, Metro Manila Ecumenical Fellowship, Philippine Collegian, Bugkos, and Galian sa Arte at Tula. The highlight of the show was a balagtasan debating on the advantages and disadvantages of retaining the US military bases in the Philippines. In 1995, after the death of Flor Contemplacion, the Filipino domestic helper sentenced to death in Singapore, a balagtasan was held in Manila to examine whether the government was remiss in its role of protecting overseas Filipino workers. Even the underground movement recognized the effectivity of the balagtasan. Manahimik o Mag-aklas (To Keep Silent or Protest) was written by Manuel Salva-Cruz and published in Magsasaka: Ang Bayaning Di-Kilala (The Farmer: The Unsung Hero), 1984, an anthology of poems, songs, stories, and illustrations of farmers and cultural activists. It was published by the Kilusan sa Paglilinang ng Rebolusyonaryong Panitikan at Sining sa Kanayunan. In this balagtasan, Juan Giting and Juan Kimi debated on what to do in times of extreme poverty: to keep silent or to protest?

In 2009, the University of the Philippines Sentro ng Wikang Filipino, together with the Department of Education, sponsored a National Balagtasan Competition for high school students. The four teams that were carefully selected through various levels of competition from school level to the national level provided meaningful arguments to explain relevant topics, such as Dapat Bang Magkaroon ng Uniporme sa Paaralan? (Should Wearing School Uniforms Be Required?), Dapat o Hindi Dapat Dagdagan ng Isa Pang Taon ang Hay-iskul (Should There Be an Additional One Year in High School?), and Sa Lumalalang Sitwasyong Pangkapayapaan sa Bansa, Sino ang Dapat Sisihin: Ang Tao o ang Pamahalaan? (Who Is to Blame for the Worsening Peace Situation: The People or the Government?). The competition was held at the 2,100 seating capacity UP Theater, filled with an audience comprising mostly teachers and students who would at times get excited and interrupt the mambabalagtas in the middle of their argumentation. text:
The balitaw/balitao is an extemporaneous poetic joust between a man and a woman that is accompanied by song and dance. It is a courtship play that also functions to strengthen social ties among peasant populations in the Visayas where it is performed during public celebrations, like harvest seasons and town fiestas. Before World War II, it was the most common form of entertainment in Cebuano-speaking areas of the region, including Cebu, Bohol, Negros Oriental, and Leyte. Known as balitaw in Cebuano and Hiligaynon, and balak, amoral, and ismayling in Waray, it is believed to have already existed prior to the arrival of the Spaniards in the country. With the mass migration of Visayans to Mindanao in the postwar years, the form has also reached the southern island region.

One of the earliest accounts on the balitaw is that of Jesuit missionary Francisco Ignacio Alcina in his Historia de las Islas e Indios de Bisayas (History of the Islands and Natives of Visayas), 1668. He describes the balak (balitaw to the Cebuano and Ilonggo) as a rhymed metaphorical joust between a man and a woman whose subject is commonly “the affairs of love” (Alcina 1668, 3:45). The exchanges, which are performed during drinking sessions or at work, are either verbal or musical, with the former depending largely on wit and speed. In cases when music is employed, the woman plays a kurlung while the man a kuriapi. The Cebuano balitaw, meanwhile, was originally sung to the accompaniment of a subing, a kind of bamboo flute, or a guitar made of a coconut shell. During the Spanish period, the harp, which had more chords, replaced the indigenous musical instruments.

 

It was also during the Spanish occupation that Christian values, such as self-sacrifice, respect for elders, and roles of women, were infused into the themes of the balitaw. Performances extended to Christian holidays like Christmas and feast days. The Waray balak adopted a Hispanized name, amoral, which may be a blend of the Spanish words for love and morals. The new name also hints on the didactic tendency of the form.

Americanization, which introduced more modern forms of entertainment like the motion picture and the phonograph, contributed to the alienation of the people from the form, with the balitaw getting relegated to the countryside. In response to the changes, the balitaw developed a more embellished melody that clearly drew influence from American jazz. This was called tirana. In Waray-speaking areas, the amoral came to be known as ismayling,an allusion to the smiles that the performances drew from the people who were recovering from the United States-triggered retaliatory massacres that rocked Samar. The balitaw also evolved to become a written form, which was intended to be sung. This was called balitaw romansada. Written balitaw graced the pages of local Cebuano newspapers from 1901 to the outbreak of the Pacific War in 1941. Fernando Buyser’s Mga Awit sa Kabukiran (Songs of the Countryside) contains some of the earliest Cebuano balitaw still extant.

The Japanese occupation somehow did the balitaw good for city dwellers who fled to the hills to escape Japanese tyranny and were reunited with the form. Here, during fiesta celebrations and harvests, they witnessed once more the performances.

In the postwar years, the drama-balitaw emerged, which was performed on a formal stage with drop curtains and props. Unlike the classic balitaw, it had a plot, not just a theme. It also included more characters, with the man and the woman debaters still playing lead. Radio programs also picked up on the balitaw through sponsorships from private firms, like the Philippine Manufacturing Company and San Miguel Brewery. A balitaw program was aired over DYRC from 1948 to 1950 and from 1954 to 1955. Rosas Pangdan was a balitaw produced by Pio Kabahar for film. Its theme song by the same title has become a classic.

Proof of the balitaw’s tenacity in contemporary times is its presence in unusual settings. In a corner of some cockpits in the Visayas and Mindanao, a group of men usually gather for a betting game called dejado. At the center is a dejadista, a female singer who challenges men to a balitaw. The dejadista sometimes goes unchallenged, prompting her to sing alone. The Queen of the Cebuano balitaw, Nicolasa Cañiban, more popularly known as Colasing, left Cebu for Mindanao when the balitaw’s popularity waned in the Visayas after the war. Here she made a living out of selling fish in the public market where she continued to sing the balitaw to attract customers. The Waray ismayling, on the other hand, has been used for revolutionary purposes in remote areas in the Eastern Visayas. Instead of the male courting the female, one finds the former recruiting the latter to the communist movement, thus subordinating the love element in the traditional form.

Love is the most common theme of many Cebuano balitaw. In the 1920s and 1930s when the balitaw was at its heyday, performances, which were usually held around a field clearing, began with a salutation and self-introduction by one or both contestants (Kapili 1951, 46-47). The man then proceeded to state his case with the aim of winning the woman’s affection. The woman repeatedly declined the man’s advances and the performance would last several hours until one of them was outwitted. The balitaw of Luis and Pinay, which is the most widely published Cebuano balitaw to date, shows the comic tussle that ensues immediately after the man’s salutation.

 

Luis: Kining akong paghigugma

sa bukog, Inday, mikagit

Kung hinog ka pa lang sab-a

lamyon ko hangtod ang panit.

 

Pinay: Dili ako, Luis, mutu-o

Nianang imong mga sulti

Pila na kaha ka babaye

ang imo nianang gitunto?

 

(Luis: This love of mine, Inday

is in my very bones

Were you a ripe banana

I’d swallow you unpeeled.

I don’t buy your words

I wonder how many women

have been fooled by your sweet talk?)

 

Among the Ilonggo, the balitaw is performed during the different stages of courtship.

Documented balitaw performances since the American period have been observed to follow a 3/4 time signature, like many Cebuano folk songs. The major key is set at C for happy and quirky verses while the minor key is at A for sentimental ones. The balitaw’s melody is generally monotonous but may change to adjust to the performers’ versification. This improvisation is called an ad lib. The interlude in the melody is essential to the performers for it buys them time to think of their next verses. The dance steps are generally made simple so they do not interfere with the singing and the versification. Balitaw performances are generally more sung than danced.

The audience’s preference for variety has prompted the balitaw to continuously transform. During the American occupation, the monotonous antiphonal balitaw had to compete with the polyphonic tunes of American music. This led to the replacement of the diatonic Spanish harp, which used to accompany the performances, with the more versatile Visayan five-string guitar. With a musical accompaniment capable of playing more tunes, the balitaw’s tune began to veer away from the traditional antiphonal type toward that of Western music. Such was the case of the tirana, a balitaw that draws influence from American jazz.

Experiments in form were also explored. Possibilities of a written balitaw were realized in the balitaw romansada, which sprung from the need of having to diversify the cast of the balitaw (Gutierrez 1961, 29). In the romansada, a third character who could not participate in the joust was given his/her own monologue which he or she sings. The romansada would foreshadow the creation of the drama-balitaw which had characters other than the male and female leads. In the drama-balitaw, the narrative was as imperative as the debate. The narrative element of the drama-balitaw was retained when the balitaw was adapted for radio and film in the postwar years.

The element of exchange or jousting seems to have gradually disappeared from the balitaw in the contemporary period. A dejadista, a female singer who sings the balitaw in a corner of a cockpit, may find herself singing the balitaw alone when no man takes on her challenge. article.value: One of the earliest accounts on the balitaw is that of Jesuit missionary Francisco Ignacio Alcina in his Historia de las Islas e Indios de Bisayas (History of the Islands and Natives of Visayas), 1668. He describes the balak (balitaw to the Cebuano and Ilonggo) as a rhymed metaphorical joust between a man and a woman whose subject is commonly “the affairs of love” (Alcina 1668, 3:45). The exchanges, which are performed during drinking sessions or at work, are either verbal or musical, with the former depending largely on wit and speed. In cases when music is employed, the woman plays a kurlung while the man a kuriapi. The Cebuano balitaw, meanwhile, was originally sung to the accompaniment of a subing, a kind of bamboo flute, or a guitar made of a coconut shell. During the Spanish period, the harp, which had more chords, replaced the indigenous musical instruments.

article.value: It was also during the Spanish occupation that Christian values, such as self-sacrifice, respect for elders, and roles of women, were infused into the themes of the balitaw. Performances extended to Christian holidays like Christmas and feast days. The Waray balak adopted a Hispanized name, amoral, which may be a blend of the Spanish words for love and morals. The new name also hints on the didactic tendency of the form.

Americanization, which introduced more modern forms of entertainment like the motion picture and the phonograph, contributed to the alienation of the people from the form, with the balitaw getting relegated to the countryside. In response to the changes, the balitaw developed a more embellished melody that clearly drew influence from American jazz. This was called tirana. In Waray-speaking areas, the amoral came to be known as ismayling,an allusion to the smiles that the performances drew from the people who were recovering from the United States-triggered retaliatory massacres that rocked Samar. The balitaw also evolved to become a written form, which was intended to be sung. This was called balitaw romansada. Written balitaw graced the pages of local Cebuano newspapers from 1901 to the outbreak of the Pacific War in 1941. Fernando Buyser’s Mga Awit sa Kabukiran (Songs of the Countryside) contains some of the earliest Cebuano balitaw still extant.

The Japanese occupation somehow did the balitaw good for city dwellers who fled to the hills to escape Japanese tyranny and were reunited with the form. Here, during fiesta celebrations and harvests, they witnessed once more the performances.

In the postwar years, the drama-balitaw emerged, which was performed on a formal stage with drop curtains and props. Unlike the classic balitaw, it had a plot, not just a theme. It also included more characters, with the man and the woman debaters still playing lead. Radio programs also picked up on the balitaw through sponsorships from private firms, like the Philippine Manufacturing Company and San Miguel Brewery. A balitaw program was aired over DYRC from 1948 to 1950 and from 1954 to 1955. Rosas Pangdan was a balitaw produced by Pio Kabahar for film. Its theme song by the same title has become a classic.

Proof of the balitaw’s tenacity in contemporary times is its presence in unusual settings. In a corner of some cockpits in the Visayas and Mindanao, a group of men usually gather for a betting game called dejado. At the center is a dejadista, a female singer who challenges men to a balitaw. The dejadista sometimes goes unchallenged, prompting her to sing alone. The Queen of the Cebuano balitaw, Nicolasa Cañiban, more popularly known as Colasing, left Cebu for Mindanao when the balitaw’s popularity waned in the Visayas after the war. Here she made a living out of selling fish in the public market where she continued to sing the balitaw to attract customers. The Waray ismayling, on the other hand, has been used for revolutionary purposes in remote areas in the Eastern Visayas. Instead of the male courting the female, one finds the former recruiting the latter to the communist movement, thus subordinating the love element in the traditional form.

Love is the most common theme of many Cebuano balitaw. In the 1920s and 1930s when the balitaw was at its heyday, performances, which were usually held around a field clearing, began with a salutation and self-introduction by one or both contestants (Kapili 1951, 46-47). The man then proceeded to state his case with the aim of winning the woman’s affection. The woman repeatedly declined the man’s advances and the performance would last several hours until one of them was outwitted. The balitaw of Luis and Pinay, which is the most widely published Cebuano balitaw to date, shows the comic tussle that ensues immediately after the man’s salutation.

sa bukog, Inday, mikagit
Kung hinog ka pa lang sab-a
lamyon ko hangtod ang panit.

Nianang imong mga sulti
Pila na kaha ka babaye
ang imo nianang gitunto?
(Luis: This love of mine, Inday
is in my very bones
Were you a ripe banana
I’d swallow you unpeeled.

text:
The term bodabil, also known as vodavil, vaudeville,or the stage show, refers to a stage presentation consisting of a variety of musical and comedy acts, skits and monologues, novelty and acrobatic numbers, solos and chorus lines.

Derived from French vaudeville and adapted into American theater, it entered the country during the American colonial era, although a Spanish predecessor might have been the can-can danced by Praxedes (Yeyeng) Fernandez in the zarzuelita comico-bufa titled Pascual Bailon, 1886, which triggered much positive and negative reaction, as well as a pastoral letter.

As early as 1901, the Teatro Zorrilla advertised a “Novelty in Manila” that promised “Good American Orchestra, New Acts, New Songs, Good Jokes, Acrobats, Dancers, Contortionists, The Most Brilliant and Stupendous Minstrel First Part Extant, Beautiful Lights and Scenic Effects, Gorgeous Costuming, Ragtime Talks, Ragtime Songs, Ragtime Walks, Every Feature Bright and Up to Date, Plus—A Grand Walk of All Nations!” These were at first performed by visiting troupes, such as the one that presented in 1906 the singer-dancer “Little Egypt” (“a sensation in Europe and the US”); the contortionist Eva Rowland; Beattie Gallardi, billed as queen of the comic opera; the “celebrated baritone” Willie Green; the “comedianteimprovisado” Bobby Mack; and the singing and dancing Rosebud Sisters.

Bodabil became indigenized in the second decade, when Filipino performers learned to perform in the American mode. A Cebuano called Luis Borromeo returned from America and Canada in 1921 as Borromeo Lou, and introduced Filipinos to what he called “Classic-Jazz Music.” It was he who renamed the form “vod-a-vil,” which Filipinos later adapted into “bodabil.” He organized a bodabil company, with such presentations as Foolish Wives, Noche de Jazz, and Tokiohokoyoko, and such performers (now part of bodabil history) as Natalia, a dancer; Hanasan and Toytoy (Diana Toy), singers; Maestro Back who played jazz on the xylophone; and the Alabama brothers. Jazz and the blues soon became part of Manila’s musical idiom, edging out the sarsuwela songs that had been the hits of the era.


Bodabil insinuated itself into local theater first as intermission numbers (sometimes called “jamboree,” as was the full-cast musical opening number) between major circus numbers or the acts of full-length sarsuwela, or between the three one-act plays that made up an evening’s bill. Then, when short film features called cinematografocame to town, it was also found there: songs and dances between screenings, while the film was being rewound. Soon, however, since these discrete numbers were easier to assemble into a show than were all the elements of a drama or sarsuwela, bodabil became its own attraction .

The numbers, of course, and the style of performance all came from their American models. Not only jazz and blues were introduced but also American ballads (“Ramona,” “Boulevard of Broken Dreams”) and the Latin beat (“Carioca,” “Besame Mucho”); chorus girls (their legs and short skirts eye-popping in a culture of long tresses and long skirts) and contortionists; acrobats and stand-up comics, animal tricks to rival the circuses in town, tap dancing and the jitterbug. Philippine songs, especially the kundiman (love songs), were offered, a small dish in an American smorgasbord.

 

The shows were at first staged in a boxing arena called the Olympic Stadium, but soon drifted to cinema houses, where they alternated with screenings, and coexisted with their greatest rival, the movie. By 1923, Manila had three theaters primarily devoted to bodabil: the Savoy (later renamed Clover), the Sirena, and the Rivoli; by 1941 there were 40 Manila theaters showing both bodabil and motion pictures. Eventually, in a career that unwound into the 1960s, the Clover Theater and the Manila Grand Opera House came to be known as the homes of bodabil. Impresarios—like Jose Zarah, a Portuguese dancer; Lou Salvador Sr, called the “Master Showman”; Enrique Davila; and Lazarus Joseph—devoted their time and attention to the new entertainment.

During the war years, the Japanese authorities considered the Filipinos too Western in orientation, so American movies were banned. The entertainment gap was filled by bodabil, which came to be called the stage show. This differed from prewar shows in that, although it still had the comics, the dancers, the musicians, and the kundiman singers, it also had full-length plays that employed the actors of stage and screen who had been rendered idle by the war. Often the plays were about Philippine heroes, walks of life, and people, like Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero’s Wanted: A Chaperon, 1940, and Forever, 1941; sometimes they were translations of plays like Lillian Hellman’s The Little Foxes, Noel Coward’s Private Lives, W. Jacobs’s The Monkey’s Paw, and Edmond Rostand’s Cyrano de Bergerac. The stage shows were mobbed in the war years. The gate of the Avenue Theater once crashed down in the rush of patrons awaiting curtain time.

The stage shows were especially popular because they bore hidden messages of encouragement for the war-weary people. The comedians Pugo and Togo, for example, made fun of their conquerors (and were jailed for it); skits were staged about the return of “Mang Arturo” (MacArthur). Guerrillas were said to be in the audience, needing encouragement too, with a special song sung onstage to signal to them that the Kempeitai were around. The Japanese censors’ restrictions actually caused a rebirth of the Tagalog theater, right in the theaters where Hollywood had reigned supreme.

After the war, when American films returned, bodabil countered with burlesque, colloquially called haba-haba, and in the 1950s had a brief flowering, with long lines of men waiting to get into such theaters as the Manila Grand Opera House and the Alegria. This started, however, a long downward slide, until in the 1970s the vestiges of bodabil were to be found only in sleazy theaters (where rose the bomba or sex film), where only the variety of acts remained to remind one of the old bodabil. The rest were cheap musicians and magicians, and even cheaper performers—not so much singing or dancing, as parading around in flimsy garments, in what were euphemistically called “fashion shows.” In the 1970s and 1980s, bodabil’s lowest point was visible in such places as the Gala and Cubao Cinemas, and the theaters of Olongapo, near the American base.

In its flowering and reign, however, bodabil made considerable impact on Filipino popular culture and consciousness. Aside from being entertainment that is still reflected in the variety shows on television and in the entertainment acts at political rallies, it was actually unnoticed, insidious, thorough, and pleasurable Americanization. The greats of Philippine bodabil were popularizers of American culture: the legendary Katy de la Cruz, magnificent torch singer a la Sophie Tucker; Canuplin, the “Charlie Chaplin of the Philippines”; Bayani Casimiro who was the Stan Laurel to Jose Criso Soto’s Oliver Hardy, but later glided onto the stage as the “Philippine Fred Astaire,” a title also claimed by dancer Benny Mack; all the boogie dancers and jazz/pop singers who made the American lifestyle seem so near and so desirable; and later all the talented singers who called themselves Philippine Elvis Presleys, Frank Sinatras, Perry Comos, and Joni Jameses—in the belief that they could not “make it” unless they were copies of an American original.

Through the rhythm and color of bodabil, the audience learned to see themselves in American images; the Filipino performer learned to belt and croon, to swing and sway, and, with the audience, to dream the American Dream. Today, although the stages are filled with original Philippine music, dance, drama, and performers, Diomedes Maturan, “Philippine Perry Como” of the 1950s, still sings “The Rose Tattoo” and eager young singers audition for Miss Saigon—and often make it.

Because of its popularity, bodabil itself has been used for propaganda. During the first years of Marcos’s martial law, the slogan “Sa ikauunlad ng bayan, disiplinaangkailangan” (For the country to progress, discipline is necessary) was repeatedly announced over the microphone at the “newly revived” and sanitized bodabil at the Manila Grand Opera House. For some months these shows featured plays that denounced drug pushers and “rebels” among others. Later, bodabil was again used as a form of political theater, this time against the dictatorship. In 1980-86, UP Tropang Bodabil (later Peryante), used vaudeville characters (barkers, clowns, comedy partners, sexy dancing girls), forms (dumb acts as opening numbers, magic acts, dog shows, horror shows, acrobatics, and musical dance extravaganzas to end the show), and production design (telon de boca, huge colorful props, skimpy and glittering costumes).

Plays such as Bodabil (Vaudeville), 1980, Ilokula: Ang Ilokanong Drakula I and II (Ilocula: The Ilocano Dracula), 1980 and 1983 respectively, and Bomba (Bomb), 1984, used political satire to discuss issues like imperialism, the Marcos dynasty, and the Bataan nuclear power plant. The Philippine Educational Theater Association’s Canuplin: Isang Improbisasyon sa Buhay at Mga Palabas ng Isang Komedyanteng Pilipino (Canuplin: An Improvisation on the Life and Shows of a Filipino Comedian), dramatized the pathetic life of local bodabil’s Charlie Chaplin.

In 2012, Mario O’Hara, who had done extensive research and interviews with stage show performers during the postwar years wrote the play Stageshow, the third Tanghalang Pilipino production in its 26th season. Directed by Chris Millado, the play featured Shamaine Centenera-Buencamino and Nonie Buencamino, with Liesl Batucan and Roeder Camañag as alternates. Several of the Stageshow performances featured special guests who presented special stage show or bodabil song and dance numbers in keeping with the original form during the 1950s.

Bodabil continues to live in town-fiesta stage shows, in film musicals, radio variety shows, and even political theater in rural and urban areas, proof of its enduring influence on Filipino popular culture. Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Apolonio B. Chua and Galileo S. Zafra

The greats of Philippine bodabil were popularizers of American culture: the legendary Katy de la Cruz, magnificent torch singer a la Sophie Tucker; Canuplin, the “Charlie Chaplin of the Philippines”; Bayani Casimiro who was the Stan Laurel to Jose Criso Soto’s Oliver Hardy, but later glided onto the stage as the “Philippine Fred Astaire,” a title also claimed by dancer Benny Mack; all the boogie dancers and jazz/pop singers who made the American lifestyle seem so near and so desirable; and later all the talented singers who called themselves Philippine Elvis Presleys, Frank Sinatras, Perry Comos, and Joni Jameses—in the belief that they could not “make it” unless they were copies of an American original.

Through the rhythm and color of bodabil, the audience learned to see themselves in American images; the Filipino performer learned to belt and croon, to swing and sway, and, with the audience, to dream the American Dream. Today, although the stages are filled with original Philippine music, dance, drama, and performers, Diomedes Maturan, “Philippine Perry Como” of the 1950s, still sings “The Rose Tattoo” and eager young singers audition for Miss Saigon—and often make it.

Because of its popularity, bodabil itself has been used for propaganda. During the first years of Marcos’s martial law, the slogan “Sa ikauunlad ng bayan, disiplinaangkailangan” (For the country to progress, discipline is necessary) was repeatedly announced over the microphone at the “newly revived” and sanitized bodabil at the Manila Grand Opera House. For some months these shows featured plays that denounced drug pushers and “rebels” among others. Later, bodabil was again used as a form of political theater, this time against the dictatorship. In 1980-86, UP Tropang Bodabil (later Peryante), used vaudeville characters (barkers, clowns, comedy partners, sexy dancing girls), forms (dumb acts as opening numbers, magic acts, dog shows, horror shows, acrobatics, and musical dance extravaganzas to end the show), and production design (telon de boca, huge colorful props, skimpy and glittering costumes).

Plays such as Bodabil (Vaudeville), 1980, Ilokula: Ang Ilokanong Drakula I and II (Ilocula: The Ilocano Dracula), 1980 and 1983 respectively, and Bomba (Bomb), 1984, used political satire to discuss issues like imperialism, the Marcos dynasty, and the Bataan nuclear power plant. The Philippine Educational Theater Association’s Canuplin: Isang Improbisasyon sa Buhay at Mga Palabas ng Isang Komedyanteng Pilipino (Canuplin: An Improvisation on the Life and Shows of a Filipino Comedian), dramatized the pathetic life of local bodabil’s Charlie Chaplin.

In 2012, Mario O’Hara, who had done extensive research and interviews with stage show performers during the postwar years wrote the play Stageshow, the third Tanghalang Pilipino production in its 26th season. Directed by Chris Millado, the play featured Shamaine Centenera-Buencamino and Nonie Buencamino, with Liesl Batucan and Roeder Camañag as alternates. Several of the Stageshow performances featured special guests who presented special stage show or bodabil song and dance numbers in keeping with the original form during the 1950s.

Bodabil continues to live in town-fiesta stage shows, in film musicals, radio variety shows, and even political theater in rural and urban areas, proof of its enduring influence on Filipino popular culture.

text:
Brechtian theater, also known as epic theater or theater of instruction, refers to one type of modern Philippine theater influenced and inspired by Bertolt Brecht (1898-1956). This is principally characterized by a social and pedagogical orientation and a presentational style that can employ mime, songs, dances, slides, stylized sets and costumes, and typical characters and stories taken from folklore, history, and other nonrealistic sources.

Starting in Germany in the 1920s, it became popular in the United States after 1945. Brecht’s epic theater seeks to explain and dissect issues and ideas before the audience. In this theater, each scene is presented for its own theme or variation on the main theme, resulting in a cyclical, rather than linear, play structure. To create “alienation” or critical distance between the audience and the ideas and actors on stage, songs, narrative passages, and later, film sequences, slide projections, and other devices may be used. Believing that men and women are “alterable and altering,” epic theater confronts the audience with arguments, thus awakening their capacity to act.

 

The 1960s saw the first Philippine productions of Brecht’s plays: Mother Courage and Her Children, mounted in English by Repertory Philippines, 1968, and The Good Woman of Setzuan, staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) in English, 1970, directed by the Czechoslovakian director Ladislav Smocek, and in Filipino, 1971, directed by the American director Brooks Jones. In the midst of the Westernized Filipino avant-gardist experimentation on stage on the one hand, and the political turmoil that gave birth to numerous activist theater productions on the other, the reaction to these productions was ambivalent, with the verfremdungseffekt (distancing effect) understood, in PETA’s evaluation, only as “grotesque stylization in production and performance.”

Militarization during the Marcos era underscored the need for alternative ways to express dissent, and so political theater developed more fully, incorporating diverse influences—from traditional theater to Brecht and Boal. It was then that Brechtian theater began to take root as a theater phenomenon embodying the basic principles, techniques, devices, and, more crucially, the dialectics and science of Brecht’s theater. It was one of the theater forms used to raise the level of awareness, and to organize and mobilize the citizenry into the mainstream of the culture of resistance against Marcos’s martial rule.

 

The Caucasian Chalk Circle has had many productions, among these a PETA translation in Filipino, 1977; a Dulaang UP version, 1977; a community theater production in Davao, 1980; and various interpretations in Mindanao, Cebu, and Surigao. The Life of Galileo Galilei was staged in Filipino by PETA in 1980, and became the basis for other adaptations, like the Cebuano and southern Tagalog versions. The Threepenny Opera has been presented by Dulaang UP, the MetropolitanTheater, and PETA. The DulaangKabataang Barangay staged a Filipino translation of St. Joan of the Stockyards in 1978. Puntilla and Matti was directed in Filipino by Fritz Bennewitz for the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1987. In 2009, Dulaang UP presented Ang Muntik Nang ’Di Mapigilang Paghahari ni Arturo Ui, a translation of Brecht’s The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui, directed by Alexander Cortez.

Plays that have been clearly influenced by the philosophy and works of Brecht are Paul Dumol’s Ang Paglilitis ni Mang Serapio (The Trial of Old Serapio), 1968; Bonifacio Ilagan’s Hukumang Tuwad (Upside Down Court of Justice), 1971; Rolando S.Tinio’s May Katwiran ang Katwiran (Reason Has Its Reason), 1972; Al Santos’s Mayo A-Beinte Uno Atbp. Kabanata (May 21 and Other Chapters), 1977; Ilagan’s Estados Unidos bersus Cruz, Abad at Tolentino (United States versus Cruz, Abad and Tolentino), 1981; Dong delos Reyes’s Bien Aligtad, 1985; and Jose Y. Dalisay’s Ang Butihing Babae ng Timog (The Good Woman of the South), 1992. A homage to Brecht’s Mother Courage is Don Pagusara’s Madonna Brava ng Mindanao (Madonna Brava of Mindanao), 2009. Ateneo’s ENTABLADO also used Brechtian elements in its production of Sampung mga Daliri (Ten Fingers), 2010; Juan Tamban, 2013; Isang Gabi, FB na Mapanglaw (One Night, A Solitary FB), 2014; and Gulo ng Gugulong na Ulo (Trouble from a Head Roll), 2015. Aside from these, many other plays continued to use aspects and techniques of Brechtian theater, such as characters that are types rather than individuals, choruses or commentators, narrators and singers, mime and dance, and stylized sets or props.

Fritz Bennewitz, a director from the then German Democratic Republic who directed many of the Brechtian plays in the Philippines, became the source of lessons and inspiration in Brechtian theater, which have had considerable impact on the many other community theater groups in the country. Most Brechtian productions in the communities outside Manila have been products of theater workshops conducted through the PETA outreach program, in which were duplicated the learning points from PETA’s own encounter with Brecht. This process includes a reading of Brecht works, theoretical writings, and historical background. Discussions underscore Brecht’s efforts to transform theater into pleasurable instruction for the marginalized people of his time. The chosen play is studied closely, with the basic contradiction in it pointed out in relation to the social forces in Brecht’s time and society as well as in contemporary Philippine society. Understanding Brecht is completed when actual rehearsals and discussions begin, and wrong notions about Brecht’s theater are corrected. In this way, the Brechtian verfremdungseffekt becomes not only a reorientation, much less a theatrical technique, but also a revival of collective political energy and a redirection of the citizens’ will toward a real power of the people. During the Marcos regime, the philosophy and techniques of Brecht’s epic theater greatly influenced the creation of a people’s theater.  Written by Maria Luisa T. Reyes, updated by Apolonio B. Chua, Tyron Judes de la Calsada Casumpang, and Galileo S. Zafra

text:
Carillo, from the Spanish carrillo or “small cart,” referred both to the little open-air theaters of bamboo and to the shadow plays shown in them in the late 19th century. The form was also known as potei, kikimut, and titire in Pampanga.

On a stage with crudely painted scenery were presented cardboard figures held up by means of wooden sticks before a lighted lamp, and projected against a white sheet. Through pantomimic movement and dialogue provided by the manipulators, they presented stories from the awit and korido, or metrical romances about lives of saints or the adventures of chivalric figures—the same material used in the komedya.

Calle Magdalena at San Jose de Trozo (in what is now the Santa Cruz district) was the site of a popular carillo theater run by one Navarro (Navarrito) de Peralta, whose repertoire is said to have included Don Juan Tenorio, Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), Siete Infantes da Lara (Seven Sons of Lara), La Tia Norica (The Aunt Norica), and Los Sudores del Rey Momo (The Toils of King Momo), shown to audiences composed mainly of the young. Fees charged at the gate ranged from two to four quartos for those without seats (who sat on their haunches before the low stage), half a real for benches, and one real for chairs. Some carillo were offered for free, like those of Vicente Letran, who put on a carrillo de sombras (little cart of shadows) from the window of his house; of Natalio Pascual, whose free show ran in Dilao (now Paco) for three weeks from 8:00 to 11:00 every evening; and of Gabriel Mercado, a laborer, whose carillo was run by young boys in training. These were approved by the authorities on condition that an officer of the guardia civil (constabulary) would make regular inspections. The Pampanga potei or kikimut, which supposedly used wooden puppets, were presented by “Chinese workers” in vacant lots in the evenings.

 

There has been no further evidence of the carillo after the Spanish period. However, some present-day theater groups have used a version of it for some of their productions, such as the Philippine Educational Theater Association’s Dupluhang Bayan (People’s Poetic Joust) and plays by the Susi ng Tayabas of Quezon province. Contemporary shadow and puppetry plays may also be considered to have been influenced by the carillo. Teatrong Mulat, based in the University of the Philippines Diliman’s College of Arts and Letters, and Anino Shadowplay Collective, based in the Philippine High School for the Arts, are examples. Elements of shadow play have been used in plays like Umaaraw, Umuulan, Kinakasalang Tikbalang (Sun Shining, Rain Pouring, Horse Demons Wed), 2011, and Bilanggo ng Pag-ibig (Prisoner of Love), 2014, both by Jose Estrella for Dulaang UP.

In 2014, El Gamma Penumbra, the shadow play group from Tanauan, Batangas, won the first season of Asia’s Got Talent. The group’s productions are noted for their imaginative and effective use of shadows, using only their bodies and a minimum of props to create images of humans, flora, and fauna smoothly morphing into each other. Before winning Asia’s Got Talent, the group placed fourth in the Philippine version of the franchise. It was chosen to be part of the Philippine tourism campaign “Choose Philippines” and was frequently invited to do television, community, and corporate shows. The group’s repertoire highlighted the creative use of shadow play not just for entertainment but in communicating timely developmental messages to a wide variety of audiences. Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Galileo S. Zafra, with notes from Apolonio B. Chua and Josefina F. Estrella
