text:
Children’s theater may refer to plays with children as actors, or plays performed by adults for children. The aims of children’s theater in the Philippines go beyond self-expression, toward the encouragement of creativity and self-esteem among children, and beyond entertainment, toward value formation and cultural formation through an appreciation of Philippine history, culture, and artistry.

School-Based Children’s Theater. Theater with children as actors is often school based. In the case of the Ateneo Children’s Theater (ACT), which has been producing an annual play since 1931, a large number of grade school boys and girls from neighboring schools, like Maryknoll (later Miriam) and St. Bridget School, learn about theater, values and people, and history and society while developing their artistic talents. For decades the plays of ACT were directed by Mariano Singson.

 

The Ateneo Children’s Theater has regularly mounted children’s plays, both foreign and Filipino, from various sources, using different forms of theater. These include Lualhati (Glory), 1983; Tolda (Canvas Awning), 1984; Ignatius of Loyola, 1991, Joseph and His Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat, 1993; Aladdin, 1994; Mga Prinsipe ng Dagat (The Princes of the Sea), 1995; Batubayani (Stone Hero), 1996; Gregorio del Pilar: Ang Batang Heneral (Gregorio del Pilar: The Young General), 1997; Mga Bata ng Himagsikan (Children of War), 1998; Sa Ngalan ng Ama (In the Name of the Father), 2000; Agyu, 2001; The Wiz, 2002; Fiddler on the Roof, 2003; Big: The Musical, 2004; The King and I, 2005; Seussical: The Musical, 2006; Beauty and the Beast, 2007; High School Musical, 2008; Adarna at ang Alaala ng Kristal (Adarna and the Memory of Crystal), 2009; Batang Rizal (Young Rizal), 2010; Ang Nawalang Kapatid (The Missing Sibling), 2011; Astig (Cool), 2012; Kules, 2013; Alex in Wonderland, 2014; and Mga Kuwentong Hari (King’s Stories), 2015.

Also school-based is the Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas in the University of the Philippines (UP), where its founder, Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio, was an English literature professor. Lapeña-Bonifacio uses Asian theater influences in her creation of puppets and of plays for children, such as Abadeja: Ang Ating Sinderela (Abadeja: Our Own Cinderella), 1977, and Papet Pasyon (The Passion of Jesus Christ in Puppetry), 1986. The puppeteers are young people, usually university students; the audience, children from schools or communities gathered at the Teatrong Mulat Theater in Teacher’s Village, Quezon City, or at various auditoriums in and out of the university, or at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP).

 

The St. Scholastica’s College Manila’s Children and Teachers Theater group was launched in 1990 by its artistic director, Naty Crame-Rogers, through the initiative of grade school principal Florina Feliciano-Castillo. Building on the concept of “drama in education,” or DIE, which began in the United States and Europe in the 1960s, theater has been integrated into the curriculum as a method of teaching, specifically in the language, social studies, and humanities courses in Grades IV, V, VI, and VII. As part of the curriculum, all students are required to attend and participate in their particular level’s annual production, for which classroom discussions and homeroom assignments are given and graded at the start and end of the production. During their particular production months, formal classroom procedures are stopped (except in the math and science subjects) to give both the students and teachers time to work on the play. In 1992, with a view to developing knowledge and understanding of the classics, as well as Southeast Asian heritage and Benedictine values, the Grade IV presentation was Rizal’s Junto al Pasig (Beside the Pasig), presented at the CCP and featuring professional Lou Veloso in the role of Satan; the Grade V presentation was Antonio Bayon’s Radia Malakas (Rajah Malakas); Grade VI presented Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream;and Grade VII presented the Benedictine Pageant,a pageant about Saints Benedict and Scholastica.

The Sining Pangkabataan was founded by its director Antee Bass-Hernandez in Dec 1988 and is based at the UP Department of Speech and Theater Arts. An offshoot of the 1988 CCP Summer Children’s Theater Workshop, the group produced original Filipino musicals: Tagisan (Struggle), 1988, with libretto by Lerric Santos and choreography by Douglas Nierras; Tikbalang, 1989, written and staged by college students from UP; Munting Mithi (Little Dream), 1990, the group’s first co-production with the UP Integrated School (UPIS), involving 450 children from the UPIS Kindergarten to Grade II; Mamahalin Kita: Kali-K-san (I Will Love You, Nature), 1991, a kabuki-inspired play conceptualized by Bass-Hernandez; and Pagdiriwang (Celebration), 1992, written by a pool of writers headed by Rhea Preclaro. Initially an adult group performing for children, it now helps child performers take the stage for their peers.

 

The Philippine High School for the Arts’ An-i-no: Shadow Puppet Collective, composed of graduates and students, was formed in 1993. The group premiered at the CCP in Feb 1993 with a highly improvisational multimedia puppetry production titled The Shadow Play,an interpretation of 13 different popular songs, including Yoyoy Villame’s “Buchikik” and “Magellan,” and original compositions by Joey Ayala and Edru Abraham’s Kontra-Gapi. The group experimented with both nontraditional and traditional theater gadgets and methods, such as shadow play with the puppeteers’ own hands and bodies; images created by “playing” with a slide projector and objects such as sand; and the puppeteers “acting” with the shadows and puppets. The CCP has toured An-i-no’s shows in different provinces.

A special category of children’s theater is theater used as therapy, such as the theater developed in the 1980s for “special” children—victims of violence, witnesses to family deaths from military clashes or political torture, or themselves survivors of torture, harassment, or grave physical injury. article.value: School-Based Children’s Theater. Theater with children as actors is often school based. In the case of the Ateneo Children’s Theater (ACT), which has been producing an annual play since 1931, a large number of grade school boys and girls from neighboring schools, like Maryknoll (later Miriam) and St. Bridget School, learn about theater, values and people, and history and society while developing their artistic talents. For decades the plays of ACT were directed by Mariano Singson.

article.value: The Ateneo Children’s Theater has regularly mounted children’s plays, both foreign and Filipino, from various sources, using different forms of theater. These include Lualhati (Glory), 1983; Tolda (Canvas Awning), 1984; Ignatius of Loyola, 1991, Joseph and His Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat, 1993; Aladdin, 1994; Mga Prinsipe ng Dagat (The Princes of the Sea), 1995; Batubayani (Stone Hero), 1996; Gregorio del Pilar: Ang Batang Heneral (Gregorio del Pilar: The Young General), 1997; Mga Bata ng Himagsikan (Children of War), 1998; Sa Ngalan ng Ama (In the Name of the Father), 2000; Agyu, 2001; The Wiz, 2002; Fiddler on the Roof, 2003; Big: The Musical, 2004; The King and I, 2005; Seussical: The Musical, 2006; Beauty and the Beast, 2007; High School Musical, 2008; Adarna at ang Alaala ng Kristal (Adarna and the Memory of Crystal), 2009; Batang Rizal (Young Rizal), 2010; Ang Nawalang Kapatid (The Missing Sibling), 2011; Astig (Cool), 2012; Kules, 2013; Alex in Wonderland, 2014; and Mga Kuwentong Hari (King’s Stories), 2015.

Also school-based is the Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas in the University of the Philippines (UP), where its founder, Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio, was an English literature professor. Lapeña-Bonifacio uses Asian theater influences in her creation of puppets and of plays for children, such as Abadeja: Ang Ating Sinderela (Abadeja: Our Own Cinderella), 1977, and Papet Pasyon (The Passion of Jesus Christ in Puppetry), 1986. The puppeteers are young people, usually university students; the audience, children from schools or communities gathered at the Teatrong Mulat Theater in Teacher’s Village, Quezon City, or at various auditoriums in and out of the university, or at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP).

article.value: The St. Scholastica’s College Manila’s Children and Teachers Theater group was launched in 1990 by its artistic director, Naty Crame-Rogers, through the initiative of grade school principal Florina Feliciano-Castillo. Building on the concept of “drama in education,” or DIE, which began in the United States and Europe in the 1960s, theater has been integrated into the curriculum as a method of teaching, specifically in the language, social studies, and humanities courses in Grades IV, V, VI, and VII. As part of the curriculum, all students are required to attend and participate in their particular level’s annual production, for which classroom discussions and homeroom assignments are given and graded at the start and end of the production. During their particular production months, formal classroom procedures are stopped (except in the math and science subjects) to give both the students and teachers time to work on the play. In 1992, with a view to developing knowledge and understanding of the classics, as well as Southeast Asian heritage and Benedictine values, the Grade IV presentation was Rizal’s Junto al Pasig (Beside the Pasig), presented at the CCP and featuring professional Lou Veloso in the role of Satan; the Grade V presentation was Antonio Bayon’s Radia Malakas (Rajah Malakas); Grade VI presented Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream;and Grade VII presented the Benedictine Pageant,a pageant about Saints Benedict and Scholastica.

The Sining Pangkabataan was founded by its director Antee Bass-Hernandez in Dec 1988 and is based at the UP Department of Speech and Theater Arts. An offshoot of the 1988 CCP Summer Children’s Theater Workshop, the group produced original Filipino musicals: Tagisan (Struggle), 1988, with libretto by Lerric Santos and choreography by Douglas Nierras; Tikbalang, 1989, written and staged by college students from UP; Munting Mithi (Little Dream), 1990, the group’s first co-production with the UP Integrated School (UPIS), involving 450 children from the UPIS Kindergarten to Grade II; Mamahalin Kita: Kali-K-san (I Will Love You, Nature), 1991, a kabuki-inspired play conceptualized by Bass-Hernandez; and Pagdiriwang (Celebration), 1992, written by a pool of writers headed by Rhea Preclaro. Initially an adult group performing for children, it now helps child performers take the stage for their peers.

Children’s theater productions and practices in the Philippines prove that even for children, theater is meant not only to entertain young audiences but also to educate and transform them into agents of change.

text:
The dapit, from Tagalog dapit or “to fetch,” refers to the custom of fetching the image of the patron saint of the town or barangay on the eve or the day of the fiesta. Usually, a group of men and women—sometimes with flowers, fans, or leaves in their hands—dance a balitaw or balse to the accompaniment of brass bands as they proceed to the house of the camarera, or caretaker, of the saint’s image, in order to salute and escort it to the church or chapel. There the image stays until it goes out in procession (called prusisyon) on the streets, or on the river or sea (called pagoda or karakol) on the day of the fiesta.

One of the longest dapit in the country today is the one for the Maria Salome in Caniogan, Malolos, Bulacan. Here, on the morning of Easter Sunday, right after the salubong (meeting) of the Risen Christ and the Virgin Mary, which is “witnessed” by Maria Salome and the other saints of Christ’s passion, a brass band and hordes of devotees “fetch” the image of Maria Salome from the patio of Santa Isabel Church, and “escort” it back to its chapel. It takes four to five hours or more to negotiate the one-kilometer distance between the church and the chapel, because the male and female devotees, who brandish flowers and leaves in their hands and wear outlandish hats and costumes, also engage in lighthearted drinking and banter, moving the procession backward and forward as they please.

 

Another dapit happens on the feast of the Ascension of the Risen Christ. Forty days after His resurrection, Christ was supposed to have ascended bodily into heaven. In Malolos, the feast is celebrated with a high mass at the cathedral, after which the Pagkabuhay or image of the resurrected Christ, having stayed at the altar since Easter Sunday, is “fetched” by devotees from Atlag, a barrio of Malolos, about two or three kilometres from the cathedral. The devotees come all the way from Atlag, accompanied by the karo of their patron saint San Antonio de Padua, to “fetch” the image of its “barrio mate,” the Pagkabuhay, also owned by a family in Atlag. The devotees, mostly women, dance to the music of a brass band, waving their hands to the left and to the right as they sway to the pandanggo beat. The procession moves slowly on its way toward the cathedral and arrives in time for the mass. After the mass, the statue of the resurrected Christ is taken down from the altar and placed on its own karo (the same one used for the salubong). The band plays a merry tune and the procession enacting the pag-akyat (ascension) begins, with the devotees dancing in two rows as they accompany the karo of San Antonio and the Pagkabuhay back to the house of the Pagkabuhay’scamarera in Atlag. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
The dotoc is a religious devotion to the Holy Cross. Every year in April and May, communities in the Bicol region of the Philippines perform the dotocfor nine days. The term “dotoc” is an archaic Bikol word for pilgrimage, the narrative contained in the dotocas cultural performance.

In 2008, there were at least four active dotoc practices: the cobacho dotoc in Baao, the dotoc as komedya in Nabua, the dotoc and lagaylay in Canaman, Camarines Sur, and the dotoc and komedya in Bigaa, Legazpi City in Albay.

The basic narrative is that of a pilgrimage: a group of pilgrims sets out to look for the Holy Cross, finds it, and, upon finding it, adores and praises it and submits their petitions for peace, justice, prosperity, good health, and deliverance from evil. All of the four dotoc forms follow this narrative, but they can be further grouped into two: (1) those that tell of the pilgrimage of ordinary, unnamed folk, and (2) those that depict the pilgrimage of Elena and Constantino. The second group takes on the form of the komedya. Distinct from the above dotoc is the lagaylay of Canaman and nearby towns of Camarines Sur, whose action is set at the end of the pilgrimage, after the cross is found.

 

The Cobacho Dotoc of Baao. The cobacho dotoc text tells of a group of pilgrims who journey to the Holy Land to visit the Holy Cross. On their way, the pilgrims come upon a cobacho (shed/shelter) with people inside. The pilgrims are dissuaded by the people in the cobacho, who heard that the Cross had been stolen. The pilgrims refute this by saying the Cross that had been stolen has already been recovered, and they proceed to recount the tale.

According to the narrative, the Holy Cross was stolen and brought to Persia by the Persian king Cosrohas (Chosroes), who conquered Byzantine territory. The emperor Heraclio (Heraclius, Byzantine emperor from 610 to 641 AD) waged war against Persia and won. Cosrohas was killed by his son Serwis, who then ruled Persia; Serwis then surrendered all to Heraclio, including the Holy Cross, which was then returned by the emperor to the Holy Land. The emperor attempted to carry the Cross up Calvary as Jesus did, but could not do it until he shed his rich clothes, ornaments, and crown to become like Jesus, who was a poor man. After the tale of Heraclio is told, the people in the cobachojoin the pilgrims. Upon reaching the Holy Land, they praise and adore the Cross and adorn it with flowers. They then sing the “Vexilla Regis” (Royal Banner), offer their petitions for mercy and blessings in the “Pasion,” and end by singing the “Adios.” The “Vexilla Regis” is the Latin hymn composed in 569 CE by the poet and bishop of Poitiers, Venantius Fortunatus (530-609 CE), to celebrate the receipt in a solemn procession of a relic of the True Cross (Rousseau 1967, 635).

Specific directions for the performance are given in a surviving copy of a printed text (Dotoc 1895). The patanid (instructions) call for two pairs of paradotoc (women cantors) to start at a distance from the altar, in an enramada (roofed structure); to walk slowly to the cobacho constructed midway between the starting point and the altar; to stop there and have a “conversation” with two other pairs of paradotoc; and then for all of the paradotoc to process to the altar, the “Holy Land” wherein they “find” the Cross. At the cobacho, there should be a table on which will be placed bandera (flags) and media luna (half-moons) arranged in an alternating position, and various flowers to be offered at the altar when the paradotoc reach it. The instructions for the action appear in the text from the beginning to the departure scene.

The “Pasion de Dotoc” comprises praises and adoration of the Holy Cross and petitions for graces in this life and in the hereafter. The “Adios” is the leave-taking, whose last two quatrains bid farewell to the Holy Cross, coming after the petitions for mercy so that the paradotocmay “attain the glory of heaven now and forever.”

All copies of the dotoc text are called orihinal (original). The last printed copy is most probably the 1939 print by an Imprenta La Sinceridad of Tabaco, Albay (Recepcion 1997), but most paradotoc have not seen any printed copy of the text—only orihinal copied by hand and passed down from mother to daughter, or among peers.

The language used is Naga Bikol, which is the Bikol used by the Church and claimed by many to be the lingua franca Bikol. The orthography generally follows the orthodox Hispanized spelling of Bikol words. The verses are octosyllabic, generally monorhymed quatrains, arranged in sets of four, each quatrain sung by a row of cantors.

Cobacho Dotoc in Tinago. In Tinago, Bigaa, Legazpi City, the cobacho dotoc is performed using exactly the same text used in Baao, but with an altogether different performance. The dotoc of Tinago is actually a combination of the dotoc and komedya. The cobacho dotoc is performed at seven o’clock in the evening between the main body of the komedya and the concluding scene on the “Holy Land,” where the dotoc singers join the komedya performers for a grand finale. The dotoc cantoras are teenage girls who sing the lines with lamano (hand gestures) and at certain parts they wave the paper flags and half-moons. The girls walk briskly on the dark path leading to the altar, with boys lighting the way with gas lamps (petromax).

Dotoc in Canaman. In Canaman, the dotoc is an action prayer consisting of praises and petitions offered to the Cross. The lines are sung all throughout, with some parts recited (Mampo 1980, 61-62). A notador or maestra (teacher) dictates the lines to the performers, the resulting effect being a rhythm of sung lines and the notador’s dictation. The performance is held for nine days, using a text for each of the first eight days and a choice of nine more for the ninth day. The action progresses from the women cantors expressing a desire to adore the Cross and then doing so for the first two days, to the women going in search of the Cross, which they find and adore, on the third day, and variations of the search and finding on the fourth to the ninth (Mampo 1980, 66). All “action” happens in the engramada, or roofed performance space, and the “journey” or walking is a mere few steps toward the front of the altar.

The Dotoc as Komedya in Baras and Tinago. The dotoc as komedya depicts Elena’s finding of the Cross. It is performed in Baras, Nabua, and in Tinago, Bigaa, in Legazpi City. The Baras performance has two parts: Elena and Constantino’s battle with a Moorish Emperadora, and the pilgrimage to find the Cross. In Bigaa, the komedya covers only the pilgrimage to the Holy Land. The Bigaa folk call their performance “komedya,” while the Baras folk refer to it only as “dotoc.”

The action of the dotoc as komedya is focused on the encounter between the Christians (Elena, Constantino, and their troops) and Moors (the Emperadora and her troops) and on the embassies sent by both parties to each other, first for the battle and then afterward, at the defeat of the latter, for the terms of surrender. This first part ends with the Emperadora and her troops being converted to Elena’s religion. The second part consists of the pilgrimage to find the Cross of Jesus. Here, tension is provided by the refusal of an old man to reveal what he knows of the whereabouts of the Cross. Elena directs the soldiers to put him in a well and starve him for three days. He relents and leads the entourage to the “mountain.” Elena orders the soldiers and ladies-in-waiting to dig in the area pointed out by the old man, and they find three crosses, three nails, and the crown of thorns, leaving them confused as to which of the three crosses found is Christ’s. God sends an angel who tells them to have a sick person kiss the three crosses; the one that heals him is the True Cross. They also test the crosses on a dead person; the cross able to resurrect the dead is Christ’s Cross.

The Lagaylay in Canaman. In the lagaylay, Elena and her entourage sing and dance their prayers in front of the newly found cross (Realubit 1976, 418). Santa Elena is joined by a pair of spokeswomen called respondes, a pair of flag bearers/wavers called paraduyag, and four to six pairs of panamparan or guards of honor. Praises to the Cross are sung in repeated stanzas, which have sections where the performers, generally referred to as cantoras (singers), form themselves into the letters of the word S-T-A-C-R-U-Z, and finally into a cross formation. There are also sections for flag waving, for blessing the Cross with incense carried by the respondes, for reciting verses, for offering flowers, and finally—the highlight of the lagaylay—for Elena to offer her crown to the Cross as a sign of her humility. The cantoras dance, kneel, or stand as they sing the lines that they have memorized (there is no notador or prompter). The performance is capped off with a square dance, in the style of the rigodon de honor, by Elena and the rest of the pilgrims. Written by Jazmin Badong Llana

text:
In the vernacular tradition, drama refers to one specific type of traditional play, which uses prose dialogue and focuses on Filipino characters and situations. Although “drama” in contemporary theater refers to the literary genre of enacted fiction, the term refers to just one kind of play in the local tradition. It has also been called dulang pang-araw-araw (drama of everyday life), dulang kataw-anan (comedy) or dulang mahinuk-logon (tragedy), and, depending on the content, dulang social, lirico, romantico,and politikal.

The drama in Philippine folk theater is a versatile form that has through history dealt with a range of subject matter with prose as principal medium, although verse has been used, solely or in combination with prose. Along with the sarsuwela, it was introduced during the Spanish colonial period by traveling troupes from Spain. In the 19th century, Spanish (Calderon de la Barca, Lope de Vega, Rojas Zorrilla, Ruiz de Alarcon) and other European (Corneille, Goethe, Moliére, Schiller, Shakespeare) plays were published in the local Spanish-language journal La Oceania Española,and thus made available to local readers. Spanish plays were also performed by visiting troupes from Spain, and eventually local playwrights, both peninsulares (Spanish born in Spain) and insulares (Spanish born in the Philippines)— Manuel Romero, Camilo Millan, Jose Conde, Mariano Garcia, Eduardo Saavedra, Eduardo Castañer—were writing dramas about Philippine life and mores. Saavedra’s revista comico lirica (comic-lyric review), for example, staged in Iloilo in March 1896, was called A 7 con 7 el Pico (Seven Pesos and Seven Reales a Picul), because it was about local currency and sugar prices.

 

By the turn of the century, Filipino playwrights were writing dramas in their own languages about various aspects of their daily lives. Tomas Remigio’s Mga Santong Tao (People Saints), 1901, in mixed verse and prose, is the story of Ambrosio and Titay, a poor couple. To compound the travails of poverty, Titay is being courted by the cura (priest), the sakristan mayor (head sacristan), and the piskal (prosecutor). The couple give the three adjacent “visiting hours,” and each knock on the door sends the incumbent visitor scurrying to hide in a room filled with holy images. At the end, some church people arrive to borrow statues for the procession, and find the three men frozen in the guises of a Nazareno, a Christ on the Cross, and an Ecce Homo—all suffering, if not Christlike, and well aware that Ambrosio and Titay had their sweet vengeance.

The drama simboliko of 1902-1906 that the American insular government saw as “seditious” was also drama politikal, using allegory and symbol to present the current realities of the American occupation and colonization. Fernandez

article.value: The drama in Philippine folk theater is a versatile form that has through history dealt with a range of subject matter with prose as principal medium, although verse has been used, solely or in combination with prose. Along with the sarsuwela, it was introduced during the Spanish colonial period by traveling troupes from Spain. In the 19th century, Spanish (Calderon de la Barca, Lope de Vega, Rojas Zorrilla, Ruiz de Alarcon) and other European (Corneille, Goethe, Moliére, Schiller, Shakespeare) plays were published in the local Spanish-language journal La Oceania Española,and thus made available to local readers. Spanish plays were also performed by visiting troupes from Spain, and eventually local playwrights, both peninsulares (Spanish born in Spain) and insulares (Spanish born in the Philippines)— Manuel Romero, Camilo Millan, Jose Conde, Mariano Garcia, Eduardo Saavedra, Eduardo Castañer—were writing dramas about Philippine life and mores. Saavedra’s revista comico lirica (comic-lyric review), for example, staged in Iloilo in March 1896, was called A 7 con 7 el Pico (Seven Pesos and Seven Reales a Picul), because it was about local currency and sugar prices.

text:
The term drama simboliko refers to allegorical drama, especially that which was called “seditious” by the American insular government in the first decade. Most of these plays were banned, and their playwrights jailed, because their “unmistakable tendency,” the American-dominated Supreme Court decision said, was to “inculcate a spirit of hatred and enmity against the American people and the Government of the United States in the Philippines, and … incite the people of the Philippine Islands to open and armed resistance to the constituted authorities, and to induce them to conspire together for the secret organization of armed forces … for the purpose of overthrowing the present Government and setting up another in its stead.” These first nationalist Philippine dramas were cognizant of and eloquent about the concept of and the need for nation, their playwrights and audiences undeterred by the arrests, closure, and imprisonment they suffered.

The historical events that led to these dramas started with the failure of the Reform Movement to win reforms from Spain; the arrest, banishment, and eventual execution of Jose Rizal; the Philippine Revolution against Spain, 1896-98; the declaration of Philippine Independence in 1898; American entry into the country as “friends” of the Filipinos against Spain; and the Treaty of Paris in 1898, through which Spain ceded the Philippines to the United States without consultation with the Filipino people. This was followed by the Philippine-American War, identified by American documents as the “Philippine Insurrection,” which, with Theodore Roosevelt’s declaration of general amnesty in 1902, ended officially but not actually, since the Filipinos continued to fight until about 1907.

 

The period between 1902 and 1906 was the era of “seditious” drama. It was a form of guerrilla warfare directly contrary to Act 292, the Sedition Act, which made advocacy of Philippine independence a crime. Section 10 was later to be invoked in the arrest of the anti-American dramatists: “it shall be unlawful for any person to advance orally or by writing or printing or like methods, the independence of the Philippine Islands or their separation from the United States …”

Juan Abad’s Tanikalang Guinto (Golden Chain), first staged at the Teatro Libertad on 7 July 1902, and subsequently in other theaters in Manila and the provinces, had its Batangas, Batangas, performance on 10 May 1903 closed down, and the author indicted for sedition. While the case was pending in court, Abad, out under bail, wrote Isang Punglo ng Kaaway (An Enemy’s Bullet), which was produced at the Teatro Rizal in Malabon on 8 May 1904, leading to Abad’s second arrest. Hindi Aco Patay (I Am Not Dead) by Juan Matapang Cruz, when presented on 8 May 1903 at the Teatro Nueva Luna in Malabon, caused a riot, the arrest of the theater manager, the banning of the play, and the confiscation of the props, among them Katipunan flags and revolutionary emblems. Ten of the actors and the author were later arrested. Cruz served his two-year sentence in full.

Aurelio Tolentino’s Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas (Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow) played to a packed house on 4 May 1903 at the Teatro Libertad, and caused the arrest of members of the company and of Tolentino, who was charged with sedition and found guilty. Among other plays suppressed were Ang Kalayaang Hindi Natupad (The Freedom Not Attained), closed in Obando, Bulacan, on 15 May 1903; Pulong Pinaglahuan (Island Subjugated), raided in Navotas, Rizal, on 23 Jan 1904, after which 20 performers and the author, Mariano Martinez, were arrested; Dahas ng Pilak (Silver Force), closed at the Teatro Nueva Luna in Malabon, Rizal, on 1 May 1904 with 11 actors, the author and manager arrested; and Ang Katipunan (The Katipunan) by Gabriel Beato Francisco, staged on 21 Feb 1905 at Laoag, Ilocos Norte, at which the entire audience was reportedly arrested.

In form, these plays were drama: largely prose, although they used some patriotic songs—for example, the forbidden “Himno Nacional,” which was not in the script but was inserted when the American Military Police were not in sight. Their plots were based on the love situations popular in the komedya and sarsuwela,but the names and relationships elevated the characters and situations to symbol, allegory, and statement.

Thus in Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas, Inangbayan (Mother Country) is mother to Taga-ilog (the Filipino people), who is imprisoned by Dilat-na-bulag (Spain) at the instigation of Halimau (Spanish friar), and betrayed by Asalhayop and Dahumpalay (Filipino traitors). In Tanikalang Guinto, Liwanag (Light, Spirit of Independence) is kept from marrying Kaulayaw (Filipino revolutionary) by her uncle Maimbot (American government) aided by Kaulayaw’s brother Nagtapon (Filipino mercenary).

Like the komedya and the sinakulo, these plays won their audiences with visual spectacle, but this time loaded with hope and meaning: the red sun of the Katipunan rising; Diwa and Liwanag ascending in a bubble as devils take Nagtapon, and Kamatayan claims Maimbot; tombs opening as Inangbayan falls; and the Philippine flag being formed onstage by girls garbed in the appropriate colors and quickly going in and out of formation. Although the traditional theater conventions used were familiar to the people, they were infused with symbol and meaning, and the message they bore—the need to fight the new colonizers and gain independence—was new, and as current as the day’s newspapers.

Definitely new was this concern: national in dimension, political in character, with persuasion and action as goals. Unlike indigenous drama, the drama simboliko was not limited to regional or community boundaries. Unlike the colonial drama of the Spanish period, it was not about Christianity or the loves and wars of European nobility. It was anti-American because it was pro-Filipino, pro-independence, and for freedom.

When in 1907 the first Philippine Assembly was inaugurated, this political allegorical drama ceased, because the fight for independence transferred from the battlefields and drama stages to the halls of legislation and negotiation, closing a proud chapter of protest in Philippine theater history.

The drama simboliko has not ceased to exist, however. Some of the “seditious” plays were revived, with new meaning, in the Marcos regime. Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas has been shown whole and in parts, with Taga-ilog obviously symbolizing as well the political prisoners of the Marcos regime, and Halimaw the cruelty of their jailers. As presented by PETA in 1990, Taga-ilog was played by three actors, representing the struggle of the Filipino people in different periods of the country’s history. Bonifacio Ilagan’s Estados Unidos bersus Cruz, Abad at Tolentino (United States versus Cruz, Abad and Tolentino), 1981, examines the phenomenon of protest theater, and Rody Vera’s Isang Rihersal (A Rehearsal), 1982, the revival of nationalist plays—both by building their plays around bits of “seditious” dramas.

In those periods of Philippine history when speaking directly was not possible, the drama simboliko showed the power of symbol and the currency of theater. Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
A dramatic monologue is a type of modern play that features one actor as the main character of the play, speaking and acting out his or her innermost thoughts and emotions.

As a poetic form, the dramatic monologue was the “favored mode of a particular literary period” between 1830 and 1930. One well-known example is Robert Browning’s My Last Duchess, in which the persona speaks directly to the reader as an actual historical figure rather than as poet.

As a theatrical form, the dramatic monologue has often been used for one-person performances on historical figures and events (such as Winston Churchill and World War II), and on the life and works of writers (such as Emlyn Williams on Charles Dickens).

In Philippine theater, the form has been especially favored, as it requires minimal set design and props and is therefore inexpensive to produce; and further, as it lends itself to many creative variations. The tula-dula (literally, poem-play), for example, is a variant in which a lone actor/narrator speaks, and the other(s) play all the parts.

 

In Tony Perez’s Alex Antiporda, 1974, a student, Alex, enacts a monologue, his reply to a question asked of him in an oral exam by an imaginary panel of philosophy professors. In explaining what is meant by Martin Buber’s I-and-Thou relationship, he reveals his own pain at being treated as an object by his “closest” friends.

Kuwadro (Portrait) by Isagani R. Cruz, 1980, portrays Katerina Alonzo, an aging actress, formerly a sarsuwela star, recalling the glories of her past.

In Chris Millado’s Ang Nazarena (The Nazarene Woman), 1983, part of a trilogy on three women from Jose Rizal’s novel Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), Sisa’s scene features a powerful dramatic monologue which counterpoints to the trilogy of scenes, structured more as “duets” featuring the same actor and actress.

Tatalon,1983, by Rogelio Sicat, features one actor playing a jeepney character narrating the suicide of a welder.

 

In Anton Juan Jr’s Taong Grasa (Tramp), 1981, a common half-deranged tramp, who is clad in rags and black from dirt, speaks of his daily struggles to exist and his plight as a nonperson.

In Buwanat Baril sa E-flat Major (Moon and Gun in E-flat Major), 1985, also by Millado, a play in five scenes with prologue and epilogue, two scenes are dramatic monologues. “Ang Socialite” has a wealthy young woman preparing to attend a street demonstration in which she expects a confrontation with the military. In “Ang Asawa,” a teacher goes to identify and claim the corpse of her husband, a member of the New People’s Army who is said to have been “killed in an encounter,” but who, she finds, was shot at close range while eating.

Alimuom (Steam of the Earth) by Reuel Molina Aguila, 1989, sees a reformed armed soldier seeking out his fellow torturers under the Marcos regime, in order to “silence” them so that his own involvement in the torturing of political detainees will not be exposed.

Kudeta (Coup d’Etat), also by Millado, 1990, is a humorous monologue in which a radio announcer talks, eats, dozes off, receives, and relays reports from his reporter-in-the-field on the attempted coup d’etat of Dec 1989.

Tonyo, Pepe at Pule (Tonyo, Pepe, and Pule), 1991, by Rene O. Villanueva, Malou Jacob, and Paul Dumol, respectively, shows Antonio Luna, Jose Rizal, and Apolinario Mabini struggling with personal pains and conflicts during the periods of reform and revolution, 1887-1903.

The play discusses various women’s issues through a series of monologues centering on the female organ, the vagina. Despite strong opposition, the play was mounted at various venues, including a number of Catholic universities. The cast included Gina Alajar, Pinky Amador, Angelu de Leon, Angel Aquino, Belinda Panelo, and Sheila Francsico under the direction of Wilson.

New Voice Company commissioned Glecy Atienza, Joi Barrios, and Luna Sicat-Cleto to translate the play into Filipino. Titled Usapang Puki, the Filipino version was mounted on 6 Mar 2002 at the Dalisay Aldaba Recital Hall in UP Diliman under the sponsorship of UP Repertory Company and Gabriela Youth and under the direction of Roselle Pineda.

The play was first mounted on stage in 2004 under the direction of Joel Lamangan, and featured actors Christian Vasquez, Luis Alandy, Paolo Paraiso, Carlo Maceda, Jeffrey Hidalgo, Douglas Robinson, Angelu de Leon, Jenine Desiderio, William Thio, Russell Simon, Jason Colis, and Ricci Chan. Written by Doreen G. article.value: As a poetic form, the dramatic monologue was the “favored mode of a particular literary period” between 1830 and 1930. One well-known example is Robert Browning’s My Last Duchess, in which the persona speaks directly to the reader as an actual historical figure rather than as poet.

As a theatrical form, the dramatic monologue has often been used for one-person performances on historical figures and events (such as Winston Churchill and World War II), and on the life and works of writers (such as Emlyn Williams on Charles Dickens).

In Philippine theater, the form has been especially favored, as it requires minimal set design and props and is therefore inexpensive to produce; and further, as it lends itself to many creative variations. The tula-dula (literally, poem-play), for example, is a variant in which a lone actor/narrator speaks, and the other(s) play all the parts.

article.value: In Tony Perez’s Alex Antiporda, 1974, a student, Alex, enacts a monologue, his reply to a question asked of him in an oral exam by an imaginary panel of philosophy professors. Kuwadro (Portrait) by Isagani R. Cruz, 1980, portrays Katerina Alonzo, an aging actress, formerly a sarsuwela star, recalling the glories of her past.

Tatalon,1983, by Rogelio Sicat, features one actor playing a jeepney character narrating the suicide of a welder.

text:
The duplo is a form of folk drama usually played on the final night of the traditional nine-day wake for the dead. It is customary among the Filipinos to give a feast on the ninth day after the death of a loved one. Relatives and friends gather in the house of the bereaved family, and various forms of amusement are prepared to pass the time away. The duplo is primarily aimed at entertaining the family and friends of the departed. This celebratory mood during the wake is consistent with pre-Spanish accounts on the death and burial rituals of early Filipinos.

Some speculate that the duplo began in the middle of the 18th century and reached its peak in the late 19th century. Balmaseda believes that the game was developed by the ladinos or poets who wrote in Spanish and Tagalog, because of the prevalence of Spanish terms used in the game. It is also highly possible that duplo came after the awit (metrical tale) and pasyon since these two forms were common sources of arguments for the poetic debate. A more convincing evidence that the game was practiced in the 18th century was an account that mentioned the prohibition by the archbishop of Manila in 1741 of the practice of duplo without the permission of the religious authorities. It is said that such a restriction was a result of the anti-church content of the game.

 

Early literary historians noted the decline of the duplo in the 20th century. This prompted scholars to study and produce master texts of the duplo. The first written documentation was by Julian Cruz Balmaseda, published in El Renacimiento Filipino, 1913, and was followed by Teodoro Gener’s Duplo’t Balagtasan, 1948. In the 1960s, there were efforts to revive the duplo. In 10 May 1964, the Cultural Affairs Office of the Manila City Government, led by Mayor Anonio Villegas, conducted a pambansang duplohan (national duplo competition). It was staged at the Luneta Grandstand to commemorate the 67th death anniversary of Andres Bonifacio. Seven duplero (duplo poets), aged 28 to 74, from various parts of the Philippines, participated in the event. Likewise, teachers and students of the Far Eastern University (FEU) established the FEU Duplo Group to revive this dramatic form. They performed the duplo in various places and for different occasions. The most recent performance of an actual duplo that happened in Barrio Lawang, Kupang, San Antonio, Nueva Ecija, was documented by Vivencio Jose in 1975.

Most of the information about the earlier duplo came from Balmaseda’s accounts published in “Ang Tatlong Panahon ng Tulang Tagalog” and Gener’s classic work. It is usually held in an open space beside the house where the wake takes place. A temporary and improvised structure made of bamboo and local fronds is built to provide protective cover for the guests and for the performance. Under this structure, two benches are placed on opposite sides. A table is positioned in the middle, on top of which one can find a palmatorya, a piece of wood with a round and flat head and a handle, or a single slipper, or a piece of bamboo to be used for meting out a punishment. This entire space is sometimes called a kaharian (kingdom).

The play, or laro (game), begins when the hari (king) holds the palmatorya in his hand. He introduces the game, its objectives, and the rules to be followed. Prayers are also offered for the soul of the departed. After this, the hari presents a situation, such as the loss of a healing rose or the death of his pet parrot. This is followed by a numeracion or counting off by several duplero, also called belyako and belyaka, who are seated on opposite sides of the table. The participants will then be acknowledged according to their number, such as primero belyako (first belyako) or primera belyaka (first belyaka). When all the participants have been identified, the hari hurls the first accusation, usually, to a belyako. The accused belyako has to defend himself, and in turn, accuses another participant, usually a belyaka. But before making the accusation, the duplero will deliver a relacion, an introductory poem—usually a narrative that contains a moral lesson or a humorous story that has no connection to the main topic. After this, the hari delivers a hatol (judgment) and orders the execution of the penalty using the palmatorya. But the judgment is usually not carried out, as another participant will stand up and defend the accused. This commences a series of pagpapatama (allegation) and pagtatanggol (defense) by the duplero. Any guest who wishes to participate in the duplo but is not in the initial lineup is then permitted to enter the circulo (circle) by performing a panawagan (plea). Here, the new participant creates a fictive situation that will allow him or her to enter the circulo. In his account, possibly of a 19th-century duplo, Balmaseda noted that a duplo performance may extend to as long as 24 hours, as participants may enter and exit the circulo. He called it the “marathon sa tulaan” (marathon of poetry).

Gener used laro and paligsahan sa katwiran (contest of reason) to describe this form. The duplo may use the same situation to launch the game but also tackle various topics as it progresses. It may use katwiran (reason or argument) derived from different sources, such as riddles, proverbs, myths and legends, awit and korido, folktales, fables, history, current events, news, the Bible, lives of the saints, the pasyon, and even the Penal and Civil Code. In his account, Jose mentioned the term binayabas to refer to very common topics or arguments used by novices and tinigpas to refer to abrupt shifting of topics resorted to by the untrained.

The Spanish chronicler Tomas Ortiz, in his account, noted that in the 18th century, the Spanish church authorities prohibited gatherings by the people and the performance of folk rituals, such as the duplo. Instead, they ordered the people to pray for the dead inside the church to avoid “errors” in commemorating the death. Ortiz further noted that when the people were confronted for violating the order, they would reason out that the purpose of their gathering was to offer a holy rosary for the deceased. Since the practice of the duplo survived over the next centuries, it was obvious that the Spanish authorities failed to fully implement the order and prevent the people from observing the rituals.

Zafra noted that the Filipinos’ insistence on mounting the duplo despite the prohibition of the Spanish religious authorities is actually a performance of the very essence of the duplo—the primacy of the katwiran (reason) over kapangyarihan (power). In the playing of the duplo, the dictum “ang utos ng hari/hindi mababali” (the king’s order/cannot be violated), set by the king, has to be transgressed since the exchange of katwiran can only happen when the king’s order of executing the punishment is ignored. The duplero’s disobedience of the hari’s order so that they can proceed with their argumentation may be seen as a parallel to the Filipinos’ assertion of the performance of their folk rituals, despite the prohibition of the authorities (2000, 158-59).

Marcelo H. del Pilar, acknowledged as one of the best duplero during his time (Gatmaitan 1965, 13-14), utilized the form in his poem “Dupluhan” (ca. 1887) to launch his attacks against the Spanish authorities. The poem, which comprises 13 stanzas of dedecasyllabic lines, can be divided into two; each part is determined by the character that the belyako is addressing. In the first part, a belyako speaks to a belyaka, the Tinubuang Lupa (Motherland), who was sentenced by the Hari or Monarka (Monarch). The belyako defends the belyaka but fails to have the sentence lifted. In the succeeding stanzas, the emotional basis of the belyako’s defense is laid out—the Bayan’s concern and care since his childhood. In the second part, the belyako turns upon the Hari, who is described as “sakdal bangis” (most fierce) and addresses him in lines full of irony that are both bitter and threatening.

A play using the duplo form was staged by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) in Jan 1976 at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago. Titled Dupluhang Bayan (National Joust/People’s Joust), the play was written by Domingo Landicho and directed by Lutgardo Labad. It was later restaged by Teatro Umalohokan in 1978 in Laguna under the direction of Rey Pimentel and Louie Sevilla (Landicho 1991, ix).

In Dupluhang Bayan, Manggagawa (Workers) and Magsasaka (Peasants) take the roles of the belyako and belyaka. The Tagapagsalita (Speaker) presents the usual opening situation of the duplo—the loss of the king’s kulasisi (bird). After this, Manggagawa and Magsasaka begin their duel. The arguments, however, do not discuss who is responsible for the loss of the kulasisi, but the contribution of the workers and peasants in society. Interspersed in the duplo are dramatized alamat (legends). These stories become starting points for exploring discourses about service, slavery, colonialism, and power. Written by Galileo S. Zafra

text:
Flores, from Spanish flores or “flowers,” also known as flores de Mayo (flowers of May), flores de Maria (flowers of Mary), or alay (offering), may refer to the whole Flower Festival celebrated in the month of May in honor of the Virgin Mary (flores, flores de Mayo, flores de Maria), or to the daily offering of flowers to an image of the Virgin in the month of May (alay), or to the culminating grand procession of the Virgin on the last Sunday of May (flores).

In the Tagalog region, this custom and celebration started after the proclamation of the dogma of the Immaculate Conception in 1854, and after the publication of Mariano Sevilla’s translation of the devotional Flores de Maria o Mariquit na Bulaclac nasa Pagninilaynilay sa Buong Buan nang Mayo Ay Inihahandog nang manga Devoto cay Maria Santisima (The Flowers of Mary or the Beautiful Flowers That in the Meditations during the Whole Month of May Are Offered by Devotees to Mary the Holiest), ca 1867.

 

A typical alay in Malolos, Bulacan, held in the afternoon of each day in May begins with the rosary being said by old women in church. After this, the pagninilay (meditation), the halimbaua (anecdote), the handog (offering), and jaculatoria (prayer) of the day are read from Sevilla’s devotional. Then follows the alay proper, with young girls or women in white with baskets of flowers forming two rows in front of the altar of the Virgin. Alternately, the chorus and the group of girls sing verses of praise to the Virgin. The antiphon in song continues until all the flowers have been arranged in the vases in front of the Virgin. Then the litany of the Virgin is sung, after which the priest comes out of the sacristy to lead in the singing of the “Salve Regina” (Hail Holy Queen). After the priest’s benediction, the last song “Adios, Reina del Cielo” (Farewell, Queen of Heaven) is sung.

The grandest alay, with young ladies and their escorts dressed to the nines, are reserved for the novenario or the last nine days before the feast of the flores itself.

On the last day, the Virgin’s image is brought around in procession in the morning and in the evening. The evening’s gala procession features a stream of young girls and women called sagala carrying emblems taken from the Virgin’s litany (e.g., Mystical Rose, Tower of David, Tower of Ivory, Morning Star, Queen of Angels, Queen of Martyrs) as well as symbols of Faith (Fe), Hope (Esperanza), and Charity (Caridad) and the letters of the AVE MARIA. Principal sagala are the Rosa Mistica and the Reina de las Flores, who walk behind the principal hermana (female sponsors) who spend for the decoration of the church, the karosa (float), and the candles.

Many variations of the flores exist. In Pakil, Laguna, there is a sunduan in the late afternoon, where the male escorts come to fetch young ladies and go in procession to the church, carrying beautiful monstrance-shaped arrangements of calachuchi, santan, and other flowers of May called bastagan. In Pila, Laguna, the ritual of transferring the role of hermana is performed in church with crowns of flowers being conferred on the new hermana. In addition to its religious purpose, the Flores also serves a social function, as it introduces to the town the youth that will form the next generation of leaders and citizens.

In most towns today, the flower procession has been mixed up with the santakrusan (May was originally the month of the Holy Cross) so that characters like Santa Elena, Constantino, Obispo Macario, Belibet, and Reina Mora from the Elena story have now been integrated with the litany titles of the Virgin, resulting in processions that are notable for their confusion as well as lack of religious fervor, many of them having turned into parades of couturier-dressed beauties. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

photos.desc: Hudas, the ritual burning of an effigy of Judas Iscariot on Palm Sunday, Santa Rita, Pampanga, 1987 (CCP Collection)

text:
Hudas refers to the ritual burning of the effigy of Judas Iscariot, held on Black Saturday evening or on Easter Sunday morning in Pampanga, Bulacan, and Cebu.

In Santa Rita, Pampanga, a life-size effigy of the traitor Judas with a bamboo frame, papel-de-hapon (Japanese paper) costume (usually red and yellow), and papier-mâché head and hands is impaled on a bamboo pole about 8-10 feet off the ground in the middle of the church patio. The Judas pole is set on a wood and bamboo framework, which in turn is surrounded by four bamboo poles located near the four corners of the patio. Because early Christian belief holds that Judas’s body hanging from the suicide tree was eaten up by black birds, the fireworks emanating from each of the poles are covered with black cardboard cutouts shaped like birds. One at a time, each of these “birds” travels on a cable connecting the pole to Judas’s limbs, “attacking” or “swooping down” on the traitor’s hands and arms. Then, bigger firecrackers explode from inside Judas’s skirt, torso, and, finally, head. Throngs of churchgoers, children, and onlookers applaud and scream with delight to see the Evil One punished and the balance of the universe restored.

In Mexico, Pampanga, the effigy sticks its tongue out, holds a bag, and may wear trendy pants, shirt, and a vest. In Minglanilla, Cebu, the image of Judas is burned on one side of the patio as the statue of the Risen Christ ascends toward the church facade. All in all, most of the hudas performed in the country affirm the superiority of good over evil—in turn affirming the power of the ruling church, which oversees the ritual and decrees what is good and what is evil.

 

However, the hudas ritual has also been used as a form of protest against the church establishment. In San Pedro, a barrio of San Jose, Antique, the large hudas effigy, a grotesque figure made of hay stuffing and sinamay skin, is dressed in a long robe, with a huge carved wooden phallus protruding from a slit in its robe. According to Rosario Cruz-Lucero (2007), the effigy is prepared the whole of Black Saturday by the townsfolk, then paraded around the barrio accompanied by a band of drunken musicians, and finally brought to the barrio plaza at around 6:00 pm. Here it is mounted on a bamboo tripod over which hangs a noose of abaca. Then, to the drunken rendition of “Aloha Oe,” the noose is tightened around the effigy’s neck, the fuse connected to Judas’s shoe is lighted, and the effigy explodes from firecrackers embedded in its body, the most virulent of which are reserved for the head and, in days past, for the huge testicles under its penis. Every bit of the traitor’s body explodes into bits—except for his penis, which falls to the ground triumphantly whole, the object of a mad scramble among barrio souvenir-seekers. Lucero reads this ritual as a carnivalesque affirmation of phallic power against the oppressive rule of the Catholic Church. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

Tiongson, Nicanor G. 1989. Dulaan: An Essay on Philippine Theater. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

photos.desc: Huling hapunan, a reenactment of the last supper, Gasan, Marinduque, 1987 (CCP Collection)

text:
The huling hapunan or ultima cena —literally, “Last Supper” in Tagalog and Spanish, respectively—is an actual supper, held to commemorate Christ’s last supper with his apostles on the night of the first Holy Thursday. After the rites of Maundy Thursday in the early evening, the priest, accompanied by the 12 apostles whose feet he had washed earlier, walks to the house of the hermana (female sponsor), where local food—usually fish, vegetables, and rice—has been laid out on a long table, or to the parish priest’s convento, where they partake of a lamb-shaped loaf of bread.

In Gasan, Marinduque, in 1987, after the rites of Maundy Thursday, the apostles went to the hermana’s house, seated themselves on two sides of a long table, and listened as the priest at the head of the table spoke on the significance of the Last Supper. The priest explained that the paschal supper was originally observed by the Jews in thanksgiving for their delivery from Egypt; that it centered on the lamb, whose blood had originally been smeared on Hebrew doors to protect the firstborn of Israel from the Angel of Death; and that this lamb in turn had become the symbol of Christ, who gave up his life so that every human being’s sins may be forgiven. After the homily, the priest and the apostles partook of the supper as a group of women chanted the verses from the Pasyong Genesis, narrating the events of the Last Supper. The rest of the guests helped themselves to the feast.

 

In Baao, Camarines Sur, in 1988, the priest and the apostles ate their supper quietly in a room in the hermana’s house, while candles burned in front of a picture of the Last Supper at one end of the table. In Loon, Bohol, before the earthquake of 2013, the 12 apostles sat 6 and 6 on either side of the parish priest (who represented Christ), on one side of a long table facing the faithful (evoking da Vinci’s masterpiece), with their backs to the altar. After the meatless supper, the last mass for Holy Week was celebrated in the evening of Holy Thursday (Cordero-Fernando and Zialcita 2000, 123-25).

In Morong, Rizal, the custom of the cordero is practiced every Holy Thursday. The hermanos mayores (principal sponsors), usually a couple chosen by the Parish Council a year or so before, lead a procession of family members, friends, neighbors, and devotees all dressed up in formal attire, from their house to the Morong church. The highlight of the procession is the cordero that the couple carry—the figure of a white lamb, representing Jesus Christ (“the Lamb of God”) reposing on a tray or huge bible, with the pole of a little flag depicting a cross tucked under one of its legs. The lamb is made of mashed potatoes and sweet potato. At the church altar, the cordero is blessed by the priest as 12 male parishioners clad in apostles’ costumes look on. After the blessing, the cordero is then cut up, and its many parts distributed to the apostles and devotees in attendance. The hermanos then lead the procession back to the house, carrying with them the head of the cordero, which they will present later to the next hermanos to symbolize the turnover of responsibility for the cordero to the latter. In the early evening, the hermanos preside over a public dinner for the whole community. At the center of the covered social hall is a long table laden with food, where the hermanos sit with the priest and the 12 apostles, quietly eating a supper in commemoration of Christ’s last with his apostles, thereby affirming or confirming for the hermanos a higher status in Morong society. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

 

See also

Hispanic Traditions and Transformations in Philippine Theater (1565 Onward)

Source

Cordero-Fernando, Gilda, and Fernando Zialcita. 2000. Cuaresma. Makati City: Bookmark Inc and Bungang Araw.

The royal personages at the opening presentacion of a komedya performance in Pakil, Laguna, 1990 (CCP Collection)

text:
The komedya is a play in verse that may dramatize actual events, the lives of saints, or stories about Christian and/or Moorish royalty in the medieval kingdoms of Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East. This ancient and popular play is called “komedya” in most Christianized parts of the country, but is also known locally as kuleleng in Isabela; bakal-bakal in Pangasinan; cumidya in Pampanga; kolokyo in Catanduanes; moro-moro, linambay,and minoros in Cebuano-speaking provinces; and hadi-hadi in Leyte. Among the Tagalog, the komedya on the search for the Holy Cross is called tibag, arakyo, kolokyo,and elena.

The local komedya is derived from the Spanish comedia (meaning, play), which was introduced into the Philippines by Spain in the 16th century. The first comedia in Latin was presented in Cebu in 1598. Since then, many types of local komedya have been staged: those depicting actual events, like the Gran Comedia dela Toma del Pueblo de Corralat y Conquista del Cerro (Grand Play on the Capture of the Town of Corralat and the Conquest of the Hill), 1637, which dramatized the defeat of the Maguindanao chieftain Kudarat at the hands of Sebastian Hurtado de Corcuera; those narrating the lives of saints, like the Martirio de Santa Barbara (Martyrdom of Saint Barbara), 1609, performed in Bohol in the native language; and those about the loves and conflicts of royal personages in the kingdoms of Europe, Turkey, Persia, and Arabia, like the Vida de Atamante (Life of Atamante), circa 1887.

 

The komedya about real events in the Philippines did not prosper, although Francisco Baltazar created komedya in the 19th century, which were based on actual events in other countries, such as Mahomet at Constanza, ca. 1828, which is about the rebellion of the Greeks aganst the Turks in the 1820s. The religious komedya, on the other hand, yielded more examples, perhaps because many of these were performed during the feasts of patron saints, which were celebrated with masses, processions, and, often, performances on stage or on the streets. Some of the religious komedya that survived to the 20th century are the Haybing of Taal, Batangas, a komedya on the miracles wrought by the Virgin of Caysasay on a Chinaman, and the Comedia de San Miguel (Play of San Miguel) of Iligan City, a verse play narrating Lusbel’s rebellion against God and his punishment at the hands of Archangel San Miguel.

Of the three types of local komedya, the third became the most popular. With stories drawn from the European metrical romances that were orally transmitted or published in cuarto-sized libritos (booklets),these komedya usually focused on stories about Carlomagno and the Doce Pares de Francia or Twelve Peers of France (e.g., Rolando and Baldovino), the Siete Infantes de Lara or Seven Sons of Lara, Gonzalo de Cordova, Rodrigo de Villa, Atamante and Minople, and Alejandre and Luis. Later, poets like Jose dela Cruz (1746-1829) and his student Francisco Baltazar (1788-1863) developed original stories for their komedya, even as they elevated the verses of the komedya to poetry and deepened the characterization of the usual stereotypes. Their outstanding plays include de la Cruz’s El Amor y la Envidia (Love and Jealousy) and Los Traidores de la Patria (Traitors of the Country) and Baltazar’s Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira) and Mahomet at Constanza (Mahomet and Constance). Foreign films (e.g., The Mark of Zorro,1920; The Bridge of Sighs, 1936)as well as popular magazines and folklore have inspired contemporary komedya. Whatever the sources, the orihinal or script of the komedya follows a strictly chronological sequence of events, and casts all dialogue in verse, most common of which are the plosa (dodecasyllabic quatrain) and the romanse (octosyllabic quatrain). In the past, long traditional komedya performances were preceded by the declamation of the loa,a long poem usually in praise of the patron saint, and featured dances or skits called sainete or entremes before or between komedya acts or scenes.

 

The characters of the komedya, who belong to Christian kingdoms like España, Portugal, Alemania, Italia, Dinamarca, Albania, and Francia, would include the rey (king), reina (queen), princesa (princess), principe (prince), consejero (counsellor), general (general), and soldado (soldier); while those who belong to the Moro kingdoms of Persia, Turquia, and Arabia would include the sultan, visir, emir, or emperadora/emperatriz, general,and soldado. Each kingdom also has a very important character—that is, the pusongor locayo,the court jester who makes audiences laugh. Villanos (villagers), pastores (shepherds), and gigantes (giants) complete the cast of a typical komedya. In general, characterization in the komedya is one-dimensional—namely, Christians are always good and Moros are invariably bad. Both are supposed to be fierce in battle, but uncouthness, braggadocio, lust, treachery, and greed are more pronounced among the Moros.

Since Spanish times, the komedya has been presented in towns as part of the town fiesta in honor of the local patron saint, with support from hermanos (male sponsors) and the townspeople, who together spend for the stage, sets, props, lighting, costumes, food for rehearsals and performances, the brass band, and other incidental expenses. When presented commercially in closed teatros (theaters) as in Manila in the 19th century, impresarios/producers sold tickets to cover production cost and their profit. With their convoluted plots, long marcha (marches), batalla (choreographed fighting), and dicho (stylized declamation of lines), one komedya usually took three nights (with performances from about 8:00 pm to midnight) or two days and nights to perform. Sometimes, one komedya could take as many as nine nights to complete.

Most komedya would have a rectangular stage about five feet above the ground, divided by a makeshift wall into the acting area (up front) and the dressing area (at the back). This wall would usually have, on the first level, two passageways, one on stage right for exits and entrances of Christian kingdoms, and another on stage left for those of the Moro kingdoms. Sometimes there is also an opening in the middle of the two passageways representing a cave for the forest scenes. From the second level juts out a balcony from which the royal family watches the torneo (tournaments) called by the king in order to choose a husband for the princess.

Definite props identify the various settings on this stage: a potted plant and chair on one corner would identify the hardin (garden) for love scenes; a trono (throne) at center stage under the balcony would denote the sala or royal hall where the king consults his generals in the consejo (council), dispenses justice, receives the embahada or embassy, and blesses marriages. To light the stage, torches, gas lamps, petromax, electric bulbs, spotlights, and dimmers have been used at different periods from the 19th century to the present. Today, microphones, hanging or standing or lapel, amplify the sounds of dialogue and background music. The overall direktor coordinates all the work of the assistants who design, construct, decorate, and take care of the entablado or stage; the bandmaster who oversees rehearsals and performances of the royal marcha (slow march), both cristiana (Christian) and mora (Muslim), the paso doble (fast double-step march), the batalla (lively fighting music), and the eskaramusa (waltz during the torneo), as well as the background music for sentimental scenes; the director de magia, who designs, installs, and manipulates the magia (magical effects) needed by a play (e.g., swooping birds, lions and tigers, devouring whales, and giant roses). The direktor himself also coordinates with the sponsors about arrangements, chooses and rehearses the actors, and often doubles up as the apuntador/diktador (prompter), who feeds every line to the actors during performance from a little concha (shell) in front of the stage.

In most communities, the actors who join the komedya do so as part of the fulfillment of personal vows called panata to the patron saint for favors asked or granted in the past. The young men and women who are chosen for the play should have able bodies, loud voices, and good looks (the last especially if they are to come out as princes and princesses). Once chosen, these young men and women train for several months under the direktor who teaches them the techniques of doing the marcha, batalla, dicho, and mustra (gestures).

Costumes in the komedya are usually made of rich materials (velvet and satin are favorites) and decorated with embroidery, sequins, beads, plumes, and feathers. Even as the costumes are influenced by the latest fashions (especially for women), they still succeed in externalizing the play’s ideological messages. Thus, Christians are dressed in black or dark colors (e.g., green, blue) while Moros are attired in red or orange. To underscore the hierarchy of authority, the king wears the longest cape and the only crown; the queen dons a tiara and cape; the prince, a small cape and a three-cornered hat called trespicos; the soldiers, tiny capes and small hats. Royal personages wear bands and sashes. All characters usually carry swords, daggers, and/or fans. True to its historical nature, the basic clothes (pants, shirts, dresses, shoes) in a komedya always follow the latest in contemporary fashion.

Many komedya continue to be performed today in the various islands of the archipelago, where the community support has not waned and modern education and mass media have not diminished the people’s belief and delight in this drama form. Since many of these komedya depict stories from the Spanish colonial period, they continue to communicate messages that may be authoritarian or anti-Muslim (and therefore divisive) or colonial (Europeans always win and the European-looking are idolized). For these negative messages, the traditional komedya have time and again been attacked, especially by the likes of Severino Reyes, who at the turn of the century stated that this “benighted” form of drama should already be replaced by a more realistic play like the sarsuwela.

Not enough komedya with positive messages have been written, but notable among these modern komedya are Prinsipe Rodante (Prince Rodante), 1962, by Max Allanigue, where the villain is a Christian prince who is unjust; and Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1992, a stage adaptation of the Baltazar awit, which was reinterpreted and directed by Jonas Sebastian, with design by Salvador Bernal and choreography by Nonoy Froilan, for the children of Dongalo Elementary School in Parañaque.

article.value: The komedya is a play in verse that may dramatize actual events, the lives of saints, or stories about Christian and/or Moorish royalty in the medieval kingdoms of Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East. This ancient and popular play is called “komedya” in most Christianized parts of the country, but is also known locally as kuleleng in Isabela; bakal-bakal in Pangasinan; cumidya in Pampanga; kolokyo in Catanduanes; moro-moro, linambay,and minoros in Cebuano-speaking provinces; and hadi-hadi in Leyte. Among the Tagalog, the komedya on the search for the Holy Cross is called tibag, arakyo, kolokyo,and elena.

The local komedya is derived from the Spanish comedia (meaning, play), which was introduced into the Philippines by Spain in the 16th century. The first comedia in Latin was presented in Cebu in 1598. Since then, many types of local komedya have been staged: those depicting actual events, like the Gran Comedia dela Toma del Pueblo de Corralat y Conquista del Cerro (Grand Play on the Capture of the Town of Corralat and the Conquest of the Hill), 1637, which dramatized the defeat of the Maguindanao chieftain Kudarat at the hands of Sebastian Hurtado de Corcuera; those narrating the lives of saints, like the Martirio de Santa Barbara (Martyrdom of Saint Barbara), 1609, performed in Bohol in the native language; and those about the loves and conflicts of royal personages in the kingdoms of Europe, Turkey, Persia, and Arabia, like the Vida de Atamante (Life of Atamante), circa 1887.

article.value: The komedya about real events in the Philippines did not prosper, although Francisco Baltazar created komedya in the 19th century, which were based on actual events in other countries, such as Mahomet at Constanza, ca. 1828, which is about the rebellion of the Greeks aganst the Turks in the 1820s. The religious komedya, on the other hand, yielded more examples, perhaps because many of these were performed during the feasts of patron saints, which were celebrated with masses, processions, and, often, performances on stage or on the streets. Some of the religious komedya that survived to the 20th century are the Haybing of Taal, Batangas, a komedya on the miracles wrought by the Virgin of Caysasay on a Chinaman, and the Comedia de San Miguel (Play of San Miguel) of Iligan City, a verse play narrating Lusbel’s rebellion against God and his punishment at the hands of Archangel San Miguel.

Of the three types of local komedya, the third became the most popular. With stories drawn from the European metrical romances that were orally transmitted or published in cuarto-sized libritos (booklets),these komedya usually focused on stories about Carlomagno and the Doce Pares de Francia or Twelve Peers of France (e.g., Rolando and Baldovino), the Siete Infantes de Lara or Seven Sons of Lara, Gonzalo de Cordova, Rodrigo de Villa, Atamante and Minople, and Alejandre and Luis. Later, poets like Jose dela Cruz (1746-1829) and his student Francisco Baltazar (1788-1863) developed original stories for their komedya, even as they elevated the verses of the komedya to poetry and deepened the characterization of the usual stereotypes. Their outstanding plays include de la Cruz’s El Amor y la Envidia (Love and Jealousy) and Los Traidores de la Patria (Traitors of the Country) and Baltazar’s Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira) and Mahomet at Constanza (Mahomet and Constance). Foreign films (e.g., The Mark of Zorro,1920; The Bridge of Sighs, 1936)as well as popular magazines and folklore have inspired contemporary komedya. Whatever the sources, the orihinal or script of the komedya follows a strictly chronological sequence of events, and casts all dialogue in verse, most common of which are the plosa (dodecasyllabic quatrain) and the romanse (octosyllabic quatrain). In the past, long traditional komedya performances were preceded by the declamation of the loa,a long poem usually in praise of the patron saint, and featured dances or skits called sainete or entremes before or between komedya acts or scenes.
