article.value: The characters of the komedya, who belong to Christian kingdoms like España, Portugal, Alemania, Italia, Dinamarca, Albania, and Francia, would include the rey (king), reina (queen), princesa (princess), principe (prince), consejero (counsellor), general (general), and soldado (soldier); while those who belong to the Moro kingdoms of Persia, Turquia, and Arabia would include the sultan, visir, emir, or emperadora/emperatriz, general,and soldado. Each kingdom also has a very important character—that is, the pusongor locayo,the court jester who makes audiences laugh. Villanos (villagers), pastores (shepherds), and gigantes (giants) complete the cast of a typical komedya. In general, characterization in the komedya is one-dimensional—namely, Christians are always good and Moros are invariably bad. Both are supposed to be fierce in battle, but uncouthness, braggadocio, lust, treachery, and greed are more pronounced among the Moros.

Since Spanish times, the komedya has been presented in towns as part of the town fiesta in honor of the local patron saint, with support from hermanos (male sponsors) and the townspeople, who together spend for the stage, sets, props, lighting, costumes, food for rehearsals and performances, the brass band, and other incidental expenses. When presented commercially in closed teatros (theaters) as in Manila in the 19th century, impresarios/producers sold tickets to cover production cost and their profit. With their convoluted plots, long marcha (marches), batalla (choreographed fighting), and dicho (stylized declamation of lines), one komedya usually took three nights (with performances from about 8:00 pm to midnight) or two days and nights to perform. Sometimes, one komedya could take as many as nine nights to complete.

Most komedya would have a rectangular stage about five feet above the ground, divided by a makeshift wall into the acting area (up front) and the dressing area (at the back). This wall would usually have, on the first level, two passageways, one on stage right for exits and entrances of Christian kingdoms, and another on stage left for those of the Moro kingdoms. Sometimes there is also an opening in the middle of the two passageways representing a cave for the forest scenes. From the second level juts out a balcony from which the royal family watches the torneo (tournaments) called by the king in order to choose a husband for the princess.

Definite props identify the various settings on this stage: a potted plant and chair on one corner would identify the hardin (garden) for love scenes; a trono (throne) at center stage under the balcony would denote the sala or royal hall where the king consults his generals in the consejo (council), dispenses justice, receives the embahada or embassy, and blesses marriages. To light the stage, torches, gas lamps, petromax, electric bulbs, spotlights, and dimmers have been used at different periods from the 19th century to the present. Today, microphones, hanging or standing or lapel, amplify the sounds of dialogue and background music. The overall direktor coordinates all the work of the assistants who design, construct, decorate, and take care of the entablado or stage; the bandmaster who oversees rehearsals and performances of the royal marcha (slow march), both cristiana (Christian) and mora (Muslim), the paso doble (fast double-step march), the batalla (lively fighting music), and the eskaramusa (waltz during the torneo), as well as the background music for sentimental scenes; the director de magia, who designs, installs, and manipulates the magia (magical effects) needed by a play (e.g., swooping birds, lions and tigers, devouring whales, and giant roses). The direktor himself also coordinates with the sponsors about arrangements, chooses and rehearses the actors, and often doubles up as the apuntador/diktador (prompter), who feeds every line to the actors during performance from a little concha (shell) in front of the stage.

In most communities, the actors who join the komedya do so as part of the fulfillment of personal vows called panata to the patron saint for favors asked or granted in the past. The young men and women who are chosen for the play should have able bodies, loud voices, and good looks (the last especially if they are to come out as princes and princesses). Once chosen, these young men and women train for several months under the direktor who teaches them the techniques of doing the marcha, batalla, dicho, and mustra (gestures).

Costumes in the komedya are usually made of rich materials (velvet and satin are favorites) and decorated with embroidery, sequins, beads, plumes, and feathers. Even as the costumes are influenced by the latest fashions (especially for women), they still succeed in externalizing the play’s ideological messages. Thus, Christians are dressed in black or dark colors (e.g., green, blue) while Moros are attired in red or orange. To underscore the hierarchy of authority, the king wears the longest cape and the only crown; the queen dons a tiara and cape; the prince, a small cape and a three-cornered hat called trespicos; the soldiers, tiny capes and small hats. text:
The loa, from Spanish loar or “to praise,” may be a long poem or a short dramatic piece originally meant to be performed on stage to extoll a visiting dignitary, the patron saint whose feast is being celebrated, the sponsors of a performance, or the people of the town where a performance is to be held. The loa may be performed by itself or as an introduction to a long komedya or sarsuwela. The lowa, in some Visayan towns, is recited in small gatherings, such as in a funeral wake.

More often than not, the loa uses rhetorical and flowery verses arranged in quatrains. The plosa or dodecasyllabic quatrain is the usual measure of the loa, with a single assonantal rhyme scheme. The rhyme scheme may change with each new stanza. Public declamation of the loa by a young man or woman, called loante, tends to be in a singsong manner because the 12-syllable line has a caesura or pause in the middle.

 

Some of the earliest recorded loa were drama. In 1708, Fr Gaspar de San Agustin wrote a loa to introduce the Spanish comedia Amor Es Mas Laberinto (Love Is Such a Labyrinth). The loa opens with a nymph representing España or Spain, asleep. Slowly Yris or Rainbow, displaying all her colors as in a fan, descends through stage machinery. After describing where she comes from, she awakens España, who then delivers a long passage that ends with her summoning Regocijo or Joy. Regocijo and España exchange verses. At the end, Regocijo introduces the comedia, which is the main feature of the performance to honor the newly born Prince Don Luis Fernando.

In 1729, on the occasion of the canonization of two Jesuit saints, San Estanislao de Kostka and San Luis Gonzaga, Fr Murillo Velarde wrote a short loa titled “No Hay Competicion en el Cielo” (There Is No Competition in Heaven). Three characters—Astrea, Italia, and Polonia—give their speeches, with six violins and six cellos providing the music in between. Italia delivers the panegyric to San Luis and Polonia to her son, San Estanislao.

In Lipa, Batangas, around the 1800s, a loa was declaimed by a loante to honor the visiting official, General Alava. On stage a young man in horse-riding attire pretended to be asleep on a chair. Three times his sleep was interrupted by sad songs being sung behind the curtain. Finally, he woke up saying that a voice had informed him that the visitor he waited for had arrived. He then launched into a long loa, which combined high-flown eulogy with comedy. He narrated all the naval expeditions of the admiral and all the honors and titles that had been conferred on him by the King of Spain. The poem was spiced up with allusions to Ulysses, Aristotle, and Plato, who figure in situations that are wildly apocryphal—for example, to measure its depth, Aristotle was supposed to have hurled himself into the sea, where he finally perished.

Usually, however, the loa is a straight lyric poem with snatches of narrative, as exemplified by two loas written by Francisco Baltazar in the mid-19th century, both commissioned by committees in charge of festivities. The first loa is an apostrophe to San Miguel, patron saint of Udyong, Bataan, narrating how God sent the archangel to crush the rebellion of proud Lucifer. The second loa takes note of the joyous festivities that are undertaken to celebrate the accession to the Spanish throne of Isabela II de Borbon. The poem is a tribute to the queen who is seen as the harbinger of peace to the Spanish nation.

The same lyric loa are performed in Dapitan, Zamboanga, on 24 Jul, the feast of the patron saint Santiago Matamoros. The image of Santiago astride a horse is taken in procession around the town to a chapel where a young man declaims a loa in praise of the saint (Tiongson 1992, 16-19). Likewise in Gasan, Marinduque, the loa is performed by a young lady in terno or long gown during the Easter Sunday salubong of the Aglipayans. In front of the image of the Virgin Mary whose black veil of mourning has just been removed by an angel, she tells the Virgin to rejoice because her son has risen from the dead, as He had foretold, and then asks her to pray so that the freedom of the country may also be resurrected.

The loa is still observed as a major tradition in Batangas to our day, in towns like Santa Teresita, Alitagtag, Lemery, San Luis, San Nicolas, Agoncillo, Calaca, Balayan, and Taal. In Taal, the loa, here called luwa, is performed to honor the town’s patron saints on their respective feast days: San Martin de Tours, a Roman soldier who converted to Christianity and became a defender and propagator of the faith, on 11 Nov; and the Virgin of Caysasay, a small wooden image of the Virgin Mary in her attribute as the Immaculate Conception, on 8 Dec. According to Gloria Tamayo (2008), for each feast day, five to eight luwa are delivered by luwante, who may be male or female, and of any age but usually teenagers. The luwante, who are chosen by the hermana mayor (principal sponsor) of the year, usually perform the luwa as a panata (vow), either to give thanks for favors received or to continue a family tradition or to ask for help in a new endeavor. Once chosen, the luwante chooses the poem he will declaim, which may be old or newly requested from a local poet. The poem, in dodecasyllabic quatrains, is usually made up of a papuri,or lines praising the patron on its feast day; a pasasalamat, where the luwante thanks the patron saint for favors he has showered on Taal and its people; and a panalangin, where the luwante asks the saint to protect Taal and give it more blessings. On the day of the fiesta, the luwante, dressed in either barong or terno, delivers the luwa on a six-foot high platform decorated with fronds and flowers built right in front of his/her family house. The luwa is declaimed with proper intonation and gestures in front of the image of the patron saint, when its flower-bedecked karo or float stops in front of the luwante’s house. After the luwa, the procession moves on and makes similar stops at all the houses where other luwa are to be declaimed. Tamayo believes that the luwa tradition continues because it expresses Taal’s identity and ensures the protection of the town from calamities like the eruption of Taal volcano, storms, floods, and locusts, simultaneously strengthening Catholicism and introducing and integrating the youth of the town to their community.

But while the long religious loa of the establishment tends to be formal, high-flown, and grave, the short lowaof the Visayan folk is casual, earthy, and irreverent. According to Puedan (1988, 204-5), the lowa of Antique is a single quatrain recited as “punishment” in parlor games held during the bilasyon (wake). Usually performed by a circle of male and female teenagers, the game could be the bordon, where participants pass a ring around from person to person as they sing the same quatrain. When the singing ends, the “thief” at center must guess who is holding the ring. If he guesses right, the participant with the ring must recite a lowa as punishment for being caught with the ring. Sometimes the game is the kabatingan, where a coco shell container is passed on from forearm to forearm without using one’s hands. Whoever drops the coco shell must recite the lowa he/she prepared.

According to Puedan, the themes of the lowa are usually connected to courtship and love, with the male proffering love and the female rejecting it, all done in colorful and sometimes metaphorical language. The male could say with thick innuendo:

Kon ako mangasawa

pilion ko guapa

Dal-on ko sa balay

Paligoan aga-aga.

(If I would marry

I’d choose a beautiful one

I’d bring her to our house

and bathe her every morning.)

For her part, the girl who might be the object of a boy’s interest could reply with a double entendre:

Kon ako mamana

pilion ko guapo

Dal-on ko sa uma

Takdan arado.

(If I would marry

I’d choose a handsome man

I’d bring him to the farm

and give him a plow.)

Sometimes a male could be boldly romantic and imaginative:

Salamat, salamat nga dili mabilang

Kamot sang dalaga akon nauyatan

Nagapanalobsob sa mga kaugatan

kag diri pomondo sa sulod sang dughan.

(Countless thanks

I held a lady’s hand

It went right to my veins

and stopped within my heart.)

Or the male could be dismissive and sarcastic, as in this bilingual loa (Puedan 1988, 301):

I did not sleep at night

Thinking of you

Pero kon may banig

matorog man ako.

(I did not sleep at night

thinking of you

But if there’s a mat

I’d sleep of course.)

Or the male can be firm and adamant about his love:

Didto sa may baybay

may tawo nga patay

Dunot ang lawas

nagatindi ang buras.

(There at the seashore

was a dead man.

His body was rotten

but his penis was erect.)

The range of loa themes that either laud or lacerate the object of its delivery attest to the imaginative ways in which the Spanish loa was appropriated, adapted, and indigenized by Filipinos both at the center and at the margins of society. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

The first loa is an apostrophe to San Miguel, patron saint of Udyong, Bataan, narrating how God sent the archangel to crush the rebellion of proud Lucifer. The second loa takes note of the joyous festivities that are undertaken to celebrate the accession to the Spanish throne of Isabela II de Borbon. The poem is a tribute to the queen who is seen as the harbinger of peace to the Spanish nation.

The same lyric loa are performed in Dapitan, Zamboanga, on 24 Jul, the feast of the patron saint Santiago Matamoros. The image of Santiago astride a horse is taken in procession around the town to a chapel where a young man declaims a loa in praise of the saint (Tiongson 1992, 16-19). Likewise in Gasan, Marinduque, the loa is performed by a young lady in terno or long gown during the Easter Sunday salubong of the Aglipayans. In front of the image of the Virgin Mary whose black veil of mourning has just been removed by an angel, she tells the Virgin to rejoice because her son has risen from the dead, as He had foretold, and then asks her to pray so that the freedom of the country may also be resurrected.

The loa is still observed as a major tradition in Batangas to our day, in towns like Santa Teresita, Alitagtag, Lemery, San Luis, San Nicolas, Agoncillo, Calaca, Balayan, and Taal. In Taal, the loa, here called luwa, is performed to honor the town’s patron saints on their respective feast days: San Martin de Tours, a Roman soldier who converted to Christianity and became a defender and propagator of the faith, on 11 Nov; and the Virgin of Caysasay, a small wooden image of the Virgin Mary in her attribute as the Immaculate Conception, on 8 Dec. According to Gloria Tamayo (2008), for each feast day, five to eight luwa are delivered by luwante, who may be male or female, and of any age but usually teenagers. The luwante, who are chosen by the hermana mayor (principal sponsor) of the year, usually perform the luwa as a panata (vow), either to give thanks for favors received or to continue a family tradition or to ask for help in a new endeavor. Once chosen, the luwante chooses the poem he will declaim, which may be old or newly requested from a local poet. The poem, in dodecasyllabic quatrains, is usually made up of a papuri,or lines praising the patron on its feast day; a pasasalamat, where the luwante thanks the patron saint for favors he has showered on Taal and its people; and a panalangin, where the luwante asks the saint to protect Taal and give it more blessings. On the day of the fiesta, the luwante, dressed in either barong or terno, delivers the luwa on a six-foot high platform decorated with fronds and flowers built right in front of his/her family house. The luwa is declaimed with proper intonation and gestures in front of the image of the patron saint, when its flower-bedecked karo or float stops in front of the luwante’s house. After the luwa, the procession moves on and makes similar stops at all the houses where other luwa are to be declaimed. Tamayo believes that the luwa tradition continues because it expresses Taal’s identity and ensures the protection of the town from calamities like the eruption of Taal volcano, storms, floods, and locusts, simultaneously strengthening Catholicism and introducing and integrating the youth of the town to their community.

But while the long religious loa of the establishment tends to be formal, high-flown, and grave, the short lowaof the Visayan folk is casual, earthy, and irreverent. According to Puedan (1988, 204-5), the lowa of Antique is a single quatrain recited as “punishment” in parlor games held during the bilasyon (wake). Usually performed by a circle of male and female teenagers, the game could be the bordon, where participants pass a ring around from person to person as they sing the same quatrain. When the singing ends, the “thief” at center must guess who is holding the ring. If he guesses right, the participant with the ring must recite a lowa as punishment for being caught with the ring. Sometimes the game is the kabatingan, where a coco shell container is passed on from forearm to forearm without using one’s hands. Whoever drops the coco shell must recite the lowa he/she prepared.

According to Puedan, the themes of the lowa are usually connected to courtship and love, with the male proffering love and the female rejecting it, all done in colorful and sometimes metaphorical language. The male could say with thick innuendo:

Kon ako mangasawa

pilion ko guapa

Dal-on ko sa balay

Paligoan aga-aga.

(If I would marry

I’d choose a beautiful one

I’d bring her to our house

and bathe her every morning.)
For her part, the girl who might be the object of a boy’s interest could reply with a double entendre:

Kon ako mamana

pilion ko guapo

Dal-on ko sa uma

Takdan arado.

(If I would marry

I’d choose a handsome man

I’d bring him to the farm

and give him a plow.)
Sometimes a male could be boldly romantic and imaginative:

Salamat, salamat nga dili mabilang

Kamot sang dalaga akon nauyatan

Nagapanalobsob sa mga kaugatan

kag diri pomondo sa sulod sang dughan.

(Countless thanks

I held a lady’s hand

It went right to my veins

and stopped within my heart.)
Or the male could be dismissive and sarcastic, as in this bilingual loa (Puedan 1988, 301):

I did not sleep at night

Thinking of you

Pero kon may banig

matorog man ako.

(I did not sleep at night

thinking of you

But if there’s a mat

I’d sleep of course.)
Or the male can be firm and adamant about his love:

Didto sa may baybay

may tawo nga patay

Dunot ang lawas

nagatindi ang buras.

(There at the seashore

was a dead man.

His body was rotten

but his penis was erect.)

The range of loa themes that either laud or lacerate the object of its delivery attest to the imaginative ways in which the Spanish loa was appropriated, adapted, and indigenized by Filipinos both at the center and at the margins of society.
Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
The moros y cristianos,from Spanish “moros y cristianos” or “moors and christians,” is a short street drama, usually with dialogue and dances, depicting the battle between Moros (Moors) and Cristianos (Christians). Popular for centuries, this dance has many variations and names: palo-palo (Ivatan), sambali (Ibanag), moro-moro (Tagalog, Cebuano), sayaw (Aklanon), bakahan (Tagalog), mardikas (Ternateño), sinulog (Waray), and kinabayo (Cebuano in Dapitan).

The dance is clearly related to the dance drama of the same name, which had roots in Spain in the 12th century and gained popularity in Mexico starting the 16th century, where it saw many variations—some with Santiago Matamoros or Carlomagno or the angels battling the Moors. The form may have been introduced into the Philippines sometime during the Spanish colonial period by priests or church people possibly brought by the galleons from Mexico sometime before 1815. Today, the moros y cristianos has become an important feature in many a town fiesta procession.

 

This playlet is typified today by the sayaw of Ibajay, Aklan, whose text is said to have been written by Marianito Dalisay Calizo in the middle of the 19th century. Performed on the morning of the third Sunday of January, in honor of the Santo Niño of Ibajay, this play begins with the warring factions grouped on opposite ends of a straight cemented street about half a kilometer long: the Bisaya (as Christians are called) in black coats, waist and breast bands, pants and pershing caps, in front of the church; and the Moros in red pants, vests, and headbands, in front of the munisipyo or town hall. The capitan of the Bisaya leads his men in praising the Santo Niño, whose image is enthroned in front of the church. Meanwhile, on the other end of the long street, the sultan of the Moros decides to send two ambassadors to the Bisaya. The two embahadores (ambassadors) march to the Christian side and demand the image of the Santo Niño. The Bisaya refuse; the ambassadors return to their sultan at the other end of the street. The sultan now leads his army of Moros, brandishing swords and shields as they walk following an S-pattern on the straight road toward the Bisaya. In the middle of the road, Moro and Bisaya confront each other in two long lines, exchange threats, and fight to the music of a brass band. After this initial encounter, individual pairs of Moro and Bisaya engage each other and perform the sayaw, showing off their agility and skills in combat. In the end, the two armies confront each other once more until the Moros kneel in defeat and agree to be baptized. Forming a long line, pairs of Bisaya and Moro move toward the altar of the Santo Niño in front of the church and cry “Viva Señor Santo Niño” (Long Live the Lord Holy Child) in honor of the town’s patron saint. The play, which takes about an hour, delights audiences of allages who usually follow the action on the street.

Another version of the dance is the kinabayo —literally, “using horses”—a playlet performed in Dapitan, Zamboanga del Norte, on 24 Jul, the feast of San Jaime or Santiago. This short drama, which has no dialogue but only a narrative at the beginning, dramatizes the famous Battle of Covadonga, said to have occurred in 718 AD, where the Christian general Pelayo took a last stand against the Moro Alkamah, famous general of Alanos, then Emir of Spain. With the onslaught of Islam, the major cities of Spain had fallen under the crescent—Cordova, Toledo, Jaen, Sevilla, Salamanca, and Zaragosa, among others. Alkamah sends an emmissary to Pelayo to demand his surrender. Pelayo refuses and a battle ensues between the Cristianos and the Moros. The Christians are routed, but Pelayo falls on his knees and asks Santiago for help. Amidst thunder and lightning, Santiago “comes down from the skies” riding on a white horse, rallies the Christians behind him, and leads Pelayo’s army to victory over the forces of Islam. With triumph ascertained, Santiago rides back into the skies.

In the past, the Battle of Covadonga was enacted on the streets, as part of the morning procession on the 24th of July. As revised in 1952, the kinabayo was presented on a bamboo stage in the church patio. A few years ago, the presentation was transferred to the Provincial High School grounds, where several groups—school- or barangay-based—competed with each other in interpreting the narration of the same scenes.

A third version of this dance is the bakahan —literally, “fighting” in Tagalog. This unusual Lenten playlet, unique to San Antonio, Kalayaan, Laguna, dramatizes the swordfight between San Miguel Arcangel, representing the forces of good, and the hudyo or Jews, here equated with the forces of evil. From 2:00 to 3:00 in the afternoon of Good Friday (the hours when Christ is agonizing on the cross), the boy playing San Miguel, who wears a long-sleeved shirt, knee-length pants, a crown, cape, and shoes, and holds a long pole with flag in his left hand and a wooden sword in his right, stands in the middle of a circle of onlookers and hudyo, played by older boys attired in bands, capes, swords, and the most bizarre masks, and headdresses. Separately, each hudyo dances into the circle, goes around San Miguel a few times, stops behind him and with his sword taps the archangel’s shoulder. San Miguel then faces the hudyo, engages him in a standard encounter of three blows, then drives him away with the long pole topped with a cross. One at a time, the other hudyo take turns fighting the archangel till the hour of Christ’s death.

Other variations of this playlet are the mardikas of Ternate, Cavite, where Moors and Christians clash in front of the karo or float carrying the image of the Santo Niño de Ternate; the palo-palo of Ivana, Batanes, where only the choreographed fighting remains, performedby boys, youths, and adults clad in blue pants and white shirts (Christians) and red pants and vests (Moors); the sambali of Cabagan, Isabela, where the protagonists have been changed to the Kalinga representing the unbaptized and the Ibanag representing the Christians; and the sinulog of Calbiga, Samar, where the Virgin Mary appears to save the defeated Christians, prompting the Moros to free their captives.

The moros y cristianos constitutes a morality tale that defined for the colonized native the forces of good (the Christians under Spain) and the forces of evil (Muslims, Kalinga, the unbaptized), characterizing Christianity (then synonymous with the Spanish colonizers) as the God-given religion that will defeat all religions inimical to it. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

 

See also

Hispanic Traditions and Transformations in Philippine Theater (1565 Onward)

Tiongson, Nicanor G. 1989. Dulaan: An Essay on Philippine Theater. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.
———. 1992. Dulaan: An Essay on the Spanish Influence on Philippine Theater. Manila: Cutural Center of the Philippines.

text:
Moryonan or moriones refers to the series of rituals and religious dramatization focusing on the story of the Roman soldier Longhino (Longinus) who was miraculously cured of blindness. It is highlighted by the pugutan or beheading of Longhino.

During the Lenten season, in the towns of Boac, Mogpog, and Gasan in the island of Marinduque, men roam around the streets wearing colorful costumes and masks. Locally referred to as moryon, morion,or moriones, these men have made a vow to reenact the pugutan on Easter Sunday. Locals refer to this dramatization and series of rituals related to it as the Moriones festival or moryonan, a colorful mix of local faith and Catholicism. Based on the Biblical story, a drop of Christ’s blood spurted into the eyes of the one-eyed Roman soldier Longhino, and cured him of his blindness, thereby turning him into a convert of Christ. The pagmomoryon, literally referring to the act of becoming a moryon, has been part of the people’s devotion and expression of faith in God. The term moryon (English, “morion”) refers to a penitent, usually a man, who pledges to wear the moryon mask during Lent as a vow of faith to do penance similar to that of Christ’s suffering. Local penitents regard the pagmomoryon as a pious vow and a gesture of appreciation for all the good graces bestowed upon their families or as a covenant with God so that their personal wishes may be granted (Adachi 1994; Goquingco 1980; Mandia 2002; Roces 1980).

 

Scholars have cited a number of sources for the termmoryon. Alejandro Roces (1980) proposes three possible sources. One is that it is a corruption of “centurion,” a captain of a hundred men in the Roman Army; the other is that it is derived from “morion,” the Spanish visorless high-crested helmet with toned-up edges used by the conquistadores; and the last is that it was named after Gov-Gen Domingo Moriones, who tried to soften the hard measures of the tobacco trust during his rule in 1877-80.

Another explanation draws from the olden times when Marinduque was frequently attacked by foreign invaders whom the people referred to asmoro. Stories popularized by the local elderly folk regarded the presence of the sea pirates as frightening, thus they would use this to scare children and discourage them from playing as expressed in “S’yaka! May moryon! Hahabulin ka ng moryon.” (Beware! There’s a morion! The morion will go after you.) “Moro yoon” (Those Moro) became moryon.Through time, the term was also used by the locals to refer to strangers or invaders. Another explanation takes note of the use of the word morion in souvenir programs that are mostly written in English, thus the term morion or moriones in its plural form.

 

To become a morion, one has to take a vow. The vow is an act of atonement for sins committed in the past or a request for pardon or good graces. The longer one’s vow, the more favorable rewards one may expect. Suffering becomes an index for the potency of a vow, as the locals believe that one expiates for an offense committed by carrying out the activities of a penitent, thereby regaining God’s favor (Adachi 1994; Mandia 2002).

Starting Holy Monday the morion walk around the streets, where they remain visible until Easter Sunday. Many believe that they descend from a sacred mountain or they may simply slip out of their houses, making sure that no one notices them. After performing ablutions in a stream, they go to a secret place where they wear their masks and costumes. At daybreak, they come down from the mountain with a sword lance or with a kalutang (wooden disc), more often by themselves or sometimes with a group. The morion remain silent as they walk to the town. Sometimes, they strike their kalutang in a distinct rhythm. Upon reaching the town, all they do is roam around the streets and walk all day long under the heat of the sun. Some perform dances or songs or play pranks on people or frighten children, making sure that their masks conceal their identities. Sometimes, the morion get invited for a snack or a drink or an invitation to sing or dance to a local tune. Amidst the intense heat or exhaustion, the morion must keep on walking around town as an expression of faith and gratitude for graces bestowed upon their families. As the sun sets, the morion make their way home to rest and prepare for the next day’s bout.

 

The moryonan is made popular by the image of the morion mask and costume, which has come to be its mark of distinction. The costume resembles that of the Roman centurions, an outfit that the morion sews and creates personally, from the headgear to the sandals, and even the mask. The process of making the mask is supposed to be done in secret to protect the identity of the morion, or his vow will lose its impact.

The mask is composed of two parts—the maskara (mask) and the turbante (headgear). There are discernible decorative incisions in the beard and hairline, and the face is painted red or deep pink. The eyes are always large and the holes are burned through the pupil. The nose and mouth are always large and open. The mask often sports a deep frown, which is cut between the heavy brows, and the ears are large and flat. It commonly carries expressions of fierceness and/or stupidity. The turbante holds the mask in place and is firmly attached through a wire or string. It is often constructed from a light bamboo frame decorated with colored tinsel or antennae made of paper flowers, as has been traditionally seen in most headgears. The number of flowers attached to the headgear represents the number of years the morion has performed the vow. A sword or lance completes the outfit. Horsewhips and wooden staffs in the shape of a snake are also used by the older morion. More conservative morion use the kalutang. These masks and costumes are stored away secretly in a cave until the following year. To keep the impact of the vow and the secrecy of the morion’s identity, he neither speaks or sings in a regular tone and only utters birdlike sounds when addressed. He covers his face with a handkerchief when he needs to take off his mask.

The dramatization of Longhino’s beheading as the first Christian martyr in the pugutan is the highlight of the moryonan. The cast includes Longhino, the centurion captain; Pontius Pilate, the Roman official; Claudia Procula, the wife of Pilate; Caiaphas, the Jewish high priest; Annas, the wealthy Jewish priest; Herod, the King of Galilee; and the centurions.

The pugutan is usually done in the evening of Holy Saturday in Boac and on Easter Sunday in the towns of Mogpog and Gasan. It is said that the pugutan started in Mogpog and that the Boac pugutan took after that of the Mogpog pugutan while the Gasan version took after the Boac pugutan. However, each town has its own staged version of the pugutan. In Boac, it is performed alongside other festivities, such as beauty contests and folk dancing, with sound facilities and lighting systems supplied by supporters and politicians who regard the activity as an asset to the tourism industry. In Gasan, the number of morion has continuously decreased, such that young students in the secondary level are involved by their teachers who have been tasked to take charge of these festivities.

In Mogpog, the morion assemble in the town plaza at around 10:00 in the morning in a public square near the market area. A big stage is constructed and a big painting of Longhino being beheaded is set up behind it. The morion take time in playing pranks and scaring the children and the rest of the crowd while waiting for the pugutan to start. A festive program commences with a parade where morion from Boac and Gasan participate. Skits on local social concerns are presented, followed by an intermission of dancing and chanting. Soon after, smoke is spotted rising in the distance, signifying Christ’s return, and Longhino rushes out of the stage proclaiming the glory of Christ’s resurrection. Longhino struggles with other Roman soldiers who have been ordered to stop him. He then goes into hiding and the Roman soldiers are ordered to seize him, thus signaling the start of the habulan (chase). Longhino runs across open fields, river banks, the rice paddies, up and down coconut trees, and inside houses as trumpets blare and drums beat. Three times Longhino is captured and three times he escapes. Finally, an exhausted Longhino is captured and put to trial on the makeshift stage created in the public plaza. Pilate and his men try to convince Longhino to renounce his faith in Christ, but he refuses and is thus sentenced to death. Longhino is then taken by the berdugo (executioner) and brought to a platform, where the crowd pleads for his life. Longhino, during his last moments, delivers an impassioned speech where he recounts how the blood of Christ restored his sight. He then confirms his faith and accepts his fate. A bottle of red wine is poured over his neck as the fatal blow is delivered. The mask of Longhino is then held up to signify his death. As tourists became attracted to the event, the need to make the story more intelligible to the outsiders became pronounced. Alejandro Roces, then secretary of the Department of Education, requested Celso Al. Carunungan to write the script called Longhino: Buhay at Pagpapakasakit (Longinus: His Life and Sacrifice). In the 1974 version of the Carunungan script, the traditional Longhino playlet became a longer, scripted play that uses a stage and its adjacent grounds, as well as taped dialogue and background music, mostly from the movie The Ten Commandments, 1956. Schoolteachers enact the following scenes: Claudia blames Pilate for having condemned Christ; the Pharisees complain that Christ’s apostles may steal His body and say He is resurrected; Pilate orders Longhino to guard Jesus’s tomb; Longhino refuses and runs around proclaiming Christ’s divinity; Pilate’s soldiers pursue and capture the new convert; Longhino prays to Jesus and is beheaded; and finally, Longhino’s body is laid on a stretcher and brought to the church, where all the morion say a last prayer.

Thus, the pugutan and habulan, which was once performed in the town’s streets and open spaces, now centered on its staging in the town plaza’s open stage. Pilate and his wife Claudia became main characters of the play, and long exchanges of dialogue required actors who were articulate and knowledgeable in memorizing long lines. What used to be a vow of piety by the local farmers and fisherfolk became a task taken over by the then Department of Education, Culture and Sports. This prompted teachers to take on the roles of the main characters of the pugutan. Changes also manifested in the morion mask. Back then, the morion mask was made of locally found materials, such as coconut leaves, corn husks, and flowers from the fields. The popular morion mask’s expressions of anger, anxiety, sleepiness, happiness, and stupidity created a distance between the ordinary people and the anonymous morion. But due to the intervention of politicians and local government, contests encouraged the creation of the morion masks for commercial purposes in the likeness of the Western centurion, much against the traditional mask-making ritual where secrecy was kept as part of the pious penitent’s vow and masks are carved based on the penitents original interpretation of the centurion. These innovations were initially met with amusement, but eventually the people tired of the formulaic script and looked forward to new ideas in familiar material whenever the pugutan was dramatized. To encourage people to watch the pugutan, some dramatizations included Pilate’s dream about the belly dancers. Instead of the Longhino story as the centerpiece of the dramatization, Claudia became the focal point of the story. Innovations attracted more and more tourists, thus raising the demand for the production of the morion masks and prompting some morion to sell their antique masks to foreign tourists (Mandia 2002; Adachi 1994; dela Paz 2014).

In 1992, in the town of Gasan, innovations were introduced to the Carunungan script of the Longhino story through the intervention of the Philippine Educational Theater Association. Through close consultations with local teachers and cultural leaders, the Bagong Longhino was dramatized with particular emphasis on maintaining the qualities of the traditional practice of the habulan while using new technologies of presentation. The habulan was emphasized with different representatives from the basic sectors as Longhino’s takbuhan or hiding place. Issues on local politics as well as local economic relations and environmental concerns were tackled in the improvised dialogue that ensued during Longhino’s run for safety. The kalutang was used as musical background while local materials, such as coconut leaves, were used to create Longhino’s costume. The taka (papier-mâché) technology was used in creating higante (giant puppets), symbolizing the basic sectors that extended their support and faith in Longhino. The whole town of Gasan was transformed into a living stage, similar to the use of open spaces in the traditional pugutan. The habulan took place in the marketplace, the hills, and the beach, and ended in the town plaza where the much-awaited pugutan was done (dela Paz 2014). Throughout the chase, the crowd followed Longhino, as spectators in the chase and as unwitting supporters and followers of the chase. Over time, the moryonan innovations have been made in consonance with the changing technologies of expression and interests of the local folk. Local organizations were put up by residents to support the moryonan. Political leaders poured in support for the moryonan and its potential as a major component in the province’s tourism program. Stages were constructed for the holding of the pugutan, with prizes at stake for the best setup.

Through the years, other areas have invited practitioners from Marinduque to enact the moryonan in their local communities, to make the Lenten rites livelier. The moryonan’s distinct charm has attracted millions of people since the colonial times, when Mariano Ponce once mentioned the staging of “The Beheading of Longinus” in his Folklore Bulaqueño (Roces 1980). Its distinct qualities as a Lenten ritual have paved the way for its replication in other parts of the country. Indeed, the moryonan has created a mark of distinction for the people of Marinduque as a sacred vow of piety and as a major tourist attraction, thus gaining for the province its unique name as “Morionduque.” Written by Nicanor G. article.value: Moryonan or moriones refers to the series of rituals and religious dramatization focusing on the story of the Roman soldier Longhino (Longinus) who was miraculously cured of blindness. It is highlighted by the pugutan or beheading of Longhino.

During the Lenten season, in the towns of Boac, Mogpog, and Gasan in the island of Marinduque, men roam around the streets wearing colorful costumes and masks. Locally referred to as moryon, morion,or moriones, these men have made a vow to reenact the pugutan on Easter Sunday. Locals refer to this dramatization and series of rituals related to it as the Moriones festival or moryonan, a colorful mix of local faith and Catholicism. Based on the Biblical story, a drop of Christ’s blood spurted into the eyes of the one-eyed Roman soldier Longhino, and cured him of his blindness, thereby turning him into a convert of Christ. The pagmomoryon, literally referring to the act of becoming a moryon, has been part of the people’s devotion and expression of faith in God. The term moryon (English, “morion”) refers to a penitent, usually a man, who pledges to wear the moryon mask during Lent as a vow of faith to do penance similar to that of Christ’s suffering. Local penitents regard the pagmomoryon as a pious vow and a gesture of appreciation for all the good graces bestowed upon their families or as a covenant with God so that their personal wishes may be granted (Adachi 1994; Goquingco 1980; Mandia 2002; Roces 1980).

article.value: Scholars have cited a number of sources for the termmoryon. Alejandro Roces (1980) proposes three possible sources. One is that it is a corruption of “centurion,” a captain of a hundred men in the Roman Army; the other is that it is derived from “morion,” the Spanish visorless high-crested helmet with toned-up edges used by the conquistadores; and the last is that it was named after Gov-Gen Domingo Moriones, who tried to soften the hard measures of the tobacco trust during his rule in 1877-80.

Another explanation draws from the olden times when Marinduque was frequently attacked by foreign invaders whom the people referred to asmoro. Stories popularized by the local elderly folk regarded the presence of the sea pirates as frightening, thus they would use this to scare children and discourage them from playing as expressed in “S’yaka! May moryon! Hahabulin ka ng moryon.” (Beware! There’s a morion! The morion will go after you.) “Moro yoon” (Those Moro) became moryon.Through time, the term was also used by the locals to refer to strangers or invaders. Another explanation takes note of the use of the word morion in souvenir programs that are mostly written in English, thus the term morion or moriones in its plural form.

article.value: To become a morion, one has to take a vow. The vow is an act of atonement for sins committed in the past or a request for pardon or good graces. The longer one’s vow, the more favorable rewards one may expect. Suffering becomes an index for the potency of a vow, as the locals believe that one expiates for an offense committed by carrying out the activities of a penitent, thereby regaining God’s favor (Adachi 1994; Mandia 2002).

Starting Holy Monday the morion walk around the streets, where they remain visible until Easter Sunday. Many believe that they descend from a sacred mountain or they may simply slip out of their houses, making sure that no one notices them. After performing ablutions in a stream, they go to a secret place where they wear their masks and costumes. At daybreak, they come down from the mountain with a sword lance or with a kalutang (wooden disc), more often by themselves or sometimes with a group. The morion remain silent as they walk to the town. Sometimes, they strike their kalutang in a distinct rhythm. Upon reaching the town, all they do is roam around the streets and walk all day long under the heat of the sun. Some perform dances or songs or play pranks on people or frighten children, making sure that their masks conceal their identities. Sometimes, the morion get invited for a snack or a drink or an invitation to sing or dance to a local tune. Amidst the intense heat or exhaustion, the morion must keep on walking around town as an expression of faith and gratitude for graces bestowed upon their families. As the sun sets, the morion make their way home to rest and prepare for the next day’s bout.

article.value: The moryonan is made popular by the image of the morion mask and costume, which has come to be its mark of distinction. The turbante holds the mask in place and is firmly attached through a wire or string. This prompted teachers to take on the roles of the main characters of the pugutan. Changes also manifested in the morion mask. Back then, the morion mask was made of locally found materials, such as coconut leaves, corn husks, and flowers from the fields. The popular morion mask’s expressions of anger, anxiety, sleepiness, happiness, and stupidity created a distance between the ordinary people and the anonymous morion. But due to the intervention of politicians and local government, contests encouraged the creation of the morion masks for commercial purposes in the likeness of the Western centurion, much against the traditional mask-making ritual where secrecy was kept as part of the pious penitent’s vow and masks are carved based on the penitents original interpretation of the centurion. These innovations were initially met with amusement, but eventually the people tired of the formulaic script and looked forward to new ideas in familiar material whenever the pugutan was dramatized. To encourage people to watch the pugutan, some dramatizations included Pilate’s dream about the belly dancers. Instead of the Longhino story as the centerpiece of the dramatization, Claudia became the focal point of the story. Innovations attracted more and more tourists, thus raising the demand for the production of the morion masks and prompting some morion to sell their antique masks to foreign tourists (Mandia 2002; Adachi 1994; dela Paz 2014).

In 1992, in the town of Gasan, innovations were introduced to the Carunungan script of the Longhino story through the intervention of the Philippine Educational Theater Association. Through close consultations with local teachers and cultural leaders, the Bagong Longhino was dramatized with particular emphasis on maintaining the qualities of the traditional practice of the habulan while using new technologies of presentation. The habulan was emphasized with different representatives from the basic sectors as Longhino’s takbuhan or hiding place. Issues on local politics as well as local economic relations and environmental concerns were tackled in the improvised dialogue that ensued during Longhino’s run for safety. The kalutang was used as musical background while local materials, such as coconut leaves, were used to create Longhino’s costume. The taka (papier-mâché) technology was used in creating higante (giant puppets), symbolizing the basic sectors that extended their support and faith in Longhino. The whole town of Gasan was transformed into a living stage, similar to the use of open spaces in the traditional pugutan. The habulan took place in the marketplace, the hills, and the beach, and ended in the town plaza where the much-awaited pugutan was done (dela Paz 2014). Throughout the chase, the crowd followed Longhino, as spectators in the chase and as unwitting supporters and followers of the chase. In the pugutan scene, a long red cloth symbolized the continuing search for truth as Longhino’s mask was hoisted in a pole to signify his death.

Over time, the moryonan innovations have been made in consonance with the changing technologies of expression and interests of the local folk. Local organizations were put up by residents to support the moryonan. Political leaders poured in support for the moryonan and its potential as a major component in the province’s tourism program. Stages were constructed for the holding of the pugutan, with prizes at stake for the best setup.

Through the years, other areas have invited practitioners from Marinduque to enact the moryonan in their local communities, to make the Lenten rites livelier. The moryonan’s distinct charm has attracted millions of people since the colonial times, when Mariano Ponce once mentioned the staging of “The Beheading of Longinus” in his Folklore Bulaqueño (Roces 1980). Its distinct qualities as a Lenten ritual have paved the way for its replication in other parts of the country. Indeed, the moryonan has created a mark of distinction for the people of Marinduque as a sacred vow of piety and as a major tourist attraction, thus gaining for the province its unique name as “Morionduque.”
Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson, updated by Glecy C. Atienza

text:
Musical theater refers to plays in which music is an integral part. It includes religious drama forms as well as established forms such as the sarsuwela, the musicals, and the opera.

Music has been a major part of Philippine theater from its earliest stages and forms. The rituals in indigenous communities usually featured chanting and singing as integral parts of the ceremonies. Songs and dances and their combinations—song-dance, dance-drama—were mimetic forms that assumed music as an essential element.

The religious drama forms that took root during the Spanish colonial period often included music. The panunuluyan, for example, or the reenactment of the search for an inn in Bethlehem, has Joseph and Mary singing their plea for shelter, which is denied in song by the may bahay (landlords, houseowners). Music for this form may be borrowed from other parishes or created by a local composer who usually sets a local poet’s words to music. The pastores or shepherds’ dance use villancicos, Christmas songs of Spanish or Mexican origin, but many songs have been especially composed for them. In Leyte and Samar, pastores and panunuluyan have merged and yielded such songs as “Pasayluwa” (seeking entry), “Tagbalay” (addressing the household), and “Lisinsiya” (asking forgiveness for having been “bothered” by the singers). The Palm Sunday osana, the pangangaluluwa for All Souls’ Day, and the flores de mayo are all sung. The weeklong sinakulo or traditional passion play has dialogue in verses that are chanted, as well as music built in where appropriate: when Salome dances for the head of John the Baptist; when the angel appears in the salubong to tell Mary that her son has risen (“Regina Coeli, Laetare”); and of course in the scenes of glory, like the Assumption of the Virgin into heaven. Holy characters march in to a slow punebre while bad characters swagger in to a fast paso doble.

 

The komedya or play in verse may or may not have the characters singing and/or dancing, but music is imperative to its action: martsa for all the royal entries and exits; paso doble for the torneo, paseo, and batalla; and the occasional waltz for the karansa. A brass band is necessary to its staging. It fell out of mainstream favor in the early 1900s. In 2008, Dulaang UP staged a new version of Francisco Baltazar’s komedya Orosman at Zafira, with music by Carol Bello and choreography and direction by Dexter Santos. This version used neo-ethnic rock music, employing indigenous instruments like the djembe drum, kulintang (gong chime), kubing (jaw harp), rainmaker, and others, as well as the present-day keyboard, electric guitar, and drum set.

The drama or prose play of the early years of the American colonial period may have had occasional songs, and the drama simboliko (“seditious” drama) used them as political statement. The “Himno Nacional” (National Anthem), forbidden by the Americans, would occasionally be played without warning, with great dramatic and emotional effect.

 

Opera was introduced into the country by traveling Italian companies in the late 19th century. Using local singers and musicians for choruses and orchestras, Italian singers performed operas like Aida, Il Trovatore, and Lucia de Lammermoor. The first Filipino opera, Sangdugong Panaguinip (Dreamed Alliance), with music by Ladislao Bonus and libretto by Pedro Paterno, was premiered in 1902. It was not until after World War II, however, that Filipino composers came out with more original Filipino operas, among which were Felipe Padilla de Leon’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1957, and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1970; Eliseo M. Pajaro’s Binhi ng Kalayaan (Seeds of Freedom), 1966; Alfredo S. Buenaventura’s Princesa Urduja (Princess Urduja), 1970; Jerry A. Dadap’s Andres Bonifacio:Ang Dakilang Anak Pawis (Andres Bonifacio: The Great Plebeian), 1979; and Francisco F. Feliciano’s La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf), 1984. The mounting of the opera continued in the succeeding decades with Mayo, Bisperas ng Liwanag (May Day Eve), 1997, music by Reynaldo Paguio and libretto by Fides Cuyugan Asensio; Spoliarium, 2003, music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Cuyugan Asensio; and San Andres B., 2013, music by Chino Toldeo and libretto by Virgilio Almario. The Philippine Opera Company, founded in 1999 by artistic director Karla Gutierrez, has been staging opera productions regularly. The group performs its productions not only in theaters but also in malls, churches, community centers, parks, and schools.

 

It is the sarsuwela, however, that is the major, dominant, and most widespread form of musical theater in the Philippines. It derives from the Spanish zarzuela, which Filipinos learned from Spanish troupes that performed in Manila and other cities, from Spanish performers who stayed to train Filipinos, and from Spanish writers who wrote zarzuelas for performance in the country. The form moved into the native languages, and thus caused Filipino playwrights and composers to evolve the Filipino sarsuwela. Musical accompaniment for the sarsuwela might range from a single piano, guitar, or even harmonica, to small or larger groups of piano, violin, viola, clarinet, flute, trombone, cornet, double bass, drum, and cymbals, depending on the group’s finances or the town’s resources. The fact that Atang de la Rama, “Queen of the Sarsuwela” in the 1920s and 1930s, could say with confidence that “a sarsuwela has 20 songs divided into preludio, concertante, solo, dueto, terceto, and coro,” and “a simple tune is played while the curtain is lowered between acts,” shows that the sarsuwela was a set and standardized form of musical theater that had evolved a structure and standards.

Some of the outstanding Tagalog sarsuwela of the prewar era are Walang Sugat (Not Wounded), 1902, music by Fulgencio Tolentino and libretto by Severino Reyes; Aurelio Tolentino and Bonifacio Abdon’s La Rosa (The Rose), 1908; Hermogenes Ilagan and Leon Ignacio’s Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), 1917; Precioso Palma and Leon Ignacio’s Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), 1920; Julian Cruz Balmaseda and Leon Ignacio’s Sa Bunganga ng Pating (At the Mercy of Sharks), 1921; Servando de los Angeles and Leon Ignacio’s Ang Kiri (The Flirt), 1926; and Engracio Valmonte and Nicanor S. Abelardo’s Dakilang Punglo (Noble Bullet), 1926.

Although sarsuwela dropped from the heights of its popularity in the 1930s with the advent of bodabil and the movies, it has survived in small towns, at fiestas, and in adaptation into movie and television musicals. Moreover, it has been revived, revitalized, and updated, and new sarsuwela have been written and composed. In the 1970s and 1980s, there were “modern” sarsuwela like Halimaw (Monster), 1971, music by Lutgardo Labad and libretto by Isagani Cruz; Ako! (I Am!), 1971, music and libretto by Bayani M. de Leon; Ang Bundok (The Mountain), 1976, music by Fabian V. Obispo and libretto by Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio; Sumpang Mahal (Sacred Vow), 1976, music by Rey T. Paguio and libretto by Domingo Landicho; Ang Palabas Bukas (Tomorrow’s Show), 1979, music by Lucio D. San Pedro and libretto by Bienvenido Lumbera; and Pilipinas circa 1907 (Philippines circa 1907), 1982, music by Labad et al. and libretto by Nicanor G. Tiongson. These productions have proved that one can pour different kinds of new wine into the old skins that the Filipino has learned to love and which have served his theater well.

In 1998, the Philippine Centennial Commission’s Publications Committee organized a Centennial Literary Composition contest. For the Sarsuwela Division, Mario O’Hara’s Palasyo ni Valentin (Valentin’s Palace) won first place and was later staged by PETA. Second place winners were George de Jesus III’s Paglayang Minamahal (Beloved Freedom), Bienvenido Lumbera’s Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. (Plea and Revolt of Victoria Laktaw and Others), and Melba Padilla Magay’s Bayan, Isang Paa na Lamang (Nation: Just One Foot Left).

In 2009, the University of the Philippines organized a Sarsuwela Festival. The monthlong event had sarsuwela productions, such as Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness) by the University of the East Drama Company, Walang Sugat (Not Wounded) by Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation, Sa Bunganga ng Pating (At the Mercy of Sharks) by the Far Eastern University Art Theatre Clinique, Ang Kiri (The Flirt) by Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas, and Iloilo Zarsuela: Padayon ang Istorya (Iloilo Zarsuela: The Story Continues) by the UP Visayas Alumni Theatre Company. There were also film screenings of movies based on sarsuwela themes from the 1930s to the 1970s, such as Giliw Ko (My Love), Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), Maalaala Mo Kaya? (Will You Remember?), and Stardoom.

Musical forms in today’s theater scene absorb influences from the global developments of musical theater, such as Broadway musicals, which gained popularity in the USA starting in the 1950s; sung-through musicals or rock operas, pioneered by Andrew Lloyd Webber with Jesus Christ Superstar in 1970; and West End mega musicals, pioneered by producer Cameron Mackintosh, popular in the 1980s. Local theater artists, especially those who had studied theater, music, and performance abroad, began to study, adapt, incorporate, and stage international trends and developments into the local milieu. Composers, librettists, lyricists, and book writers would draw from different musical genres, such as rock, pop, rap, hip-hop, and electronic dance music. In their development and creation of original Filipino musicals, some Filipino productions blended indigenous Asian instruments with western instruments, resulting in ethnic rock musicals.

Early examples of Filipino musicals are Dulaang Sibol’s oft-performed Sinta (Beloved), 1973, which is an adaptation of The Fantasticks, with Filipino characters and music; and Sining Kambayoka’s Mga Kuwentong Maranao (Maranao Tales), 1974, which uses the folk form called bayok effectively as singing/chanting theater, and their musical adaptation of Paul Dumol’s Ang Paglilitis ni Mang Serapio (The Trial of Old Serapio), which gave it new life. In 1975, staged was Betsy Romualdez-Francia and Mon Faustmann-Bing Labrador’s musical Mahal (Beloved). Virgilio S. Almario and Tito Climaco’s Bernardo Carpio, 1976, and Kapinangan, 1981, are rock musicals on folk legends. Gomburza, 1982, music by Butch Monserrat, commissioned by the Manila Metropolitan Theater, was another Filipino rock musical. Bayani (Hero), 1984, music by Jim Paredes, a musical about Jose Rizal, has the soul of the sarsuwela and the glitter of Broadway sensibilities, pop rock, and history.

Ballet Philippines staged dance-centric productions, such as Tales of the Manuvu, 1977, music by Nonong Pedero, using pop songs and ballet to dance folkore; Rama Hari (Rama, The King), 1980, music by Ryan Cayabyab, a pop ballet based on the Ramayana; and Encantada, 1992, using an ethnic rock score by Joey Ayala.

Also notable are the musical scores of Gines Tan’s Magsimula Ka (Make a Start), 1983; Joey Ayala and Al Santos’s Nukleyar I and II (Nuclear I and II), 1982 and 1985; Dong de los Reyes and Jun Austria’s Bien Aligtad, 1985; and Joel Lamangan, Buddy Palad, and Bong Rosario’s Roy Regalario, 1989. Manny Pambid’s Canuplin, 1980, with music by Labad et al., highlighted the bodabil milieu of the titular character.

PETA has also staged Oratoryo ng Bayan (People’s Oratorio), 1983, by Alan Glinoga and Al Santos, music by PETA’s Kalinangan Ensemble; Pangako ng Binhi (Promise of the Seed),1989, a folk operetta, music by Vince de Jesus and libretto by Robbie Guevara based on Marina Feleo-Gonzales’s play Dahong-Palay (Palay-Leaves/Green Whip Snake); 1896, 1996, the first sung-through Filipino musical, music by Lucien Letaba and libretto by Charley dela Paz; Ang Operang Tatlong Pera (Threepenny Opera), 1998, music and book by Rody Vera; Batang Rizal (Young Rizal), 2007, music by Vince de Jesus and libretto by Christine Bellen; Skin Deep, 2008, music and book by Vince de Jesus; Care Divas, 2010, music by Vince de Jesus and libretto by Liza Magtoto; and Rak of Aegis, 2014, book by Liza Magtoto using songs by rock band Aegis.

Repertory Philippines staged Broadway and West End English-language musicals as part of its regular seasons. Some of these musical productions are Sound of Music, 1975; The King and I, 1977; Fiddler on the Roof, 1978; A Chorus Line, 1979; Annie, 1980; South Pacific, 1981; West Side Story, 1981; Camelot, 1982; Sweeney Todd, 1982; Evita, 1986; Man of La Mancha, 1987; Grease, 1991; Les Miserables, 1993; My Fair Lady, 1994; Once on This Island, 1995; Wizard of Oz, 1998; and Little Women, 2010. Most of these musicals had restagings in the succeeding years.

After the 1986 EDSA Revolt and well into the 2010s, newer theater companies, such as Tanghalang Pilipino (TP), developed original Filipino musicals. Tanghalang Pilipino’s production of Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1988, music by Nonong Buencamino, lyrics by Tony Perez, drew on komedya, sarsuwela, and the Broadway/West End musical; and its El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1991, a sung-through musical with lyrics by Jovy Miroy and music by Ryan Cayabyab, was influenced by the styles of musicals like Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schonberg’s Les Miserables. Tanghalang Pilipino also staged Prinsipe ng Buwan (Prince of the Moon), 1994, music by Nonong Buencamino and libretto by Tony Perez; Mulan, 2007, music by Jed Balsamo and libretto by Rody Vera; Dugtong-Dugtong na Sumbong (Ang Hukuman ni Sinukuan) (Series of Complaints: The Court of Sinukuan), 2010, music by Jed Balsamo and libretto by Liza Magtoto; Stageshow, 2012, music by Jeffrey Hernandez and libretto by Mario O’Hara; Ibalong, 2013, music by Carol Bello and libretto by Rody Vera; Sandosenang Sapatos (A Dozen Pair of Shoes), 2013, music by Jed Balsamo and Noel Cabangon; Kleptomaniacs, 2014, music by Jose Frios and libretto by Layeta Bucoy; and Mabining Mandirigma (Gentle Warrior), 2015, music by Jed Balsamo and libretto by Nicanor G. Tiongson. TP also led the way in staging jukebox musicals, musicals that use preexisting songs, which became popular in the 2010s. It staged EJ: Ang Pinagdaanang Buhay nina Evelio Javier at Edgar Jopson (EJ: The Lives of Evelio Javier and Edgar Jopson), 2008, book by Ed Maranan using songs by rock band The Dawn. TP also adapted films and comic books or graphic novels into musicals. It staged Himala: The Musical, 2003, based on the film Himala (Miracle); and Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Muzikal, 2004, based on Carlo Vergara’s graphic novel Ang Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Zsazsa Zaturnnah (The Amazing Adventures of Zsazsa Zaturnnah).

Aside from TP, some other groups ventured into this type of adaptation of popular culture forms. Bit by Bit Productions staged Maxie, 2005, based on the film Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros); Viva Productions and Full House Theater Company staged Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), 2015, based on the film and komiks of the same title. Later, Culture Shock Productions staged Sa Wakas (At Last), 2013, book by Andre Nicolai Pamintuan and Marianne Abuan using songs by rock band Sugarfree.

Musicals staged by Musical Theater Philippines include Katy!,1988, on the life and times of the “Queen of Philippine Vaudeville and Jazz” Katy de la Cruz, music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Jose Javier Reyes; Kenkoy Loves Rosing, 1992, music by Bob Serrano and Archie Castillo and libretto by Boy Noriega, based on the komiks story by writer Romualdo Ramos and illustrator Tony Velasquez; Alikabok (Dust), 1995, music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Noel Balmaceda; Sino Ka Ba, Jose Rizal? (Jose Rizal, Who Are You?),1996, with music and libretto by Nonoy Gallardo, based on Leon Ma. Guerrero’s The First Filipino, a biography of Rizal; Larawan: The Musical, 1997, music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Rolando Tinio, based on Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino.

Trumpets focused on creating original musicals in English. It staged First Name, 1989, music and lyrics by Gary Valenciano, Ray-an Fuentes, Bob Serrano, Freddie Santos, and Ogie Alcasid; The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, 1997, and The Little Mermaid, 2000, both with music by Lito Villareal, libretto by Jaime del Mundo and Luna Inocian; and N.O.A.H. (No Ordinary Aquatic Habitat), 2009, and Bluebird of Happiness, 2013, both with music by Rony Fortich, libretto by Jaime del Mundo.

Atlantis Productions and 9 Works Theatrical, founded in 2009, also focused on musicals from abroad. Atlantis staged Rent, 1999; Jesus Christ Superstar, 2000; Hedwig and the Angry Inch, 2001; The Rocky Horror Show, 2002; Dreamgirls, 2003; Urinetown, 2003; Disney’s Beauty and the Beast, 2005; Avenue Q, 2007; Hairspray, 2008; Spring Awakening, 2009; Legally Blonde, 2010; Disney’s Little Mermaid, 2011; Next to Normal, 2012; In the Heights, 2012; Rock of Ages, 2012; Nine, 2012; Disney’s Aladdin, 2012; Piaf, 2013; Carrie, 2013; The Addams Family, 2013; Ghost: The Musical, 2014; and Shrek, 2014. Some of the musicals produced by 9 Works Theatrical were Rent, 2010; The Wedding Singer, 2010; You’re a Good Man, Charlie Brown, 2010; Sweet Charity, 2012; They’re Playing Our Song, 2013; Grease, 2013; and The Last Five Years, 2014.

Filipino artists have also collaborated with or were commissioned by campus-based theater groups to create original musicals. Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas staged Amado Lacuesta’s Taos (Heartfelt), 1993; Domingo Landicho’s Elias at Salome (Elias and Salome), 1996; Bienvenido Lumbera and Lucien Letaba’s Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. (Plea and Revolt of Victoria Laktaw and Others), 2001; Floy Quintos and Antonio Africa’s And St. Louis Loves Dem Filipinos, 2005; Joi Barrios and Joy Marfil’s Gabriela, 2005; Nicanor Tiongson and Joy Marfil’s Basilia ng Malolos (Basilia of Malolos), 2007; Ricardo Saludo, Vincent de Jesus, and Arnel de Pano’s The Silent Soprano, 2007; Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira), 2008, a reworking of the komedya by Francisco Baltazar (Balagtas), music by Carol Bello, book adaptation by Sir Anril Tiatco, Katherine Sabate, and Patrick Valera; Atang: Isang Dulang may Musika (Atang: A Play with Music), 2008, and Isang Panaginip na Fili (A Dream Fili), 2011, both with music by Ceejay Javier, libretto by Floy Quintos; Ang Nawalang Kapatid (The Missing Sibling), 2014, based on the Mahabharata, music by Krina Cayabyab and libretto by Floy Quintos; and Ang Huling Lagda ni Apolinario Mabini (The Last Signature of Apolinario Mabini), 2014, music by Krina Cayabyab and libretto by Quintos.

Tanghalang Ateneo staged Bayani: Isang Bagong Rock Opera (Hero: A New Rock Opera), 1995, based on a short story by Jose Dalisay, music and libretto by Khavn dela Cruz and Zosimo Quibilan Jr; Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas: Seditious Love Musical (Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow: Seditious Love Musical), 1998, based on the play by Aurelio Tolentino, music and libretto by dela Cruz and Quibilan; and Lam-ang, 2004, music by Von de Guzman, libretto by Jose Capino. Ateneo’s ENTABLADO staged Si Pilandok at ang Bayan ng Bulawan (Pilandok and the Country of Bulawan), 2011, music by Christine Muyco and Jema Pamintuan, libretto by Christine Bellen; and Labaw Donggon: Ang Banog ng Sanlibutan (Labaw Donggon: The Hawk of the Universe), 2013, with music by Jema Pamintuan and Teresa Barrozo, libretto by Nicanor G. Tiongson.

Ateneo Children’s Theater staged Batubayani, 1996, music by Jesse Lucas and libretto by Jesus Deogracias Principe; Gregorio del Pilar: Ang Batang Heneral (Gregorio del Pilar: The Young General), 1997, music by Jesse Lucas and libretto by Dennis Marasigan; and Sa Ngalan ng Ama (In the Name of the Father), 2000, music by Liesel Tiamson and libretto by Edna May Landicho. Tanghalang Ateneo and Bulwagang Bughaw staged Ang Bagong Damit ng Dakilang Bahaghari (The Emperor’s New Clothes), 2002, music by Chris Carandang and Dirty Kitchen, libretto by Ony de Leon.

In the current Philippine theatrical scene, therefore, musical theater is vibrantly alive. It ranges from plays with incidental music or occasional songs called drama musical, to those in which music is secondary to other elements (e.g., religious dramas/dramatizations, komedya, etc.), through the plays classifiable as sarsuwela/musical/operetta, in which songs function as part of the dialogue and music is fundamental element, all the way to deliberate attempts to create Filipino opera, in which all parts are sung, or music and lyrics have equal weight, or in which music is the dominant element.

The development of Philippine musical theater has shown not only the great affinity of the Filipinos for music, or the great dependence of their theater on music, but especially the viability of musical theater in all the settings in which theater is found in Philippine life: schools; church groups; rural and urban communities; factories and other workplaces; and nonprofessional, semiprofessional, and professional theaters. Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Walter O. Ang

article.value: Music has been a major part of Philippine theater from its earliest stages and forms. The rituals in indigenous communities usually featured chanting and singing as integral parts of the ceremonies. Songs and dances and their combinations—song-dance, dance-drama—were mimetic forms that assumed music as an essential element.

The religious drama forms that took root during the Spanish colonial period often included music. The panunuluyan, for example, or the reenactment of the search for an inn in Bethlehem, has Joseph and Mary singing their plea for shelter, which is denied in song by the may bahay (landlords, houseowners). Music for this form may be borrowed from other parishes or created by a local composer who usually sets a local poet’s words to music. The pastores or shepherds’ dance use villancicos, Christmas songs of Spanish or Mexican origin, but many songs have been especially composed for them. In Leyte and Samar, pastores and panunuluyan have merged and yielded such songs as “Pasayluwa” (seeking entry), “Tagbalay” (addressing the household), and “Lisinsiya” (asking forgiveness for having been “bothered” by the singers). The Palm Sunday osana, the pangangaluluwa for All Souls’ Day, and the flores de mayo are all sung. The weeklong sinakulo or traditional passion play has dialogue in verses that are chanted, as well as music built in where appropriate: when Salome dances for the head of John the Baptist; when the angel appears in the salubong to tell Mary that her son has risen (“Regina Coeli, Laetare”); and of course in the scenes of glory, like the Assumption of the Virgin into heaven. Holy characters march in to a slow punebre while bad characters swagger in to a fast paso doble.

article.value: The komedya or play in verse may or may not have the characters singing and/or dancing, but music is imperative to its action: martsa for all the royal entries and exits; paso doble for the torneo, paseo, and batalla; and the occasional waltz for the karansa. A brass band is necessary to its staging. It fell out of mainstream favor in the early 1900s. In 2008, Dulaang UP staged a new version of Francisco Baltazar’s komedya Orosman at Zafira, with music by Carol Bello and choreography and direction by Dexter Santos. This version used neo-ethnic rock music, employing indigenous instruments like the djembe drum, kulintang (gong chime), kubing (jaw harp), rainmaker, and others, as well as the present-day keyboard, electric guitar, and drum set.

The drama or prose play of the early years of the American colonial period may have had occasional songs, and the drama simboliko (“seditious” drama) used them as political statement. The “Himno Nacional” (National Anthem), forbidden by the Americans, would occasionally be played without warning, with great dramatic and emotional effect.

article.value: Opera was introduced into the country by traveling Italian companies in the late 19th century. Using local singers and musicians for choruses and orchestras, Italian singers performed operas like Aida, Il Trovatore, and Lucia de Lammermoor. The first Filipino opera, Sangdugong Panaguinip (Dreamed Alliance), with music by Ladislao Bonus and libretto by Pedro Paterno, was premiered in 1902. It was not until after World War II, however, that Filipino composers came out with more original Filipino operas, among which were Felipe Padilla de Leon’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1957, and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1970; Eliseo M. Pajaro’s Binhi ng Kalayaan (Seeds of Freedom), 1966; Alfredo S. Buenaventura’s Princesa Urduja (Princess Urduja), 1970; Jerry A. Dadap’s Andres Bonifacio:Ang Dakilang Anak Pawis (Andres Bonifacio: The Great Plebeian), 1979; and Francisco F. Feliciano’s La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf), 1984. The mounting of the opera continued in the succeeding decades with Mayo, Bisperas ng Liwanag (May Day Eve), 1997, music by Reynaldo Paguio and libretto by Fides Cuyugan Asensio; Spoliarium, 2003, music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Cuyugan Asensio; and San Andres B., 2013, music by Chino Toldeo and libretto by Virgilio Almario. The Philippine Opera Company, founded in 1999 by artistic director Karla Gutierrez, has been staging opera productions regularly. The group performs its productions not only in theaters but also in malls, churches, community centers, parks, and schools.
