article.value: It is the sarsuwela, however, that is the major, dominant, and most widespread form of musical theater in the Philippines. It derives from the Spanish zarzuela, which Filipinos learned from Spanish troupes that performed in Manila and other cities, from Spanish performers who stayed to train Filipinos, and from Spanish writers who wrote zarzuelas for performance in the country. The form moved into the native languages, and thus caused Filipino playwrights and composers to evolve the Filipino sarsuwela. Musical accompaniment for the sarsuwela might range from a single piano, guitar, or even harmonica, to small or larger groups of piano, violin, viola, clarinet, flute, trombone, cornet, double bass, drum, and cymbals, depending on the group’s finances or the town’s resources. The fact that Atang de la Rama, “Queen of the Sarsuwela” in the 1920s and 1930s, could say with confidence that “a sarsuwela has 20 songs divided into preludio, concertante, solo, dueto, terceto, and coro,” and “a simple tune is played while the curtain is lowered between acts,” shows that the sarsuwela was a set and standardized form of musical theater that had evolved a structure and standards.

Some of the outstanding Tagalog sarsuwela of the prewar era are Walang Sugat (Not Wounded), 1902, music by Fulgencio Tolentino and libretto by Severino Reyes; Aurelio Tolentino and Bonifacio Abdon’s La Rosa (The Rose), 1908; Hermogenes Ilagan and Leon Ignacio’s Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), 1917; Precioso Palma and Leon Ignacio’s Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), 1920; Julian Cruz Balmaseda and Leon Ignacio’s Sa Bunganga ng Pating (At the Mercy of Sharks), 1921; Servando de los Angeles and Leon Ignacio’s Ang Kiri (The Flirt), 1926; and Engracio Valmonte and Nicanor S. Abelardo’s Dakilang Punglo (Noble Bullet), 1926.

Although sarsuwela dropped from the heights of its popularity in the 1930s with the advent of bodabil and the movies, it has survived in small towns, at fiestas, and in adaptation into movie and television musicals. Moreover, it has been revived, revitalized, and updated, and new sarsuwela have been written and composed. In the 1970s and 1980s, there were “modern” sarsuwela like Halimaw (Monster), 1971, music by Lutgardo Labad and libretto by Isagani Cruz; Ako! (I Am!), 1971, music and libretto by Bayani M. de Leon; Ang Bundok (The Mountain), 1976, music by Fabian V. Obispo and libretto by Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio; Sumpang Mahal (Sacred Vow), 1976, music by Rey T. Paguio and libretto by Domingo Landicho; Ang Palabas Bukas (Tomorrow’s Show), 1979, music by Lucio D. San Pedro and libretto by Bienvenido Lumbera; and Pilipinas circa 1907 (Philippines circa 1907), 1982, music by Labad et al. and libretto by Nicanor G. Tiongson. These productions have proved that one can pour different kinds of new wine into the old skins that the Filipino has learned to love and which have served his theater well.

In 1998, the Philippine Centennial Commission’s Publications Committee organized a Centennial Literary Composition contest. For the Sarsuwela Division, Mario O’Hara’s Palasyo ni Valentin (Valentin’s Palace) won first place and was later staged by PETA. Second place winners were George de Jesus III’s Paglayang Minamahal (Beloved Freedom), Bienvenido Lumbera’s Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. (Plea and Revolt of Victoria Laktaw and Others), and Melba Padilla Magay’s Bayan, Isang Paa na Lamang (Nation: Just One Foot Left).

In 2009, the University of the Philippines organized a Sarsuwela Festival. The monthlong event had sarsuwela productions, such as Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness) by the University of the East Drama Company, Walang Sugat (Not Wounded) by Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation, Sa Bunganga ng Pating (At the Mercy of Sharks) by the Far Eastern University Art Theatre Clinique, Ang Kiri (The Flirt) by Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas, and Iloilo Zarsuela: Padayon ang Istorya (Iloilo Zarsuela: The Story Continues) by the UP Visayas Alumni Theatre Company. There were also film screenings of movies based on sarsuwela themes from the 1930s to the 1970s, such as Giliw Ko (My Love), Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), Maalaala Mo Kaya? (Will You Remember?), and Stardoom.

Musical forms in today’s theater scene absorb influences from the global developments of musical theater, such as Broadway musicals, which gained popularity in the USA starting in the 1950s; sung-through musicals or rock operas, pioneered by Andrew Lloyd Webber with Jesus Christ Superstar in 1970; and West End mega musicals, pioneered by producer Cameron Mackintosh, popular in the 1980s. Local theater artists, especially those who had studied theater, music, and performance abroad, began to study, adapt, incorporate, and stage international trends and developments into the local milieu. Composers, librettists, lyricists, and book writers would draw from different musical genres, such as rock, pop, rap, hip-hop, and electronic dance music. In their development and creation of original Filipino musicals, some Filipino productions blended indigenous Asian instruments with western instruments, resulting in ethnic rock musicals.

Early examples of Filipino musicals are Dulaang Sibol’s oft-performed Sinta (Beloved), 1973, which is an adaptation of The Fantasticks, with Filipino characters and music; and Sining Kambayoka’s Mga Kuwentong Maranao (Maranao Tales), 1974, which uses the folk form called bayok effectively as singing/chanting theater, and their musical adaptation of Paul Dumol’s Ang Paglilitis ni Mang Serapio (The Trial of Old Serapio), which gave it new life. In 1975, staged was Betsy Romualdez-Francia and Mon Faustmann-Bing Labrador’s musical Mahal (Beloved). Virgilio S. Almario and Tito Climaco’s Bernardo Carpio, 1976, and Kapinangan, 1981, are rock musicals on folk legends. Gomburza, 1982, music by Butch Monserrat, commissioned by the Manila Metropolitan Theater, was another Filipino rock musical. Bayani (Hero), 1984, music by Jim Paredes, a musical about Jose Rizal, has the soul of the sarsuwela and the glitter of Broadway sensibilities, pop rock, and history.

Ballet Philippines staged dance-centric productions, such as Tales of the Manuvu, 1977, music by Nonong Pedero, using pop songs and ballet to dance folkore; Rama Hari (Rama, The King), 1980, music by Ryan Cayabyab, a pop ballet based on the Ramayana; and Encantada, 1992, using an ethnic rock score by Joey Ayala.

Also notable are the musical scores of Gines Tan’s Magsimula Ka (Make a Start), 1983; Joey Ayala and Al Santos’s Nukleyar I and II (Nuclear I and II), 1982 and 1985; Dong de los Reyes and Jun Austria’s Bien Aligtad, 1985; and Joel Lamangan, Buddy Palad, and Bong Rosario’s Roy Regalario, 1989. Manny Pambid’s Canuplin, 1980, with music by Labad et al., highlighted the bodabil milieu of the titular character.

PETA has also staged Oratoryo ng Bayan (People’s Oratorio), 1983, by Alan Glinoga and Al Santos, music by PETA’s Kalinangan Ensemble; Pangako ng Binhi (Promise of the Seed),1989, a folk operetta, music by Vince de Jesus and libretto by Robbie Guevara based on Marina Feleo-Gonzales’s play Dahong-Palay (Palay-Leaves/Green Whip Snake); 1896, 1996, the first sung-through Filipino musical, music by Lucien Letaba and libretto by Charley dela Paz; Ang Operang Tatlong Pera (Threepenny Opera), 1998, music and book by Rody Vera; Batang Rizal (Young Rizal), 2007, music by Vince de Jesus and libretto by Christine Bellen; Skin Deep, 2008, music and book by Vince de Jesus; Care Divas, 2010, music by Vince de Jesus and libretto by Liza Magtoto; and Rak of Aegis, 2014, book by Liza Magtoto using songs by rock band Aegis.

Repertory Philippines staged Broadway and West End English-language musicals as part of its regular seasons. Some of these musical productions are Sound of Music, 1975; The King and I, 1977; Fiddler on the Roof, 1978; A Chorus Line, 1979; Annie, 1980; South Pacific, 1981; West Side Story, 1981; Camelot, 1982; Sweeney Todd, 1982; Evita, 1986; Man of La Mancha, 1987; Grease, 1991; Les Miserables, 1993; My Fair Lady, 1994; Once on This Island, 1995; Wizard of Oz, 1998; and Little Women, 2010. Most of these musicals had restagings in the succeeding years.

After the 1986 EDSA Revolt and well into the 2010s, newer theater companies, such as Tanghalang Pilipino (TP), developed original Filipino musicals. Tanghalang Pilipino’s production of Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1988, music by Nonong Buencamino, lyrics by Tony Perez, drew on komedya, sarsuwela, and the Broadway/West End musical; and its El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1991, a sung-through musical with lyrics by Jovy Miroy and music by Ryan Cayabyab, was influenced by the styles of musicals like Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schonberg’s Les Miserables. Tanghalang Pilipino also staged Prinsipe ng Buwan (Prince of the Moon), 1994, music by Nonong Buencamino and libretto by Tony Perez; Mulan, 2007, music by Jed Balsamo and libretto by Rody Vera; Dugtong-Dugtong na Sumbong (Ang Hukuman ni Sinukuan) (Series of Complaints: The Court of Sinukuan), 2010, music by Jed Balsamo and libretto by Liza Magtoto; Stageshow, 2012, music by Jeffrey Hernandez and libretto by Mario O’Hara; Ibalong, 2013, music by Carol Bello and libretto by Rody Vera; Sandosenang Sapatos (A Dozen Pair of Shoes), 2013, music by Jed Balsamo and Noel Cabangon; Kleptomaniacs, 2014, music by Jose Frios and libretto by Layeta Bucoy; and Mabining Mandirigma (Gentle Warrior), 2015, music by Jed Balsamo and libretto by Nicanor G. Tiongson. TP also led the way in staging jukebox musicals, musicals that use preexisting songs, which became popular in the 2010s. It staged EJ: Ang Pinagdaanang Buhay nina Evelio Javier at Edgar Jopson (EJ: The Lives of Evelio Javier and Edgar Jopson), 2008, book by Ed Maranan using songs by rock band The Dawn. TP also adapted films and comic books or graphic novels into musicals. It staged Himala: The Musical, 2003, based on the film Himala (Miracle); and Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Muzikal, 2004, based on Carlo Vergara’s graphic novel Ang Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Zsazsa Zaturnnah (The Amazing Adventures of Zsazsa Zaturnnah).

Aside from TP, some other groups ventured into this type of adaptation of popular culture forms. Bit by Bit Productions staged Maxie, 2005, based on the film Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros); Viva Productions and Full House Theater Company staged Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), 2015, based on the film and komiks of the same title. Later, Culture Shock Productions staged Sa Wakas (At Last), 2013, book by Andre Nicolai Pamintuan and Marianne Abuan using songs by rock band Sugarfree.

Musicals staged by Musical Theater Philippines include Katy!,1988, on the life and times of the “Queen of Philippine Vaudeville and Jazz” Katy de la Cruz, music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Jose Javier Reyes; Kenkoy Loves Rosing, 1992, music by Bob Serrano and Archie Castillo and libretto by Boy Noriega, based on the komiks story by writer Romualdo Ramos and illustrator Tony Velasquez; Alikabok (Dust), 1995, music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Noel Balmaceda; Sino Ka Ba, Jose Rizal? (Jose Rizal, Who Are You?),1996, with music and libretto by Nonoy Gallardo, based on Leon Ma. Guerrero’s The First Filipino, a biography of Rizal; Larawan: The Musical, 1997, music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Rolando Tinio, based on Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino.

Trumpets focused on creating original musicals in English. It staged First Name, 1989, music and lyrics by Gary Valenciano, Ray-an Fuentes, Bob Serrano, Freddie Santos, and Ogie Alcasid; The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, 1997, and The Little Mermaid, 2000, both with music by Lito Villareal, libretto by Jaime del Mundo and Luna Inocian; and N.O.A.H. (No Ordinary Aquatic Habitat), 2009, and Bluebird of Happiness, 2013, both with music by Rony Fortich, libretto by Jaime del Mundo.

Atlantis Productions and 9 Works Theatrical, founded in 2009, also focused on musicals from abroad. Atlantis staged Rent, 1999; Jesus Christ Superstar, 2000; Hedwig and the Angry Inch, 2001; The Rocky Horror Show, 2002; Dreamgirls, 2003; Urinetown, 2003; Disney’s Beauty and the Beast, 2005; Avenue Q, 2007; Hairspray, 2008; Spring Awakening, 2009; Legally Blonde, 2010; Disney’s Little Mermaid, 2011; Next to Normal, 2012; In the Heights, 2012; Rock of Ages, 2012; Nine, 2012; Disney’s Aladdin, 2012; Piaf, 2013; Carrie, 2013; The Addams Family, 2013; Ghost: The Musical, 2014; and Shrek, 2014. Some of the musicals produced by 9 Works Theatrical were Rent, 2010; The Wedding Singer, 2010; You’re a Good Man, Charlie Brown, 2010; Sweet Charity, 2012; They’re Playing Our Song, 2013; Grease, 2013; and The Last Five Years, 2014.

Filipino artists have also collaborated with or were commissioned by campus-based theater groups to create original musicals. Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas staged Amado Lacuesta’s Taos (Heartfelt), 1993; Domingo Landicho’s Elias at Salome (Elias and Salome), 1996; Bienvenido Lumbera and Lucien Letaba’s Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. (Plea and Revolt of Victoria Laktaw and Others), 2001; Floy Quintos and Antonio Africa’s And St. Louis Loves Dem Filipinos, 2005; Joi Barrios and Joy Marfil’s Gabriela, 2005; Nicanor Tiongson and Joy Marfil’s Basilia ng Malolos (Basilia of Malolos), 2007; Ricardo Saludo, Vincent de Jesus, and Arnel de Pano’s The Silent Soprano, 2007; Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira), 2008, a reworking of the komedya by Francisco Baltazar (Balagtas), music by Carol Bello, book adaptation by Sir Anril Tiatco, Katherine Sabate, and Patrick Valera; Atang: Isang Dulang may Musika (Atang: A Play with Music), 2008, and Isang Panaginip na Fili (A Dream Fili), 2011, both with music by Ceejay Javier, libretto by Floy Quintos; Ang Nawalang Kapatid (The Missing Sibling), 2014, based on the Mahabharata, music by Krina Cayabyab and libretto by Floy Quintos; and Ang Huling Lagda ni Apolinario Mabini (The Last Signature of Apolinario Mabini), 2014, music by Krina Cayabyab and libretto by Quintos.

Tanghalang Ateneo staged Bayani: Isang Bagong Rock Opera (Hero: A New Rock Opera), 1995, based on a short story by Jose Dalisay, music and libretto by Khavn dela Cruz and Zosimo Quibilan Jr; Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas: Seditious Love Musical (Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow: Seditious Love Musical), 1998, based on the play by Aurelio Tolentino, music and libretto by dela Cruz and Quibilan; and Lam-ang, 2004, music by Von de Guzman, libretto by Jose Capino. Ateneo’s ENTABLADO staged Si Pilandok at ang Bayan ng Bulawan (Pilandok and the Country of Bulawan), 2011, music by Christine Muyco and Jema Pamintuan, libretto by Christine Bellen; and Labaw Donggon: Ang Banog ng Sanlibutan (Labaw Donggon: The Hawk of the Universe), 2013, with music by Jema Pamintuan and Teresa Barrozo, libretto by Nicanor G. Tiongson.

Ateneo Children’s Theater staged Batubayani, 1996, music by Jesse Lucas and libretto by Jesus Deogracias Principe; Gregorio del Pilar: Ang Batang Heneral (Gregorio del Pilar: The Young General), 1997, music by Jesse Lucas and libretto by Dennis Marasigan; and Sa Ngalan ng Ama (In the Name of the Father), 2000, music by Liesel Tiamson and libretto by Edna May Landicho. Tanghalang Ateneo and Bulwagang Bughaw staged Ang Bagong Damit ng Dakilang Bahaghari (The Emperor’s New Clothes), 2002, music by Chris Carandang and Dirty Kitchen, libretto by Ony de Leon.

In the current Philippine theatrical scene, therefore, musical theater is vibrantly alive. It ranges from plays with incidental music or occasional songs called drama musical, to those in which music is secondary to other elements (e.g., religious dramas/dramatizations, komedya, etc.), through the plays classifiable as sarsuwela/musical/operetta, in which songs function as part of the dialogue and music is fundamental element, all the way to deliberate attempts to create Filipino opera, in which all parts are sung, or music and lyrics have equal weight, or in which music is the dominant element.

The development of Philippine musical theater has shown not only the great affinity of the Filipinos for music, or the great dependence of their theater on music, but especially the viability of musical theater in all the settings in which theater is found in Philippine life: schools; church groups; rural and urban communities; factories and other workplaces; and nonprofessional, semiprofessional, and professional theaters.
Source
Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Walter O. Ang

photos.desc: The Palm Sunday osana in Santa Isabel, Malolos City, 1990 (CCP Collection)

text:
The osana, from Latin “hosanna,” is a liturgical playlet that reenacts the triumphal entry of Jesus Christ into Jerusalem on the first Palm Sunday. It is also known as osanahan, meaning “the place where the osana is held”; and humenta, meaning “donkey.” Performed in most Catholic and Aglipayan parishes all over the country, this custom embroiders on the original Roman Catholic ritual of the blessing and procession of the palms, by bringing the procession outside the church and adding songs to it.

On the morning of Palm Sunday, in Malolos, Bulacan, after the priest blesses a wilderness of decorated palaspas or coconut palm fronds in church, he picks up a huge palaspas and uses it as a staff as he walks down the church aisle into the patio. On the priest’s path throughout the procession, women spread out overskirts called tapis, in imitation of the women of Jerusalem who laid out their cloaks to welcome the Messiah.

On each corner of the church square stands a kubol, an elevated wooden balcony covered with cloth and decorated with flowers and arches of palaspas on the sides and top. From the church, the priest walks to the first kubol, and here young girls in white sing a secular version of the Palm Sunday antiphon “Hosanna Filio David, Benedictus qui venit in nomine Domini” (Hossana to the Son of David, Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord) to the accompaniment of a local band. As they sing, the girls take handfuls of flower petals from their baskets to shower on the priest. There is a mad scramble for these petals, which are used as medicine or planted with the rice seedlings to ensure a good harvest. After the song, the procession moves on to the second, the third, and the fourth kubol for other versions of the “Hosanna,” and finally findsits way to the church’s main doors, which are closed at first to signify the Pharisees’ refusal of the Messiah. The priest knocks on the door three times with the bottom of his palaspas, the door opens, and all enter for the mass of Palm Sunday.

 

In some Bulacan parishes, the osanais also called the humenta because the karo (float) of the image of Christ riding on a donkey follows the priest throughout the procession. Here, too, the palms are blessed not in church but in a nearby bisita (chapel), from where the procession winds its way to the church a kilometer away. Some processions are held in the early evening. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

 

See also

Hispanic Traditions and Transformations in Philippine Theater (1565 Onward)

Sources

photos.desc: The priest washing the feet of male parishioners dressed as apostles, Gasan, Marinduque, 1990 (CCP Collection)

text:
The paghuhugas ng paa —literally, “washing of the feet” in Tagalog—dramatizes the episode in the New Testament where Christ, after the Last Supper, washed the feet of His 12 apostles to exemplify the spirit of humility and service to others. It is part of the original Roman liturgy for Maundy Thursday’s afternoon mass and continues to be practiced by Catholics and Aglipayans all over the country.

In a church filled with Lenten devotees, the washing of the feet is done by the main celebrant, assisted by deacons or sacristans who carry a pitcher of water, a basin, and a towel. After reading the gospel of Maundy Thursday, which narrates the episode of the washing of the feet, the celebrant goes to the apostles—played by male parishioners usually wearing white sutana (soutane) with satin capes or bands of different colors—who are seated in two rows flanking the altar. Kneeling in front of the apostle Pedro, the priest pours water over the latter’s foot, dries it with a towel, and bends to kiss the foot (in some parishes, there used to be a short dialogue between the priest and San Pedro, where the latter refuses at first and later agrees to have his feet washed). He does the same to the rest of the apostles, who—whether young, middle-aged, or old—play their parts in fulfillment of their panata (personal vows).

 

The ritual of the washing of the feet is followed by the procession in church to enshrine the Eucharist in the monumento —literally, “monument”—a high catafalque or side altar decorated by flowers and lights. After the church rituals, some parishes stage a simple reenactment of the Huling Hapunan or Last Supper, with the priest, representing Christ and the apostles, eating an actual meal, either before the altar itself or in the house of an hermana (female sponsor) who prepares the food. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

photos.desc: Pangangaluluwa singers, 2015 (Eduardo Rabaya Castro)

text:
The pangangaluluwa —literally, “for the souls” in Tagalog—refers to the custom that is performed late in the night of the Todoslos Santos (All Saints’ Day or the first day of November), where male and female carollers—old or young—go from house to house, impersonating the souls in purgatory, who beg for alms so that masses may be said for them.

In Batangas, the souls chant the story of an old man (Christ) who asks for water from a rich man who discriminates against him, and from a poor shepherdess, who welcomes him to her house and whom he rewards with a pouch of gold coins. In Bulacan, the “souls” are those of old unmarried women and old bachelors who are doomed to pound rice chaff as punishment for not marrying, even as they take care of the souls of dead children. In a mournful chant, these “souls” ask the household for alms and prayers, which will facilitate the purgation of their souls and their entry into heaven:

Kaluluwa kaming madla

ng dalagang matatanda,

Ang kasamang gumagala

ay binatang matatanda.

Kami po’y mga kaluluwa

na nagbabayo ng ipa

Kami raw ay nagkasala

pagkat hindi nag-asawa.

Sa langit ang aming gawa

ay mag-alaga ng bata

Kami’y nanaog sa lupa

para hulugan ng aua.

(We are all souls

of old spinsters.

Our traveling companions

are old bachelors.

We are the souls

who pound rice chaff.

We are supposed to have sinned

for we never married.

In heaven our task

is to care for children.

We have come down to earth

to beg for mercy.)

 

In the end the singers beg the houseowner to make haste if he/she wants to give them alms, for “heaven’s gate might close on us.” As piety waned and poverty precluded the giving of alms, the “souls” turned naughty and made away with whatever they could lay their hands on—for example, chickens, rice, other foodstuffs—leading peeved homeowners to baptize them as “kaluluwang dakma” (spirits who grab). Today, in urbanized towns and cities, the custom has all but disappeared in favor of television and or an early bedtime for the next day’s work. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

photos.desc: A couple dressed as Mary and Joseph searching for an inn in the panunuluyan, Hagonoy, Bulacan, ca 1981 (Nicanor G. Tiongson)

text:
The panunuluyan —literally, “requesting to come in” in Tagalog—is a Christmas procession that dramatizes the search for an inn by Mary and Joseph on Christmas Eve in Bethlehem. It is also known as panawagan or “calling out” in Tagalog; kagharong or panharong-harong or “going from house to house” in Bikol; or maytinis, from Latin matines,or early morning prayers, in Cavite Tagalog.

The panunuluyanmay have descended from the Mexican posadas but differs from the latter in that the posadas are usually performed for nine consecutive nights, while the panunuluyan is done only on Christmas Eve. The custom was probably introduced into the Tagalog and Bicol towns by Mexican or formerly Mexico-based priests or sailors who came to the Philippines on the galleons and settled in towns near shipyards or dockyards.

This procession usually features two karo or floats, bearing the images of San Jose and the Virgin, accompanied by one male and one female singer and a brass band. At about eight on Christmas Eve, the procession leaves the church and goes to about three or more houses located in different parts of the barrio or town. At each house, the procession stops. The male and female singers, representing the Holy Couple, sing, to the accompaniment of the band, a mournful plea to the may bahay (houseowners), begging them for a room for the night for Mary who is about to give birth.

San Jose :

O ginoo pong may bahay

Magdalita kami’y dungawin

Ampunin at kahabagan

sa mahal mo pong tahanan

upang lumubay ang pagod

naming magkasi at irog

at ang pagod ay umuntos

sa mahal mong pagkupkop.

Mahal na Birhen :

Paglalakad naming ito

tatlong araw na pong husto

Kaya po maginoo

kami’y kahabagan mo.

Saint Joseph :

Oh lord of the house

Please look out the window

Have pity, take care of us

in your noble house

so that we can rest

this loving couple

and get some sleep

under your care.

Blessed Virgin :

We have been walking

for three full days

So please, dear owner,

have pity on us.)

From the balcony or window of the house, the houseowners, also played by singers, turn the couple away because they have no room to spare:

 

May Bahay :

Hindi ko man ipagsaysay

Inyo na pong mamasdan

na halos mutok na lamang

sa tao ang aking bahay.

(Houseowner :

I don’t need to tell you

You can see it plainly

that my house is bursting

with so many people.)

 

The couple bid the houseowners goodbye and the procession moves on to the next house, where a similar plea is made by the two. In this and in subsequent houses, they are again turned away either because the couple are poor, because the real owner is not home, or because it is dangerous to let strangers in at night. About a few minutes before midnight, the procession returns to the church, now full of people waiting for the midnight Mass. Here at the “Gloria,” the nativity scene is revealed at the altar to denote the birth of Jesus Christ.

There are many variations of the panunuluyan. In some towns, the singers are themselves dressed in costumes like those of the images in the karo; in others, the singers are in everyday clothes; in others, there are no images, only costumed singers. Sometimes, and this is probably the older tradition, the verses are not sung but partly or wholly declaimed. The accompaniment too may vary, from a single guitar to a 10-piece band/orchestra.

By far the most elaborate of all panunuluyan is the maytinis of Kawit, Cavite, where a young couple costumed as the Virgin and San Jose ride a huge float, which in turn is accompanied by about 13 other floats depicting characters and scenes from the Old Testament, like Adam and Eve, Moses, King David, Queen Esther, Judith and Holofernes, Samson and Delilah; the New Testament, like the Annunciation, the Immaculate Conception, and the Visitation; and Kawit’s past (Mother Country and Independence). Before midnight, the Holy Couple come down from their float, walk to the church, and ascend the stairs to an elaborate Bethlehem scene on the altar, where they are welcomed by “angels” in white costumes and led into a “cave” where they disappear behind the curtains. At the “Gloria,” the curtains of the “cave” are drawn, revealing the Nativity scene, with the images of Mary and Joseph wearing the costumes of their live counterparts. Wooden angels descend from the “heavens” and several angelita (girls dressed as angels) adore the Christ Child as the drums and orchestra play the jubilant “Gloria.”

Because of its popularity, the form of the panunuluyan has been used by different groups to reinterpret the search for an inn by Mary and Joseph according to sectoral realities. A play inspired by the panunuluyan is the Philippine Educational Theater Association’s Ang Panunuluyan ng Birhen Maria at San Jose sa Cubao, Ayala, Plaza Miranda, Atbp. Lugar sa Loob at Labas ng Metro Manila (Virgin Mary and Saint Joseph’s Search for an Inn in Cubao, Ayala, Plaza Miranda, and Other Places Inside and Outside Metro Manila),1979. Here the images of Mary and Joseph come to life, and down from their float and are led by a young boy, Jesus, to different parts of Metro Manila to see for themselves the conditions of Philippine society. They go to Carriedo, Quiapo, where the vendors eke out a living; to the Manila Hotel where the rich are enjoying themselves, oblivious of the poor; to Navotas, Rizal, where the batilyo or fish stevedores are overworked and underpaid; to a farm where peasants are deprived of their rightful share of the harvest by the landlord; and to California Clark Philippines where workers are forming a union to fight for better wages. In the end Mary and Joseph realize that their plight as working people is no different from that of the sectors they visited.

During the incumbency of Lou Veloso as Manila City councilor, from 1995 to 2012, Tanghalang Santa Ana presented the panunuluyan. The group performed the panunuluyan for nine evenings, starting Dec 16. The group coordinated with the barangay officials to identify the most impoverished family in each of the nine barangays of Santa Ana. The residence of each of these families became the performance site of the panunuluyan. The dramatization culminated on the eve of Christmas inside the Santa Ana Church.

Other panunuluyan have been organized by cause-oriented groups, like those of the urban poor, the workers, the teachers, and the students, using images or puppets to represent the Holy Couple who go to several destinations in Metro Manila, in a procession that is a convoy of jeepneys and trucks. An example was that organized by Buklod in Dec 1991 in the quadrangle of the Claret Church in Quezon City. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson, with notes from Galileo S. Zafra

photos.desc: Women and men dressed as pastores or shepherds singing and dancing to villancico music, Camalig, Albay, 1989 (CCP Collection)

text:
The pastores, from Spanish pastores meaning “shepherds,” is a dramatization of the shepherds’s adoration of the Infant Jesus in Bethlehem, usually presented in the days just before Christmas or on Christmas Eve; it can also refer to a band of singers dressed as shepherds who perform Christmas songs and dances from house to house during the Christmas season.

Far north in Cagayan, there is the infantes, which is the locality’s equivalent for the pastores.The girls dress like baby dolls and click bamboo castanets, while the boys beat on bamboo tubes called tubtubong .The Three Kings are represented as simulated higante (giants), while accompanying angels are teased by a comic who represents the devil.

In Bicol, the pastores are 12 adults or children, mostly female, led by a capitana (female captain). The number probably alludes to the apostles with the capitanarepresenting Christ. The “shepherdesses” wear full skirts, round-necked blouses with puffed sleeves, and wide-brimmed hats, while the “shepherds” sport long-sleeved shirts, breast and waistbands, and decorated hats. Groups dress in a uniform color—red, blue, or green. At every house, they sing, to the accompaniment of a small orchestra (guitar, violin, bass, drum), a series of Spanish villancicos or carols (including “Pastores a Belen,” which is attributed to Jose Rizal), as well as Bikol carols, while executing dance movements and patterns, using handkerchiefs and rattan arko or arches gaily trimmed with colorful paper as props. They are gifted with money or food by the owners of houses at which they sing. To encourage the barrio people to continue with the tradition, pastores contests are held on stage in Legazpi, Albay, during the Christmas season.

 

Most colorful in Bicol is pastores Talisay in Camarines Norte. Looking colorfully Mexican, it has women swirling their voluminous poblana skirts like cascading rainbows, while the men bear papier-mâché horses to signify that they are riding up and down hills. With kaleidoscopic movements, the women also carry arches of flowers. Another in Pilar, Sorsogon, is pastores Santo Niño, where boys dress in Middle Eastern shepherds’ garb (long white soutanes and head scarves with headband), the girls in white or pastel dresses, usually wearing hats with ribbons or flowers. They dance to “Vamos a Belen”played by a rondalla and a drum. Still another is pastores Tubog in Oas, Albay, where again shepherds dress in the Middle Eastern way, with children carrying lambs (made of bamboo and rice paper) as piñatas and floral arches. Six pairs of girls and boys are led by a capitana. Characteristically, they wear abaca slippers with simulated cloth leggings and sing in Spanish, Latin, and Bikol. This is done on the feast of the Three Kings. Pastores Bungiawon is also attributed to Oas in Albay. Here, the girls put ruffles of recycled plastic bags around their skirts and arches. In Mercedes, Eastern Samar, skirts are made of crepe paper, and blouses from commercial plastic sacks.

In her masteral thesis in the University of the Philippines, Jiye A. Margate describes the pastoras from Camarines Sur. In the pastora Baao and pastora Bombon, girls wear the usual pretty dresses and hats and sing to different musical accompaniments: in Baao, originally to the violin, double bass, and guitar, but now only to the saxophone; and in Bombon, originally to saxophone, violin, guitar, and flute, but now more often just to a guitar. Here girls train under their elders and danceas panata (vow) to the Virgin Mary.

In Cebu and Leyte, the pastores, played by a group of children wearing hats with bands, sing and dance at different houses, confront and drive away the devil, who dissuades them from visiting the Messiah, and then proceed on their journey to adore the child. Sometimes a couple playing Mary and Joseph presents them with the image of the Christ Child at some point in the journey.

Out in Cebu is pastores Kalawit in one of the Camotes Islands, where middle-aged women dance as their fellow fisherfolk watch them. In the nacio pastores of New Washington, Aklan, the ritualists dance with the image of the Niño dormido (asleep) and sing old villancicos. In Ibajay, Aklan, the bailo (from baile) de pastores features boys and girls dressed in white with red waistbands and hats with flowers and carrying tambourines while dancing. In Leyte, pastores Tolosa has singing in Waray, with a comic encounter between the devil and the shepherds. Also in Ormoc, Leyte, a little more complex scenario shows a half-man and half-monkey devil trying to mislead the shepherds until the latter are rescued by an angel.

Most of these pastores with place-names are from the field research of National Artist Ramon Arevalo Obusan. These names serve as index to the repertoire of the Ramon A. Obusan Folkloric Group. For several years, Obusan presented the program Vamos at Belen every December at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson, updated by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

article.value: Far north in Cagayan, there is the infantes, which is the locality’s equivalent for the pastores.The girls dress like baby dolls and click bamboo castanets, while the boys beat on bamboo tubes called tubtubong .The Three Kings are represented as simulated higante (giants), while accompanying angels are teased by a comic who represents the devil.

In Bicol, the pastores are 12 adults or children, mostly female, led by a capitana (female captain). The number probably alludes to the apostles with the capitanarepresenting Christ. The “shepherdesses” wear full skirts, round-necked blouses with puffed sleeves, and wide-brimmed hats, while the “shepherds” sport long-sleeved shirts, breast and waistbands, and decorated hats. Groups dress in a uniform color—red, blue, or green. At every house, they sing, to the accompaniment of a small orchestra (guitar, violin, bass, drum), a series of Spanish villancicos or carols (including “Pastores a Belen,” which is attributed to Jose Rizal), as well as Bikol carols, while executing dance movements and patterns, using handkerchiefs and rattan arko or arches gaily trimmed with colorful paper as props. They are gifted with money or food by the owners of houses at which they sing. To encourage the barrio people to continue with the tradition, pastores contests are held on stage in Legazpi, Albay, during the Christmas season.

article.value: Most colorful in Bicol is pastores Talisay in Camarines Norte. Looking colorfully Mexican, it has women swirling their voluminous poblana skirts like cascading rainbows, while the men bear papier-mâché horses to signify that they are riding up and down hills. With kaleidoscopic movements, the women also carry arches of flowers. Another in Pilar, Sorsogon, is pastores Santo Niño, where boys dress in Middle Eastern shepherds’ garb (long white soutanes and head scarves with headband), the girls in white or pastel dresses, usually wearing hats with ribbons or flowers. They dance to “Vamos a Belen”played by a rondalla and a drum. Still another is pastores Tubog in Oas, Albay, where again shepherds dress in the Middle Eastern way, with children carrying lambs (made of bamboo and rice paper) as piñatas and floral arches. Six pairs of girls and boys are led by a capitana. Characteristically, they wear abaca slippers with simulated cloth leggings and sing in Spanish, Latin, and Bikol. This is done on the feast of the Three Kings. Pastores Bungiawon is also attributed to Oas in Albay. Here, the girls put ruffles of recycled plastic bags around their skirts and arches. In Mercedes, Eastern Samar, skirts are made of crepe paper, and blouses from commercial plastic sacks.

In her masteral thesis in the University of the Philippines, Jiye A. Margate describes the pastoras from Camarines Sur. In the pastora Baao and pastora Bombon, girls wear the usual pretty dresses and hats and sing to different musical accompaniments: in Baao, originally to the violin, double bass, and guitar, but now only to the saxophone; and in Bombon, originally to saxophone, violin, guitar, and flute, but now more often just to a guitar. Here girls train under their elders and danceas panata (vow) to the Virgin Mary.

In Cebu and Leyte, the pastores, played by a group of children wearing hats with bands, sing and dance at different houses, confront and drive away the devil, who dissuades them from visiting the Messiah, and then proceed on their journey to adore the child. Sometimes a couple playing Mary and Joseph presents them with the image of the Christ Child at some point in the journey.

Out in Cebu is pastores Kalawit in one of the Camotes Islands, where middle-aged women dance as their fellow fisherfolk watch them. In the nacio pastores of New Washington, Aklan, the ritualists dance with the image of the Niño dormido (asleep) and sing old villancicos. In Ibajay, Aklan, the bailo (from baile) de pastores features boys and girls dressed in white with red waistbands and hats with flowers and carrying tambourines while dancing. In Leyte, pastores Tolosa has singing in Waray, with a comic encounter between the devil and the shepherds. Also in Ormoc, Leyte, a little more complex scenario shows a half-man and half-monkey devil trying to mislead the shepherds until the latter are rescued by an angel.

Most of these pastores with place-names are from the field research of National Artist Ramon Arevalo Obusan. These names serve as index to the repertoire of the Ramon A. Obusan Folkloric Group. For several years, Obusan presented the program Vamos at Belen every December at the Cultural Center of the Philippines.
Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson, updated by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
Puppet theater is a form of drama in which the characters are puppets—inanimate objects manipulated by a puppeteer in front of an audience. The basic types are finger puppets, hand puppets, rod puppets, shadow puppets, and string puppets.

The carillo of the 19th century, also known as potei, kikimut, and titire in Pampanga, is one of the early forms of puppetry in Philippine theater history. It did not, however, continue into the 20th century. The carillo made use of crudely painted scenery and cardboard figures held up by means of wooden sticks before a lighted lamp projected against a white sheet. By means of pantomimic movement and dialogue provided by the manipulators, they presented stories from the awit and korido, metrical romances about lives of saints or the adventures of chivalric figures—for example, Don Juan Teñoso, Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), Siete Infantes de Lara (Seven Sons of Lara)—the same material used in the komedya.

The higante of Angono, Rizal, can also be considered part of puppetry. These are giant figures measuring 8-11 feet in height and 4-5 feet in diameter. Traditionally, the bodies of these higante are made of bamboo frames covered in cloth and the heads are made of papier-mâché. Over time, new materials, such as aluminum for the frame body and resin for the head, were used to create these huge puppets. The higante are carried by men hidden inside the hollow bodies of the three-dimensional figures and are paraded during the feast of San Clemente, the patron saint of fisherfolk. Higante usually represent farmers, fisherfolk, and mythological creatures. They wear traditional Filipino costumes and a panleeg (bib or scarf) to cover the part where the head and the body are connected. Social classes of the higante are distinguished by their facial features. For example, landlords are depicted with pointed noses, rosy cheeks, and fair complexion, while the fisherfolk and farmers have flat noses and dark skin tone. Although the higante became popular in Angono, other areas have their own version of these huge figures, such as in Lucban, Quezon; Gasan, Marinduque; Miag-ao, Iloilo; and Kalibo, Aklan.

 

In the late 1930s, puppetry in the form of ventriloquism became known in the Philippines through the efforts of Manuel Urbano, more popularly known as Manuel Conde. When he was in grade school in Daet, he asked a ventriloquist named Austria, a performer in Borromeo Lou’s bodabil troupe, to teach him the techniques of ventriloquism. He learned the art and so around 1938, he asked his friend, Tony Dumlao, to make him a doll, a local version of the Edgar Bergen and Charlie McCarthy dolls then sold at Beck’s Department Store. The doll, which looked Filipino and funny, was christened Kiko Tolosa. The doll also instigated the renaming of “Manuel Urbano” to “Manuel Conde,” since it was difficult for a ventriloquist to pronounce “Urbano.” Kiko and Conde performed on the Purico Hour over the radio, at stage shows, and on special occasions for many years (Tiongson 2008a, 17).

After Conde’s time, the next reference to puppet theater was in the early 1970s with the founding of Alsa Balutan, headed by Tessie Ordoña, who studied puppet therapy at the London Puppet Center through the sponsorship of the British Council and observed puppetry in Europe. Alsa Balutan was a group of 15 puppeteers that performed from the poorest tenement houses to the most luxurious hotels in the Philippines. The group used muppets, or hand puppets with movable mouths, inspired by Jim Henson’s Muppets from the television show Sesame Street.

Also in the 1970s, Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio of the University of the Philippines (UP) started working on puppets with a group of students (comprising grade school to graduate school students). After the success of her first full-length puppet play, Abadeja: Ang Ating Sinderela (Abadeja: Our Own Cinderella), performed at UP in 1977, the group refused to disband; at the performance of Tatluhan, three one-act plays, in Rizal Park in 1978, it was introduced as Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas. Since then, Lapeña-Bonifacio’s works have been mainly for this group. She is its writer and artistic director, her husband Manuel Bonifacio is its producer, and her daughter Amihan, herself a puppeteer, musician, and composer, is assistant director.

The Teatrong Mulat makes extensive use of Asian puppets, especially wayang kulit, wayang golek, and bunraku, but within stories drawn from Asian (Indian, Burmese, Japanese, Chinese, etc.) and Philippine folklore, such as Ang Paghuhukom (The Trial), 1979; Ang Pagong at ang Tsonggo (The Turtle and the Monkey), 1980; Sa Kasimu-simula (In the Beginning), 1981; and Si Suan, Si Suan (This Suan, This Suan), 1983. It has therefore developed puppet characters from Filipino folklore, such as Tsonggo, Matsing, and Abadeja. A signal achievement has been Papet Pasyon (The Passion of Jesus Christ in Puppetry), 1985, which melds the Christian tradition and its religious folk theater (the pasyon and the sinakulo) with Asian puppetry both past and present. In the late 1990s, Lapeña-Bonifacio’s dream came true when the Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio Teatro Papet Museo was built. It houses an auditorium for puppet performances, a puppet museum, and other spaces for creative endeavors. Teatrong Mulat is also the National Center of the international puppet organization Union Internationale de la Marionnette. In 2004, Teatrong Mulat staged its version of the popular Indian epic Ramayana, titled Sita & Rama: Papet Ramayana, with text and puppets by Lapeña-Bonifacio, and arrangement and composition by Cynthia Alexander and Joey Ayala.

Teatrong Mulat gave support to other puppetry groups. With the initiative of culture scholar Ino Manalo, the group trained and helped organize the youth in Baclayon, Bohol, in 2010. The community-based puppet theater group, composed of neighborhood youngsters, call themselves Usbong Papet Baclayon, and they present puppet shows for Bohol residents and guests interested in discovering the Boholano heritage and history. In 2011, the group performed Ang Aniniput ug ang Anunugba (The Firefly and the Moth) written by Manalo. It was performed in a makeshift space on the ground floor entertaining area of Manalo’s home in Baclayon. The other play they presented is The Jewel of the Virgin, 2014, also written by Manalo. This puppet theater group is trained by Amihan Bonifacio-Ramolete, who also serves as the group’s artistic consultant. Sigmund Roy Pecho, UP BA Theater Arts student and Mulat member, also serves as co-trainor.

Puppets are also the specialty of the Black Theater of Manila. Founded in 1978, this is the development communication arm of the Philippine Information Agency, which began with a show on nutrition called Kainan Na! (Eating Time!), the main character being Kapitan Munggo. The repertoire has since expanded to include shows on parenthood, dental care, Balik-Probinsiya (Return to the Provinces), care for the disabled, and folktales. Shows are presented on tours to audiences of children (ages 4 to 10 or 9 and above), and on television in shows such as Batang Pinoy (Filipino Child) and Tok-Tok Karatok,which spun off into a travelogue for children called Sa Ating Daigdig (In Our World).

Black Theater uses puppet characters acting as co-hosts on TV shows, shows in the “black theater technique” (luminous paint on props and costumes, and ultraviolet lights that make objects glow in the dark), hand puppets, string puppets, and muppets. In their repertoire are shows such as Bernardo Carpio, Awit ng Adarna (Song of the Adarna Bird), Magigue, Aming Pasko (Our Christmas), Tatlong Biik (Three Little Pigs), Mariang Alimango (Maria the Crab), and Smile Ato.The company also conducts workshops on puppet theater production, including topics such as puppetry in education, puppet design and construction, props and set design, scriptwriting and direction, puppet manipulation, lighting and special effects, and voicing and acting for the puppet stage.

Another puppet group is Roppets Edutainment Production Inc, founded by Danny Liwanag in 1987. It produced the first hand puppet magician in the Fancy Magic Show. Along with puppet groups are individual artists, such as ventriloquists, puppeteers who specialize in the art of projecting their voices without moving their lips while moving the mouths of their dummies (puppets) to make it appear that their dummies are the ones talking. Well-known ventriloquists are Ony Carcamo, Talentadong Pinoy Hall of Famer Wanlu Lunaria, and Ruther Urquia, among others.

Born out of the Philippine High School for the Arts is A-NI-NO: Makiling Shadow Play Collective, composed mainly of young graduates and student artists. The group premiered at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in Feb 1993 with The Shadow Play, an “experimental multimedia puppetry production.” Through the use of rear-projected imagery, soft candle-enhanced shadow imagery, flashlight-enhanced puppets, Indonesian wooden puppets, and the puppeteers’ own hand and body shadows, as well as other conventional and experimental puppetry gadgets and methods, the collective interpreted 13 popular, environmental, folk, and original songs (e.g., Yoyoy Villame’s “Magellan,” “Granada,” and “Buchikik”) and compositions by Joey Ayala and Edru Abraham’s Kontra-Gapi. The concept was born out of the school’s need to evolve and explore alternative approaches in storytelling with light, shadow, sound, and movement. Initially conceptualized as a co-curricular annual activity for students as part of the school’s Visual Arts Week celebration in 1979, it was integrated into the academic program in 1987. The collective has toured the production and conducted workshops for children in different parts of the country (e.g., resettlement area for Pinatubo victims in Tarlac), and it continues to expand and explore new possibilities in puppetry.

In 1996, the group became known as Anino Shadowplay Collective, composed of visual artists, educators, cultural workers, musicians, and theater practitioners. In 2006, Anino performed a modern adaptation of Balagtas’s Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura). Written by Ian Victoriano with Nono O. Pardalis, composition and music by Chris Carandang with Datu Arellano, this became an official entry of the Philippines in the 10th World Festival of Puppet Art, Prague, Czech Republic.

Puppets have been used as well in plays for adults, such as Domingo Landicho’s Dupluhang Bayan (National Joust), staged in 1975 by the Tanghalang Tampipi, a group of puppeteers and children’s theater artists in Metro Manila. Dulaang UP director Jose Estrella has incorporated shadow puppetry in her works, such as Umaaraw, Umuulan, Kinakasal ang Tikbalang (Sun Shining, Rain Pouring, Horse Demons Wed), 2011; Adarna, 2013; and Bilanggo ng Pag-ibig (Prisoner of Love), 2015. In 2012, the UP Center for International Studies (UP CIS) organized the UP CIS Bunraku Ensemble after training several students in the art of bunraku, a Japanese theater form with three puppeteers manipulating one puppet, under the Naoshima Onna Bunraku group in Naoshima, Japan. The group staged Papet at Maskara (Puppet and Mask) in 2013 in celebration of the 40th year of ASEAN-Japan Friendship and Cooperation.

Performances, workshops, and seminars continue to expand the field and present the potential of puppetry not only in theater but also in education, therapy, and creating awareness about social issues.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Amihan Bonifacio-Ramolete

text:
Realism refers to a style of modern theater that aims to give a truthful rendering of reality, through characters that are well rounded, authentic individuals, plots that develop as the individuals interact with each other and with society, and production design (costumes, props, sets, lighting) that helps to produce an “illusion of reality” or a “slice of life” on stage. A species of realism is naturalism, which emphasizes the effect of heredity and environment on characters that are out of the ordinary.

The movement toward realism began in the 1850s in Europe with French writers like Alexandre Dumas and Émile Augier who focused on contemporary characters and social problems. Considered the “Father of Realism,” however, is Norwegian dramatist Henrik Ibsen who staged The Pillars of Society, a problem play, in 1875. In this as in his A Doll’s House, 1879, Ghosts, 1881, and An Enemy of the People, 1882, Ibsen unmasked society’s code of “morality” whose hypocrisy destroys human beings. In The Wild Duck, 1884, Hedda Gabler, 1890, and The Master Builder, 1892, Ibsen concentrated on the psychology of particular individuals.

 

As important to realism as Ibsen is the Russian playwright Anton Chekhov, who wrote about upper-class characters whose dreams are frustrated by social developments and the weakness of their own personalities. The Seagull, 1896, Uncle Vanya,1899, The Three Sisters, 1901, and The Cherry Orchard, 1904, present individuals who are tragic and comic, often floating aimlessly in a space that is effectively recreated on stage by a plot that seems to unfold as it would in real life.

Other classics of realism are Emile Zola’s Therese Raquin, 1873, August Strindberg’s Miss Julie, 1888, Friedrich Durrenmatt’s The Visit, 1956, and Maxim Gorky’s Lower Depths, 1902, and Enemies, 1907.

The plays of Chekhov were successfully staged by the Moscow Art Theater founded by Constantin Stanislavsky, who evolved a method of acting aimed at psychological realism. This method required the actor to keenly observe reality, hone the body as an instrument of expression, identify the character’s principal “spine” as the basis for characterization, and develop “emotion memory” to recall a situation in one’s life where the actor felt the emotion called for in a play’s situation.

 

In the United States, realism began to develop from 1910 to 1920 through the “little theater movement” which was concerned with presenting plays with artistic excellence. In the decades that followed, realism developed in the hands of American playwrights, like Tennessee Williams, who wrote The Glass Menagerie, 1945, A Streetcar Named Desire, 1947, The Rose Tattoo, 1951, Summer and Smoke, 1952, Orpheus Descending, 1957, Suddenly Last Summer, 1959, and The Night of the Iguana, 1961; Arthur Miller who did All My Sons, 1947, Death of a Salesman, 1949, The Crucible, 1953, and A View from the Bridge, 1955; and Eugene O’Neill who created Mourning Becomes Electra, 1931, and Long Day’s Journey into Night, 1957.

In the 1920s another type of realism developed in Russia called socialist realism, which referred to plays of the “people’s theater” where forces opposed to the Russian Revolution of 1917 are presented as villains or where the lower classes are depicted in their abject poverty, exploited by landlords and capitalists. Under the influence of Vsevelod Meyerhold, socialist realism began to employ a nonrealistic production style to present social problems.

It was only after World War II that the styles of modern theater were introduced in the Philippines through the Westernized educational system. Anglo-American culture was given emphasis in English classes, and dramas, such as those of realism, were studied in college as contemporary world classics. Moreover, some of the plays of realism reached even wider audiences when their movie versions were shown in Manila.

Most playwrights and audiences encountered European or American realism through the translations and adaptations of these plays in local productions. Henrik Ibsen’s Hedda Gabler was directed by Wilfrido Ma.Guerrero for the UP Dramatic Club in the 1950s, by Rolando S. Tinio for Teatro Pilipino in 1977 and 1980, and by Antonio Mabesa for Dulaang UP in 1982. Ghosts was directed by Guerrero for his company in the 1950s and by Lito Casaje for Dramatis Personae in 1991, while A Doll’s House was directed by Mabesa for Dulaang UP in 1982. Chekhov’s The Seagull was staged as Ang Tagak, 1979, translated and directed by Rolando S. Tinio for Teatro Pilipino; and as Ibon ng Lawa, 1992, translated by Jose Maria Matute and directed by Nonon Padilla for Tanghalang Pilipino. The Cherry Orchard and The Three Sisters were directed by Antonio Mabesa in 1983 and 1987, respectively, and adapted by Rody Vera as Arbol de Fuego in 2015 and Tatlong Mariya in 2010, respectively; Tiyo Vanya (Uncle Vanya), translated and directed by Rolando S. Tinio in 1976 and 1980; A Marriage Proposal, translated as Pamanhikan by Marcelino Cavestany Jr and directed by Lutgardo Labad in 1974, and translated and directed as Ang Pamamanhikan by Rolando S. Tinio in 1981; and The Boor and The Anniversary, both translated and directed by Rolando S. Tinio in 1981. Bienvenido Lumbera’s translation of Gorky’s Enemies was directed by Behn Cervantes in 1982; Ligaya Perez’s translation of The Lower Depths was directed by Nonon Padilla in 1990; and Virgilio Almario’s translation of Summerfolk was directed by Antonio Mabesa in 1990. Friedrich Durrenmatt’s The Visit was translated and directed by Rolando S. Tinio as Ang Pagdalaw ng Senyora in 1980, and by Joi Barrios and Jerry Respeto into Ang Pagbabalik ng Madam directed by Alexander Cortez in 1991. Rolando S. Tinio directed August Strindberg’s Miss Julie for Repertory Philippines in 1967.

The works of realism of many other playwrights in Europe and the United States have also been staged in the Philippines. Tennessee Williams’s The Glass Menagerie was produced by Ateneo de Manila as Laruang Kristal, translated and directed by Rolando S. Tinio for the first time in 1966; by Repertory Philippines directed by Joey Gosiengfiao in 1978; by Dulaang UP in 1987 directed by Jorge Ledesma; and by Tanghalang Ateneo directed by Ricky Abad in 2007. Cat on a Hot Tin Roof was directed by Bernardo Bernardo for Repertory Philippines in 1979; its Filipino translation, Pusa sa Yerong Bubong, by Tony Perez was directed by Lino Brocka for the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) in 1980. Flores para los Muertos, Orlando Nadres’s translation of A Streetcar Named Desire, was directed by Lino Brocka for PETA in 1980 and by Floy Quintos for Tanghalang Pilipino in 2009; Summer and Smoke, directed by Lolita Swiryn, and Suddenly Last Summer, directed by Joey Gosiengfiao, were produced by Repertory Philippines in 1973 and 1968, respectively; and Camino Real was directed by Antonio Mabesa in 1986. Arthur Miller’s Death of Salesman was translated and directed by Rolando S. Tinio as Pahimakas sa Isang Ahente for the Ateneo de Manila in 1966 and directed by Joel Lamangan for Tanghalang Pilipino in 2014.

Performed in English or Filipino, in translation or adaptation by school-based groups or by professional or semiprofessional theater companies, these plays of European and American realism became the models for the first one-act and full-length plays of realism written in the Philippines. Instrumental in the spread of these plays and in the writing and staging of the realistic plays by Filipinos are directors like Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero, Rolando S. Tinio, Antonio Mabesa, Zeneida Amador, Behn Cervantes, Nonon Padilla, Anton Juan Jr, Jonas Sebastian, Ricky Abad, Chris Millado, Soxie Topacio, and Maribel Legarda. The styles of modern theater introduced from the West were adapted by Filipino modern playwrights and directors according to the needs of Philippine society and the temper of the times.

Realism has followed two tendencies in the country: the psychological, which focuses on the problems of individuals in themselves or in relation to other individuals; and the social, which situates individual problems within the larger framework of a class society in order to highlight urgent economic, political, or social issues in that society.

Plays that painstakingly depict believable and well-rounded characters are first found among plays written in English by Filipinos in the 1940s and the 1950s, like Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero’s The Forsaken House, 1940, which is about a family torn apart because of the conflict in the ways and values of parents and children; and Three Rats, 1948, which tells of a woman’s affair with her husband’s best friend, and the subsequent murder of his friend by her husband. Severino Montano’s Sabina,1944, tells of the tragic fate of a young woman who fell in love with a traveling American trader.

Two plays by Nick Joaquin employ the style of realism. A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1955, first directed by Lamberto V. Avellana for the Barangay Theater Guild, depicts the tragedy of two old-maid sisters in old Intramuros right before World War II, who refuse to accept the values of commercialism and pragmatism being propagated by the Americans and their Filipino followers, defending instead the Hispanic and genteel lifestyle of their father and their childhood even if they must live in poverty. Portrait ’s Filipino translation by Alfred Yuson and Franklin Osorio, titled Larawan, was directed by Lino Brocka for PETA in 1979; by Behn Cervantes for UP Repertory Company in 1982; and by Nonon Padilla for Tanghalang Pilipino in 1989. Larawan was restaged by Tanghalang Pilipino in 1992 with a new translation by Bienvenido Lumbera, still under the direction of Padilla. Fathers and Sons, 1975, focuses on the conflict of generations—between the patriarch and his businessman son and between the latter and his own son who wants to be a priest. Its translation, Mga Ama, Mga Anak, was directed by Lino Brocka for PETA in 1976 and by Joel Lamangan for Tanghalang Pilipino in 2014.

After Guerrero, Montano, and Joaquin, younger playwrights ventured into writing plays that present the personal problems of typical Filipino individuals. Paraisong Parisukat (Square Eden), 1974, written and directed by Orlando S. Nadres for PETA, shows how a simpleminded girl decides to bury her life and dreams of love and progress in the stuffy stockroom of a shoe store. Bienvenido Noriega Jr’s Bayan-bayanan (Little Country), 1975, first directed by Antonio Mabesa for Dulaang UP, and restaged by Pio de Castro in 1989 for Tanghalang Pilipino, exposes the personal dreams and frustrations of Filipino expatriates in Switzerland. Rene O. Villanueva’s Hiblang Abo (Strands of Gray), 1980, first directed by Tony Espejo for Bulwagang Gantimpala, depicts the loneliness and tragic end of four senior citizens in a home for the aged. Tony Perez’s Biyaheng Timog (Trip to the South), 1985, first directed by Nonon Padilla for Bulwagang Gantimpala, shows how an autocratic patriarch has destroyed the lives of his children, and how, after his death, his children finally become whole as persons. Elsa Martinez-Coscolluela’s In My Father’s House, 1987, directed by Antonio Mabesa for UP Playwrights Theater, depicts the slow deterioration of an upper middle-class family and its members who either reject or collaborate with the Japanese occupation of Negros Oriental in the early 1940s. Rody Vera’s Kung Paano Ko Pinatay si Diana Ross (How I Killed Diana Ross), 1991, is about a young man who represses his gay self by living like a regular macho and even marrying a girl, until his love for his best friend breaks down all pretensions and liberates the Diana Ross in him. Nick Pichay’s Tres Ataques de Corazon, 2005, depicts three characters from different classes and walks of life as they struggle with personal crises that lead to their heart attacks. Floy Quintos’s An Evening at the Opera, 2011, reveals the destructive relationship between a cultured but feisty socialite and her boorish, corrupt, and womanizing politician of a husband, whom she married for convenience. Auraeus Solito’s Mga Buhay na Apoy (Living Flames), 2015, shows how a middle-aged woman finally comes to terms with her traumatic past and an ethnicity that she had tried to erase by living a normal middle-class life in the city.

Plays of social realism, on the other hand, present individuals caught in the issues and conflicts of society. One of the first plays about poverty, which ironically is written in English, is Alberto Florentino’s The World Is an Apple, 1954, first directed by Nick Agudo for Civic Theater, and later by Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero for the UP Mobile Theater tours. The play shows how a slum dweller is driven into crime in order to buy medicine for his sick child. Rogelio Sicat’s Moses, Moses, 1968, was first directed by Paul Dumol in the 1970s at Ateneo, then performed at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, and restaged by Auraeus Solito for Tropa in 1990. The play portrays a family’s struggle for justice. Reuel Molina Aguila’s In Dis Korner (In This Corner), 1978, first directed by Anton Juan Jr for Dulaang UP, dramatizes an episode in the life of a professional boxer, who comes back to the ring to earn enough money to open a little store for his wife but turns his back on victory to buck the system of “fixing,” which exploits boxers like him. Chris Millado’s Buwan at Baril sa E-flat Major (Moon and Gun in E-flat Major), 1985, directed by Apo Chua for PETA, and for Tanghalang Pilipino in 1989, shows in five simple episodes the politicization of two brothers (a farmer and a worker) who meet during the Lakbayan march; a socialite dressing up to join a rally; an ethnic woman who reveals to a priest the abuses she suffered at the hands of the military; a student activist who gets caught by the military, is investigated, but outwits the military and manages to escape; and a teacher who has come to fetch the body of her NPA husband. Malou Jacob’s Anatomiya ng Korupsyon (Anatomy of Corruption), 1992, dramatizes how an idealistic young lawyer struggles to keep her integrity in a law office where corruption has become a way of life. Layeta Bucoy’s Doc Resureccion: Gagamutin ang Bayan (Doc Resureccion: Will Heal the Nation), 2009, is about a doctor who visits the slums where he came from to solicit his cousin’s support in the coming elections, but instead is murdered in cold blood by his relatives for snubbing and neglecting the people he left behind in the slums.

Realism is also used by many contemporary adaptations of stories first popularized in other media. Because the original novels were already written in that style, it was natural for Rody Vera and collaborating artists to adapt F. Sionil Jose’s Mass and The Pretenders for the stage using the style of realism in 2005 and 2007, respectively. Similarly, movies made famous by Lino Brocka—namely, Insiang, 1976, and Bona, 1980—were successfully adapted for the stage using a predominantly realistic style in 2002 and 2012, respectively.

In the staging of these plays, realism is evident in one-unit sets such as the living room set in Three Rats; in costumes depicting a particular period, such as the 1940s clothes and hairstyles worn by the actors in In My Father’s House; and in special effects, such as the snow seen falling outside a window in Bayan-bayanan. In In Dis Korner,a boxing arena was used for the fight scenes but modified for other scenes as well. In Insiang, the wraparound set covered almost three walls of the CCP Tanghalang Huseng Batute with two-level slum dwellings and narrow passageways. This in-your-face set, together with the interminable movements of its lumpen characters and the strong expletives punctuating the colourful exchanges, captures so well the dog-eat-dog conditions that assault and devour the innocent Insiang.

Since the 1950s, the spirit of realism and its method of scientific observation have enabled Filipino artists to grapple with the here and now. This has resulted in plays that now present a gallery of memorable Filipino characters painstakingly delineated—peasants, workers, sales clerks, social workers, street children, basketball stars, boxers, middle-class couples, impoverished gentry, war heroes, slum dwellers—and a compendium of stories that chronicle the Filipino’s various reactions to the institutions and conditions of Philippine society. No doubt such plays have contributed greatly to the continuing definition of the Filipino identity. However, even as realism has been lauded for its insistence on what is, it has also been faulted for exactly the same reason, because many plays of realism confine and resign themselves to the immutable and less-than-ideal present, often negating hope in the future and the possibility of change. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

Chris Millado’s Buwan at Baril sa E-flat Major (Moon and Gun in E-flat Major), 1985, directed by Apo Chua for PETA, and for Tanghalang Pilipino in 1989, shows in five simple episodes the politicization of two brothers (a farmer and a worker) who meet during the Lakbayan march; a socialite dressing up to join a rally; an ethnic woman who reveals to a priest the abuses she suffered at the hands of the military; a student activist who gets caught by the military, is investigated, but outwits the military and manages to escape; and a teacher who has come to fetch the body of her NPA husband. Malou Jacob’s Anatomiya ng Korupsyon (Anatomy of Corruption), 1992, dramatizes how an idealistic young lawyer struggles to keep her integrity in a law office where corruption has become a way of life. Layeta Bucoy’s Doc Resureccion: Gagamutin ang Bayan (Doc Resureccion: Will Heal the Nation), 2009, is about a doctor who visits the slums where he came from to solicit his cousin’s support in the coming elections, but instead is murdered in cold blood by his relatives for snubbing and neglecting the people he left behind in the slums.

Realism is also used by many contemporary adaptations of stories first popularized in other media. Because the original novels were already written in that style, it was natural for Rody Vera and collaborating artists to adapt F. Sionil Jose’s Mass and The Pretenders for the stage using the style of realism in 2005 and 2007, respectively. Similarly, movies made famous by Lino Brocka—namely, Insiang, 1976, and Bona, 1980—were successfully adapted for the stage using a predominantly realistic style in 2002 and 2012, respectively.

In the staging of these plays, realism is evident in one-unit sets such as the living room set in Three Rats; in costumes depicting a particular period, such as the 1940s clothes and hairstyles worn by the actors in In My Father’s House; and in special effects, such as the snow seen falling outside a window in Bayan-bayanan. In In Dis Korner,a boxing arena was used for the fight scenes but modified for other scenes as well. In Insiang, the wraparound set covered almost three walls of the CCP Tanghalang Huseng Batute with two-level slum dwellings and narrow passageways. This in-your-face set, together with the interminable movements of its lumpen characters and the strong expletives punctuating the colourful exchanges, captures so well the dog-eat-dog conditions that assault and devour the innocent Insiang.

Since the 1950s, the spirit of realism and its method of scientific observation have enabled Filipino artists to grapple with the here and now. This has resulted in plays that now present a gallery of memorable Filipino characters painstakingly delineated—peasants, workers, sales clerks, social workers, street children, basketball stars, boxers, middle-class couples, impoverished gentry, war heroes, slum dwellers—and a compendium of stories that chronicle the Filipino’s various reactions to the institutions and conditions of Philippine society. No doubt such plays have contributed greatly to the continuing definition of the Filipino identity. However, even as realism has been lauded for its insistence on what is, it has also been faulted for exactly the same reason, because many plays of realism confine and resign themselves to the immutable and less-than-ideal present, often negating hope in the future and the possibility of change.
Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson
