text:
The ritual, which may be called pag-aanito (literally, dealing with the anito or ancestral spirits) or pagdiwata (literally, dealing with the diwata or spirit), is the prototypal sacrifice in which a native shaman called mambunung, catalonan, bayok, babaylan, or balyan goes into a trance, possessed by the spirit the shaman is calling upon. While entranced, the shaman kills the sacrificial animal—usually a pig, chicken, or carabao—or pours water over the offerings of food, betel nut, wine, textiles, or jewelry. These rituals are believed to be the principal way by which mortals can communicate with the gods or spirits, who are perceived to have power over the economic, political, and social as well as physical and spiritual well-being of the tribe.

Rituals, which are usually attended by dancing and chanting and accompanied by musical instruments, constitute the oldest form of theater in the Philippines because they contain the essence of theater— mimesis, or the imitation of action. Here, the sacrificial animal “plays the role” of the supplicant offering it, while the shaman stands for the spirit to whom the ritual is being offered. In full mimesis, therefore, the killing of the sacrificial animal represents the taking of the life of the supplicant by the spirit. In cases where food, betel nut, textiles, and jewelry are offered, the act of pouring water over these items by the shaman represents the consummation by the spirits of the “essence” of these offerings.

 

In indigenous Philippine societies, the basic ritual of sacrifice adapts itself to the different occasions for which it is held. Rituals may be offered in connection with the passage of tribal men and women through the stages of the life cycle—for example, to ensure the health of a newly born babe, to integrate a child into the community through the rite of baptism, to invite good fortune on the newly circumcised boy or to wish a young girl a good marriage after her first menstruation, to ask for prosperity and happiness for a newly married couple, and to lay the dead to everlasting rest.

An example of this life-cycle ritual is the Zambal ritual of baptism recorded by Father Perez in 1680. In this ritual, which is done in honor of the god Malyari, the shaman kills the animal prepared by the child’s parents for the occasion. Then, amidst the chanting of all, the priest dresses the child in its best clothes, and unravels its long hair whose fringes the shaman ornaments with pieces of gold (thus wishing the child prosperity in life). The shaman then pours the blood of the sacrificial animal on the child (identifying the child with the animal), and then proceeds to cut the child’s gold-embellished hair, to throw to an eager audience (thus reminding the child that individual prosperity must be shared with the tribe).

But rituals may also be held to bless or sanctify some of the most important economic, social, or political activities of the community—to cure the sick, to bless newly planted seedlings and to ensure a good harvest, to pray for or celebrate victory in war, to stop an epidemic or a plague, to identify a criminal, to consecrate a new shaman, or to elevate a new datu (chieftain).

A good example of the rice-planting ritual is the kashawing of the Maranao, as described by Madale in 1974. In order to ensure a bountiful harvest, the Maranao hold a series of nine rituals, which reenact the pact made between the god of the seen (the ancestor of the Maranao) and his brother, the god of the unseen beings who reside in the waters of Lake Lanao. The Maranao believe that in the past, the god of the unseen promised to protect the harvest of his brother’s descendants.

For this ritual, all Maranao farmers bring cooked rice, fish, and vegetables wrapped in banana leaves, and arrange these on a mat placed at the foot of the baletetree that stands at a certain distance from Lake Lanao. Beside the mat is a man who holds a pole with a red flag flying from it, symbolizing the Maranao. As soon as all are gathered, the farmers go on a procession led by an old man and the gong beater to the lake. Here, the old man wades into the water, calling on all the spirits of the lake to partake of their offering and to protect the crops of the Maranao, all the while waving a green-yellow flag to symbolize the invitation. After chanting his prayers, the old man then scoops water and some seaweed into a small can he has brought with him (the water symbolizes the spirits; the seaweed, their boats). The same man leads the procession of farmers back to the balete tree, with one man holding up on a pole a yellow flag symbolizing all the gods of the lake. Upon arrival at the tree, the pole of the yellow flag is stuck into the ground near the red flag, to signal the renewal of the pact. The old man pours out the water from the can on the offerings laid out on the mat. After the spirits have thus “partaken” of the offerings, the food is distributed and eaten reverently by the farmers. Thus is the pact ratified once more between the descendants of the seen and unseen gods.

Many rituals continue to be performed today by cultural communities that have not been thoroughly Westernized, like the Aeta, Ifugao, Kalinga, Bontok, Tinguian, Ibaloy, Tboli, Blaan, Bukidnon, Mandaya, Manobo, Tiruray, Palawan, Tagbanwa, Sama, and other ethnic groups. Interestingly enough, the rituals survive to our day even among Islamized peoples, like the Tausug, Maranao, and Maguindanaon, as well as Christianized groups like the Ibanag, Ilocano, Pangasinan, Pampango, Tagalog, Bikol, Cebuano, Ilonggo, and Waray. Among the Christianized groups, the rituals have assimilated Christian influences, especially in the replacement of ethnic gods with Christian saints, ethnic chants and movements with Christian prayers, music, and dances. Many scholars see this as proof that the ethnic precolonial culture has actually prevailed through the centuries, assimilating the foreign into the basic matrix of ethnicity.

A case in point is the atang-atang —literally, “offerings” in Ibanag. This healing ritual of the Ibanag in Cagayan features a colorfully decorated small bamboo raft that contains offerings of rice, eggs, oil, cigarettes, rice cakes, and a little chick representing the soul of the sick person. Around this raft situated on the ground, two old women dance to the accompaniment of a guitar, drink, and chant Christian prayers to cure the sick. Later, the women take oil from the raft and rub it on the face, legs, or hands of the sick person. Although it invokes the Christian God, this ritual is clearly in the tradition of the animistic pag-aanito.

In some Christian communities, the ritual survives in almost symbolic form, but without losing its original motive and mimetic structure. For example, while the presentation of the Hispanic komedya in a rural town like Peñaranda, Nueva Ecija, is done in early May to honor the patron Santa Cruz (May 3 being the feast of the Exaltation of the Cross in the Christian liturgy), its essence as a precolonial ritual can still be discerned. The two-day performance on an elevated stage in front of the parish church of Peñaranda is also called arakyo, a kind of komedya that dramatizes the story of the finding of the true cross of Christ and how Reyna Elena and her son Haring Constantino had to fight the Moros to keep it. A very important part of the presentation, which is not even in the script, is the performance of popular folk songs and even contemporary songs by the ladies in the cast, at intervals. So frequent and so long are these interval dances that one begins to suspect that they are not just intermission numbers, especially the long free-for-all dancing session called the pantot, which happens toward the end of the komedya on the afternoon of the second day. For the pantot, it is not only the female komedyante who dance but the males as well, and they are joined on stage by the townsfolk, male and especially female, who dance carrying their babies and young children in their arms. If the womenfolk do not dance on stage, they ask the male and female komedyante to carry their babies and dance with them for the duration of the pantot.

The key to understanding the komedya performance as an ethnic ritual is the term “pantot,” which is a variation of the Tagalog word pandot. As described by the Franciscan friar Juan de Plasencia in 1589, the pandot is a “festival” or “worship” attended by the community in the chief’s house, where the catalonan or shaman, after singing songs to the image of a native anito (spirit/god) and bedecking it in expensive cloths and jewelry, danced himself into a trance as the anito entered him. In his trance the shaman killed the sacrificial animal (goat, fowl, or pig), and distributed its parts to the community to be cooked and consumed. Such rituals, Plasencia noted, were held to ask the anito to heal the sick, bless a voyage, or ensure a good harvest, victory in war, a successful childbirth, and a happy married life.

Analyzed more closely, the parallelism between the spirit and structure of the pandot and those of the komedya/pantot becomes apparent. As the ethnic pandot was held by the Tagalog to ask a favor of the native anito, so the komedya and pantot are produced and performed as a solemn offering to the Christian image of the Holy Cross to ensure blessings (in many cases, identical to those mentioned by Plasencia) on Peñaranda town and its inhabitants. In the pandot, the supplicant is the one who is asking the anito for a favor; in the komedya and pantot it is the hermanos (sponsors) in the name of the community. The sacrificial pig would be the komedya itself, with the women and men dancing the pantot playing the role of the shaman presiding over the pantot. As the catalonan danced himself into a trance beside the sacrificial animal, so the women and men dance themselves into a frenzy on the stage of the komedya, side by side and with the komedyante who embody the sacrificial komedya. The three-way relationship between shaman, supplicant, and sacrifice has survived in the komedya/pantot for over four centuries, appropriating and prevailing over the foreign religion that tried its best to exterminate it. The komedya or arakyo, therefore, in spite of the foreign origins of its story and form, has remained as indigenous as the primordial pandot or pag-aanito originally enacted in the bosom of the indigenous Tagalog community. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
The salubong, from Tagalog salubong, meaning “meeting,” dramatizes the meeting of the grieving Mater Dolorosa or Sorrowful Mother and the Risen Christ on the first Easter Sunday morning. Easily one of the most popular of all Lenten playlets, the salubong is also known as sabet in Ilocano, padafung in Ibanag, abet-abet in Pangasinan, pagsugat in Ilonggo, sugat in Cebuano and Waray, and encuentro or alleluya in many other Catholic and Aglipayan parishes.

At crack of dawn, two processions with their own karo or floats wind their separate ways around opposite parts of town—the first, that of the image of the Risen Christ; the second, that of the Mater Dolorosa veiled in black, usually preceded by the images of San Pedro, Maria Jacobe, Maria Salome, Maria Magdalena, and San Juan. At the appointed time, the two processions meet in front of a colorful four-posted structure of bamboo or cement called the galilea, from whose “heaven” (i.e., ceiling) hangs a huge inverted heart-shaped “bud” with four petals, sometimes called puso (heart). As the band plays, these petals are opened one at a time (usually by colorful wooden birds) to reveal a little child dressed as an angel. The Mater Dolorosa is brought directly under the angel, who is then lowered slowly, as she sings the Easter Sunday antiphon: “Regina Coeli, laetare, alleluia, alleluia” (Queen of Heaven, rejoice, alleluia, alleluia). At song’s end, the little angel takes the Virgin’s veil and removes it to signify that the Virgin’s mourning has ended. Then, the angel is pulled back to “heaven” once more. Joyously, the two images then follow each other to the church, where Easter Sunday Mass is celebrated.

 

Many variations of the salubong are found in different regions. In many Tagalog towns of Rizal, Laguna, Cavite, Quezon, and Marinduque, an important feature of the salubong is the bati or pagbati (greeting), which dramatizes the meeting of the Virgin and the Risen Christ (before the actual unveiling), through the lively dance of a young woman holding the flag of the Virgin and a young man holding the flag of the Agnus Dei (Lamb of God) of Christ. In Angono, Rizal, which has one of the most elaborate salubong in the country, a tenienta (female lieutenant) dances waving a flag; then the capitana (female captain) declaimsa poem narrating the Resurrection of Christ, after which huge colorful birds swoop down on the galilea to open the inverted “bud.” In Bustillos, Sampaloc, a pigeon attached to a cluster of about 50 balloons clutches the Virgin’s veil with its claws and flies off with it (with help from the balloons), even as hundreds of balloons around the area are released all together to the band’s triumphant march. In Gasan, Marinduque, the Aglipayan salubong ends with a poem declaimed by a young woman to the Virgin, telling her to rejoice because Christ has risen from the dead, and to pray for the country so that its freedom may also rise from the dead. In Vigan, after the veil has been taken off by the angel, the inverted “bud” may open with a shower of roses and a flurry of pigeons’ wings. Also inVigan, the curtain between Christ and the Virgin is drawn away only after the veil has been taken off by the angel. In Santo Tomas, Pampanga, the salubong angel goes on procession after the salubong itself, carrying the Virgin’s black veil around the town’s streets, escorted by other little angels and preceded by 12 young ladies in colorful long gowns, who sing and dance to a violin’s lilting melody at more than 20 designated stages around town.

In Minglanilla, Cebu, about seven to nine angels “descend” from the breast of what looks like a huge bird sitting on top of the galilea. article.value: At crack of dawn, two processions with their own karo or floats wind their separate ways around opposite parts of town—the first, that of the image of the Risen Christ; the second, that of the Mater Dolorosa veiled in black, usually preceded by the images of San Pedro, Maria Jacobe, Maria Salome, Maria Magdalena, and San Juan. At the appointed time, the two processions meet in front of a colorful four-posted structure of bamboo or cement called the galilea, from whose “heaven” (i.e., ceiling) hangs a huge inverted heart-shaped “bud” with four petals, sometimes called puso (heart). As the band plays, these petals are opened one at a time (usually by colorful wooden birds) to reveal a little child dressed as an angel. The Mater Dolorosa is brought directly under the angel, who is then lowered slowly, as she sings the Easter Sunday antiphon: “Regina Coeli, laetare, alleluia, alleluia” (Queen of Heaven, rejoice, alleluia, alleluia). At song’s end, the little angel takes the Virgin’s veil and removes it to signify that the Virgin’s mourning has ended. Then, the angel is pulled back to “heaven” once more. Joyously, the two images then follow each other to the church, where Easter Sunday Mass is celebrated.

article.value: Many variations of the salubong are found in different regions. text:
San Roque, literally Saint Roch, refers to the festivities on the feast of San Roque, of Montpellier (lived ca. 1348-76). The saint worked during times of calamities and epidemics (especially cholera). Celebrated on Aug 16, these festivities may include a simple procession of the image of San Roque through the town streets, or a more elaborate procession of floats, depicting live tableaux of scenes from the life of San Roque, including, the birth of San Roque, his journey to Rome, his audience with the pope, and the lifting of his tunic so that the dog may lick his wounds. As San Roque’s statues are found in almost all churches in the country, so the festivities in his honor were popular in many Christianized provinces at the turn of the century and up to the outbreak of World War II. With the rise of better sanitation and the emphasis on health practices, cholera epidemics became a thing of the past, relegating the devotion to San Roque to the background.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
The sarsuwela is a play with music, which flourished in different Philippine provinces in the first two decades of this century. Also called zarzuela, sarsuela, sarswela, dulang inawitan, dulang hinonihan, drama lirico, and operetta, the Philippine sarsuwela is descended from the Spanish zarzuela brought to the Philippines from 1879 to the end of the century by actors and troupes from Spain, who performed popular plays of the day, like the 1851 Madrid hit Jugarcon Fuego (Playing with Fire) by Ventura de la Vega and El Barberillo de Lavapies (The Little Barber of Lavapies) by Luis Mariano de Larra, both with music by Francisco A. Barbieri.

Filipino artists were eventually trained in this form of popular Spanish theater, and such actors as Praxedes (Yeyeng) Fernandez, Patrocinio Tagaroma, Venancia Suzara, Nemesio Ratia, and Jose Carvajal gained fame, trodding both city and country stages. When the Teatro Zorrilla was inaugurated on 17 Aug 1893, it became the home of the zarzuela. Its inaugural presentation was Emilio and Rafael del Val’s El Diablo Mundo (The Devil’s World). With music by Jose Estella, Filipinos in its cast were Raguer, Suzara, and Barbero among others, and its setting was Madrid. This zarzuela was in one act and three cuadros (scenes), in prose and in verse, and was published in 1893.

 

The Spanish zarzuela that had come to the Philippines with Spanish actors in Spanish plays had thus moved to Filipino and Spanish actors in plays written in Spain, and then to Filipino and Spanish actors in plays written in the Philippines. The complete Filipinization of the form came when the sarsuwela unfolding the topics and concerns of Filipinos were written in Philippine languages. Among the first sarsuwela on record are Budhing Nagpahamak (Tragic Conscience), circa 1890, with libretto by an anonymous Bulacan playwright, and music by Isidoro Roxas; Norberto Romualdez’s Ang Pagtabang ni San Miguel (The Help of Saint Michael), a Waray sarsuwela first staged at a town fiesta in Leyte in 1899; Mariano Proceso Pabalan-Byron’s Ing Managpe (The Patcher), premiered at the Teatro Sabina in Bacolor, Pampanga, on 13 Sep 1900; Catalino Palisoc’s antifriar Say Liman ag Naketket, Pampinsioan (The Hand That Cannot Be Bitten Must Be Kissed) in Pangasinan in 1897, but staged only in 1901 after the American insular government had been established; Vicente Sotto’s Maputi ug Maitum (Fair and Dark), a three-act play in Cebuano written in 1902; Valente Cristobal’s Ang Capitan (The Captain) and Ang mga Viciohan (The Vice-Ridden), both first presented in Iloilo City in 1903; and Mena Pecson Crisologo’s plays in Ilocano Codigo Municipal (Municipal Code) and Meysa a Candidato (There Was a Candidate), both dated 1908.

The first step in the indigenization of the zarzuela was thus the language, and the subject matter followed naturally, being the experience the language could encapsulate, as reality coming from its own cultural matrix—or perhaps the desire to present this reality—forced the use of the native language. The sarsuwela focused on Filipino situations, domestic and social: marriage and family, elections and feasts, vices and values.

Many were one-act plays, vignettes of Philippine life modeled on the Spanish genero chico (Spanish one-act zarzuela); but major works of two, three, four, and five acts eventually burgeoned in almost every region. They were written in the local language, generally by a member of the community, for specific drama groups and even for specific singers. Being so directly focused on a concrete and real audience and its consciousness, they came to be comedies of manners and, eventually, social documentation and history.

Among the major Philippine sarsuwela are Severino Reyes’s Walang Sugat (Not Wounded), 1902, in Tagalog, about lovers separated by the cruelty of friars and the revolution against Spain; and Mena Pecson Crisologo’s Natakneng a Panagsalisal (Noble Rivalry), circa 1911, in Ilocano, about a couple who fall in love after having been both bereaved during the Philippine-American War. Juan Crisostomo Soto’s Alang Dios (There Is No God), 1902, staged in Pampanga, revolves around the story of a forced and abandoned marriage in a network of emotions and Filipino character types. Valente Cristobal’s Nating,1908, has the central figure kidnapped by a band of men farming in the mountains, and the situation serving as a test for herself and her three suitors.

Peak years for the sarsuwela were the 1920s, when it was not only staged at town fiestas in many provinces but also achieved a kind of professionalism. Troupes like Severino Reyes’s Gran Compañia dela Zarzuela Tagala and Hermogenes Ilagan’s Compañia Ilagan; stars like Atang dela Rama, undisputed “Queen of the Sarsuwela”; plays like Servando delos Angeles’s Ang Kiri (The Flirt), 1926, with 700 performances, and Hermogenes Ilagan’s Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), 1919, with more than 1,000 performances (both with music by Leon Ignacio); audiences in theaters like the Zorrilla and in open-air makeshift stages in the provinces, singing sarsuwela songs—all proved that this regnant drama form had caught the popular imagination because it reflected lived life and taught the profitable lessons people expected of it.

Light but didactic as it was, it did not become real social satire, although some plays touched on, caricatured, explored, and even exposed such social ills as the corruption and false promises of politicians, and the often cruel treatment by landlords and bosses of tenants, employees, and servants. In the plays’ heroes (strong, loving, and loyal) and heroines (modest, obedient, and virtuous) were reflected deeply held community values.

Around the plays grew a world of theater, and a theater of conventions. At fiestas, they were paid for by the comite de festejos (fiesta committee) and offered free to the public. Outside of fiestas, they were organized by the samahang sarsuwelista (sarsuwela groups) or by individuals (often the playwright) who directed, financed, organized, and made some profit. Low though the fees were then, they represented professional status for the actors, who were rewarded as well with respect and social prestige.

Music was composed by untrained or barely trained church or folk musicians, as well as by schooled and accomplished composers like Nicanor Abelardo. It was played by musicians and ensembles, ranging from single pianos or guitars, to orchestras of the size dictated by the group’s or town’s resources. According to Ramon Santos, this localization of musical forms served as the beginnings of new musical genres such as the kundiman (Tagalog love song). The backstage crew—the apuntador or prompter, the telonero who managed the painted backdrops, the director—came from the community.

The short period of the flowering of the sarsuwela did not give the form time to stretch its wings and develop with the changing times. Coming as it did at the junction of history when the Filipino emerged from his Spanish centuries and entered his American decades, the sarsuwela reflected in its inchoate realism, the reality of the transition.

However, even as the sarsuwela bowed out of the entablado (stage), it began to enjoy a new life on the silver screen. Capitalizing on the popularity of the sarsuwela, early film producers filmed sarsuwela hits like Dalagang Bukid, Ararong Ginto (Golden Plow), Ang Kiri,and Walang Sugat. At the same time, composers were commissioned by film producers to create songs for the filmed sarsuwela, which were later known as musicals.

In contemporary times, new sarsuwela have been written: Isagani R. Cruz’s Halimaw (Monster), 1971; Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio’s Ang Bundok (The Mountain) and Domingo Landicho’s Sumpang Mahal (Sacred Vow), both 1976; Nicanor G. Tiongson’s Pilipinas circa 1907 (Philippines circa 1907), 1982; pop musicals like Bienvenido Lumbera’s Bayani (Hero), 1970, and Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. (Plea and Revolt of Victoria Laktaw and Others), 1998; and Mario O’Hara’s Palasyo ni Valentin (Valentin’s Palace), 1998. They show the viability of the form, and its continuing appeal to the Filipino audience. They also suggest ways of updating and revitalization.

In 2009, the sarsuwela was brought back into the limelight by the College of Arts and Letters of the University of the Philippines Diliman through a monthlong Sarsuwela Festival with the theme “Amor, Vida, Patria” (Love, Life, and Nation). According to then dean Virgilio Almario, the festival was an attempt to establish the sarsuwela as a Philippine national theater form. Opening with a grand parade, the festival brought to light the art form’s contributions to Philippine history and culture through sarsuwela productions by various theater groups. The University of the East Drama Company performed Precioso Palma’s Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), 1920, with music by Leon Ignacio as directed by Frederick Castro. The Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation staged their rendition of the classic Walang Sugat with music by Fulgencio Tolentino. The Far Eastern University’s Art Theatre Clinique performed Julian Cruz Balmaseda’s Sa Bunganga ng Pating (At the Mercy of Sharks), 1921, directed by Joey Ting and with music by Leon Ignacio. The UP in the Visayas Alumni Theatre Company staged Ilo-Ilo Sarsuwela: Padayon ang Istorya (Ilo-Ilo Sarsuwela: The Story Continues), a sarsuwela directed by Alfredo Diaz, devised from five Visayan sarsuwelas: Dumut Cag Huya (Anger and Shame), 1912; Mga Anak ni Sisa (The Children ofSisa), 1926; Ma Pa Ta (Mother, Father, and Children), 1927; Sa Tiangge ni Takay (Takay’s Small Store), 1928; and Pinustahan nga Gugma (The Game of Love), 2000. Dulaang UP closed the performances with their version of Ang Kiri under the direction of Dexter Santos with music by Leon Ignacio.

The Sarsuwela Festival also hosted a conference whose papers discussed the history, production, and theories behind the sarsuwela. Some of the papers were later published in one volume of the Philippine Humanities Review. Similarly, a sarsuwela writing contest yielded one honorable mention entry, Ang Señorita at ang Hukbo (The Lady and the Soldier) by Bonifacio Ilagan with music by Lucien Letaba.   Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

According to then dean Virgilio Almario, the festival was an attempt to establish the sarsuwela as a Philippine national theater form. Opening with a grand parade, the festival brought to light the art form’s contributions to Philippine history and culture through sarsuwela productions by various theater groups. The University of the East Drama Company performed Precioso Palma’s Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), 1920, with music by Leon Ignacio as directed by Frederick Castro. The Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation staged their rendition of the classic Walang Sugat with music by Fulgencio Tolentino. The Far Eastern University’s Art Theatre Clinique performed Julian Cruz Balmaseda’s Sa Bunganga ng Pating (At the Mercy of Sharks), 1921, directed by Joey Ting and with music by Leon Ignacio. The UP in the Visayas Alumni Theatre Company staged Ilo-Ilo Sarsuwela: Padayon ang Istorya (Ilo-Ilo Sarsuwela: The Story Continues), a sarsuwela directed by Alfredo Diaz, devised from five Visayan sarsuwelas: Dumut Cag Huya (Anger and Shame), 1912; Mga Anak ni Sisa (The Children ofSisa), 1926; Ma Pa Ta (Mother, Father, and Children), 1927; Sa Tiangge ni Takay (Takay’s Small Store), 1928; and Pinustahan nga Gugma (The Game of Love), 2000. Dulaang UP closed the performances with their version of Ang Kiri under the direction of Dexter Santos with music by Leon Ignacio.

The Sarsuwela Festival also hosted a conference whose papers discussed the history, production, and theories behind the sarsuwela. Some of the papers were later published in one volume of the Philippine Humanities Review. Similarly, a sarsuwela writing contest yielded one honorable mention entry, Ang Señorita at ang Hukbo (The Lady and the Soldier) by Bonifacio Ilagan with music by Lucien Letaba.
Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

text:
A short entertainment piece, usually farcical, used as a curtain raiser, intermission number or interlude in longer plays (e.g., a komedya), is called saynete or sainete. Both the name and the form come from the Spanish sainete, which in Spain usually lasted about 20 minutes, had from 6 to 10 characters, and offered an entertaining slice of Madrid life between the second and third acts of a play. Although also called entremes or intermedio, the saynete is a bit longer and meatier than the entremes, since it purposes to convey an aral or lesson as well as to entertain.

The Filipino version may be a farce in verse or in prose, may have music, and may speak of ordinary and real people and situations—usually with a view to teaching a lesson through humorous means. This might be about the evils of debt and vice or about the consequences of whimsical or disobedient behavior, or about the impossibility of buying love with money or authority (power).

The first example in print was Francisco de P. Entrala’s Cuadros Filipinos (Philippine Scenes), 1882, in which he humorously portrays local ways of courtship and theater. It is set in Divisoria, where a komedya is to be staged, and where Juancho, who is married to Candida and loved by Nicolasa, woos Fuensanta, a cigarette vendor also wooed by Panchito, who plays a Christian king in the night’s komedya. Confusions ensue on and off stage, until the curtain is brought down with a pandanggo .Since Entrala was a Spaniard, the Tagalog audience took Cuadros as an insult rather than with humor, and rejected both work and author.

A success then and now has been Francisco Baltazar’s La India Elegante y el Negrito Amante (The Elegant India and Her Aeta Suitor), 1857-60, which Balagtas is said to have based on incidents around him . Tomeng, an itang tagabundok (Aeta from the mountain), has been courting the unresponsive Menangge, a tagabayan (a girl from the town), and has tried all manner of costume (Chinese, Tagalog, Moro, Spanish), to no avail. He scorns her way of looking at “ang balat, hindi ang laman” (the skin, not the flesh), and finally wins her, singing:

Sa pagsinta’y walang hindi sumusuko

ang lalong mailap ay napapaamo,

ang tigreng mabangis na uhaw sa dugo

daig ng pag-ibig at napasusuyo.

 

(Everyone yields to love

the wildest one is tamed,

the fierce tiger hungry for blood

is won by love and comes a-courting.)

Its charm comes both from the wiles Tomeng uses, and from the aral about loving the person rather than his trappings.

The saynete thus represents the short entertainment before or within a longer play, which is not improvised, but especially written to encapsulate a lesson within a slice of ordinary life. It is meant as a pampaalis suya, a change of flavor, relieving the length of a komedya, treating of ordinary or even low characters in song and dance, verse or prose.

With the advent of film, radio, and other forms of media, as well as other forms of theater, the long-winded komedya declined and the saynete along with it, giving way to shorter plays that ran for two to three hours. But saynete did not die, but rather reappeared in comic episodes in the sarsuwela, bodabil, and even radio, film, and television.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

text:
Siete palabras —literally, “seven words” in Spanish—dramatizes Christ’s last three hours of suffering on the cross, when he says the Seven Last Words.

In Catholic churches, the focus of this custom is usually the life-size wooden image of Christ (with moveable head and arms), nailed on the cross erected in front of the main altar on a platform covered with alagaw leaves and flanked by the crucified images of Dimas on Jesus’s right and Gestas on his left. Sometimes the images of the Mater Dolorosa (the Sorrowful Mother) and San Juan are made to stand, or are parked on their karo (floats), on Christ’s rightand left, respectively.

From 12:00 noon to 3:00 pm, a priest/priests or lay persons deliver homilies on each of Christ’s words, leading the congregation in prayer after each homily. As each of the Seven Words is spoken, the head of the Christ image moves (strings are pulled from behind the cross) even as thunder rolls (drums or galvanized iron sheets are struck continuously) and lightning strikes (liquid gas is blown into a candle; or sunlight caught by a mirror flashing onto the image from outside the church’s main door; or fireworks exploding beside the cross). At three o’clock, the Christ image drops its head “in death,” amidst a frenzy of thunder and lightning, as many shed tears. After this electrifying moment, two males, costumed as Nicodemus and Joseph of Arimathea, ascend two ladders leaning on the two sides of the back of the cross, and slowly remove, in sequence, the INRI, the crown of thorns, and the nails. Then with a white shroud swathed across Christ’s breast and armpits (the image’s arms are movable), they slowly lower the body down to the assistants, who then lay it out on a stretcher and cover it with a white/red blanket. After this, the body is laid out on a catafalque surrounded by four candles, in front of the altar mayor (high altar) and/or the central aisle. During the “wake,” the faithful line up to wipe and kiss the hands and feet of Christ and drop coins into a donation box. Later, the same image is laid in the glass coffin on top of a karo for the procession of the Santo Entierro (Holy Burial) in the evening.

 

Many variations of the siete palabras exist. In Betis, Pampanga, the crosses are erected on a little hill located beside the church and Christ’s “body” is brought in procession around one block into the church. In Santa Rita, Pampanga, the image of Christ used to be taken down and laid on the lap of a woman dressed as the Virgin, who declaims some lines in the attitude of the Pieta. In Buhi, Camarines Sur, a middle-aged woman, dressed in white and black, chants a moving lamentation over the body of Christ laid out on a stretcher, using the words of Mary in the Pasyong Bicol as she weeps over the wounds and hair of her dead Son. In most towns, after Christ’s body is taken down, the faithful rush to collect the alagaw leaves, which are considered medicinal.

Because the siete palabras is familiar to all Christian Filipinos, artists interested in social change have reinterpreted Christ’s words according to contemporary political and economic realities. In Al Santos’s Kalbaryo ng Maralitang Tagalungsod (Calvary of the Urban Poor), 1988-92, each of the Seven Words is related to an urgent issue relating to the urban poor, both by huge murals framed and mounted on jeepneys for the long and winding procession, as well as by the street drama where the 13 Christs (who wear huge papier-mâché masks modeled after the face of the Quiapo Nazarene) use each of the Seven Words to answer the seven accusations of the three Pilates. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
Sinakulo or senakulo, from Spanish cenaculo, meaning “cenacle” or “supper room,” is a play presented during the Lenten season and especially during Holy Week, which dramatizes the history of salvation—from the creation of the world, Adam and Eve, and Cain and Abel, to the life and passion, death and resurrection of Jesus Christ. Probably begun in the 18th century and already popular by the 19th century, the passion play is known by many names and versions: as sinakulo or pasion y muerte, from Spanish “passion and death,” in Rizal, Bulacan, Pampanga, and Pangasinan; as kalbaryuhan, from Tagalog “play on Calvary,” in Marinduque; as centurion, from Spanish centurion, and hudyo-hudyuhan, from Tagalog “playing at Jews,” in Paete, Laguna; as tanggal, from Bikol “deposition,” in Camarines Sur; as taltal or pagtaltal from Ilonggo “crucifixion,” in Guimaras and Negros Occidental; and as senakulo in Leyte.

Starting out as a dramatization of the 1814 Pasyong Genesis, which starts with the creation of the world and ends with the search for the cross by Elena and Constantino, the contemporary sinakulo orihinal or script has added lines and scenes from other pasyon (e.g., the Pasyong Candaba and Pasyong Truncalis); from the New Testament; from religious novels like El Martir del Golgotha by Enrique Perez Escrich (translated into Tagalog by Juan Evangelista); from the awit and korido or metrical tales (e.g., the Tatlong Haring Magos, Sagrada Familia,and Quince Misterios );from the religious playlets (e.g., the panunuluyan, osana, and salubong); from popular magazines (e.g., the Liwayway); from movies (e.g., The Ten Commandments, 1956, The Robe, 1953, and Quo Vadis, 1951); and other sinakulo. Sometimes an awtor (author) may create his own scenes, characters, and dialogue.

 

The sinakulo is presented any time from Ash Wednesday to Easter Sunday, either on different nights in different teatro (theaters) by commercial troupes, or on Holy Week by barrio-based samahan (organizations) in front of the barrio chapel (sometimes the latter may also be contracted commercially for performances outside their barrio). Shorter scenes of the sinakulomay also be presented on the streets of the barrio on Holy Thursday, like the centurion of Paete, Laguna; or on Good Friday, like the grand penitensiya of Cainta, Rizal, the pagdakip of Malolos, Bulacan, and the senakulo of Cutud, San Fernando, Pampanga, where devotees playing Christ are crucified with real nails.

The entablado or stage of the sinakulo is usually a rectangular platform about five feet high and made of wooden planks or of cement, generally divided by a permanent backdrop and bamboo frame into the acting area in front and the dressing area at the back.

 

Entablado posts support a row of bamboo/wooden frames from which are hung the various telon or backdrops. Samples of these telones are the telon de boca or front curtain, which masks scene changes; the telon de fondo,which separates the dressing from the acting area and is usually painted with clouds and angels; the telon natural,often painted with a typical tropical landscape with trees, fields, and mountains for scenes of travel; the telon palacio, usually showing the interior of a palace for scenes of Annas, Caiphas, Herod, and Pilate; and the telon bundok, depicting mountain peaks for scenes of Christ’s recollection, transfiguration, and crucifixion. Bastidor or flats are hung or stood on either side of the stage to mask lateral exits and entrances, while bambalina or short curtains hang from the ceiling to conceal the lights and rolled-up telon.

 

Props are often functional but anachronistic, like pansit (noodles) on plastic plates and Coca-Cola in bottles for the Last Supper, a plastic basin for the washing of the feet, and a papag (bamboo bed) for the Virgin’sdeath. Most sinakulo are now lighted by naked electric bulbs orby sophisticated, computerized lighting gadgets, while microphones—hanging, standing, or lapel—are used in town and country. The direktor are the unquestioned masters of the sinakulo. They teach young and old alike how to chant the punto or chanted melody proper to a character, how to deliver their lines in the correct dicho,how to make the various mustra or gestures and aksiyon or actions. They keep the orihinal (script) and, as apuntador or prompters during performances, feed each line to all the characters; blow the whistle to signify to the band of musikero what kind of march (slow punebre or fast paso doble) to play for exits and entrances; liaise with sponsors and barrio leaders who support the sinakulo; act as chief counselor for all problems—personal or professional; and pull together the work of the persons in charge of the backdrops, the props, the band, and all other assistants.

Actors who act for commercial troupes are paid per performance, while those who act for the barrio do so in fulfillment of a panata or holy vow. Acting styles of the sinakulo are of two types: the style for the Kristo and the banal (the holy ones), who march to slow punebre beat, chant their lines in lamenting fashion, and move their hands and headswith meekness and humility; and the style for the hudyo (Jews), who swagger to the paso doble beat, sing ordeliver lines snappily, and act proud and fierce.

In general, sinakulo characters are costumed like the images of Lenten processions: Christ in maroon velvet with gold embroidery, wearing white lace around His neck and wrists, a brunette wig, and three tin rays called potensiya;the Virgin in a blue and purple gown with a white or purple veil tucked under a rostrillo (thin rays around her face), and the heart with seven daggers traced in sequins on her breast; San Juan in red and green; San Pedro in green and yellow; Magdalene in purple and yellow; and Veronica in blue and white. Characters without corresponding images in church may be dressed by the folk imagination, thus Claudia, Herod’s wife, in the Philippine Carnival Queen’s terno with train, collar, and crown; Barabbas in knee-length pants, a T-shirt, and balanggot (farmer’s hat); and Roman soldiers in knee-length salawal (pants) and puff-sleeved, waisted shirts, with Viking headgear and Roman helmets as seen in various movies.

Important for all sinakulo are the artipisyo (artifices), which create special effects like galaxies of stars, suns, and moons that come in and out of the stage on a mechanism of strings and pulleys at the Creation of the World; special fireworks for the Resurrection; and machines to raise the Virgin up to heaven for the scene of the Assumption.

The staging of the sinakulo may be as basic as the kalbaryuhan, the Marinduque dramatization of the pasyon, which is as basic as it is charming (e.g., to portray the Three Kings, three old men in civilian clothes don farmer’s hats garlanded with bougainvillea blooms) or as technically sophisticated as the sinakulo of Cainta, Rizal, which has hundreds of spots and dimmers, boulders that roll aside to reveal the resurrected Christ, and a heavenly sky studded with the cherubic heads of real children on wings that actually flap.

In recent years, the shortened sinakulo of Barrio Cutud in San Fernando, Pampanga, has attracted hordes of local and foreign tourists. Here, on Good Friday, devotees fulfill their panata or vow to undergo physical suffering to ask God for personal favors or to thank him for blessings received. The ritual begins with devotees flagellating themselves and then carrying the cross, and culminates in the reenactment of the crucifixion, where the devotee playing Christ is stripped of his robe down to a piece of cloth that hides his nakedness and laid on the cross on which he is nailed with actual long construction nails. Then the cross and devotee are raised to stand from the ground for all to see for a few minutes, after which other devotees may also have themselves nailed to the cross in fulfillment of their own vows (Tiatco 2006). This type of crucifixion of devotees in fulfillment of religious vows has been practiced for many decades in Kapitangan, Paombong, Bulacan, where both male and female Christs are literally nailed to the cross on Good Friday.

Today, the full-length sinakulo survives in towns and places where the community or community organizations have taken over the play and supported it with generous funding. It has disappeared, however, in many other places, either because industrialization has turned farmers into workers who now no longer have time for the sinakulo, or because modernization and mass media have successfully robbed the sinakulo of its avid audiences and participants.

As the traditional sinakulo dramatizes the struggle of good and evil and the final triumph of the good, so the modern sinakulo now dramatizes the struggle between classes and sectors in Philippine society. Earliest of the modern passion plays is Aurelio V. Tolentino’s Bagong Cristo (New Christ), 1907, a “drama socialista” (socialist drama) that portrays Christ as the labor leader organizing city and countryside workers to demand better wages from factory owners and landlords. In 1977, Christ was likewise interpreted by the Dulaang Babaylan Sinakulo as a farmer whose cross is the plow and whose oppressors are landlords and capitalists (the modern Annas, Caiaphas, and Herod). In 1983, Virgilio Vitug’s Sinakulo Ning Balen (Passion Play of the Country), presented in Lubao, Pampanga, exposed fiscals who can be bribed to dismiss capital crimes, fake overseas recruiters who victimize helpless peasants, and candle sellers who commercialize religion. Here Jesus Macabalen dies, but his struggle for justice is carried on by teachers, workers, farmers, and the ethnic minorities. In 1988, an organization of the urban poor in Manila produced Al Santos’s Kalbaryo ng Maralitang Tagalungsod (Calvary of the Urban Poor), and staged its first scene on Smokey Mountain and then marched to Mendiola, where the 13 Christs (representing 13 organizations of the urban poor) wearing huge masks inspired by the face of the Quiapo Nazareno were accused of seven sins/infractions of urban law by the three Pilates who represent the establishment. After the Christs were condemned to carry the cross, the procession, which also featured seven huge murals interpreting Christ’s Seven Last Words according to contemporary social realities, moved on to Quiapo where the crucifixion was held. To this day, the passion of Christ continues to be interpreted by many progressive groups according to the social issues and concerns of the times.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

article.value: Starting out as a dramatization of the 1814 Pasyong Genesis, which starts with the creation of the world and ends with the search for the cross by Elena and Constantino, the contemporary sinakulo orihinal or script has added lines and scenes from other pasyon (e.g., the Pasyong Candaba and Pasyong Truncalis); from the New Testament; from religious novels like El Martir del Golgotha by Enrique Perez Escrich (translated into Tagalog by Juan Evangelista); from the awit and korido or metrical tales (e.g., the Tatlong Haring Magos, Sagrada Familia,and Quince Misterios );from the religious playlets (e.g., the panunuluyan, osana, and salubong); from popular magazines (e.g., the Liwayway); from movies (e.g., The Ten Commandments, 1956, The Robe, 1953, and Quo Vadis, 1951); and other sinakulo. Sometimes an awtor (author) may create his own scenes, characters, and dialogue.

article.value: The sinakulo is presented any time from Ash Wednesday to Easter Sunday, either on different nights in different teatro (theaters) by commercial troupes, or on Holy Week by barrio-based samahan (organizations) in front of the barrio chapel (sometimes the latter may also be contracted commercially for performances outside their barrio). Shorter scenes of the sinakulomay also be presented on the streets of the barrio on Holy Thursday, like the centurion of Paete, Laguna; or on Good Friday, like the grand penitensiya of Cainta, Rizal, the pagdakip of Malolos, Bulacan, and the senakulo of Cutud, San Fernando, Pampanga, where devotees playing Christ are crucified with real nails.

The entablado or stage of the sinakulo is usually a rectangular platform about five feet high and made of wooden planks or of cement, generally divided by a permanent backdrop and bamboo frame into the acting area in front and the dressing area at the back.

article.value: Entablado posts support a row of bamboo/wooden frames from which are hung the various telon or backdrops. Samples of these telones are the telon de boca or front curtain, which masks scene changes; the telon de fondo,which separates the dressing from the acting area and is usually painted with clouds and angels; the telon natural,often painted with a typical tropical landscape with trees, fields, and mountains for scenes of travel; the telon palacio, usually showing the interior of a palace for scenes of Annas, Caiphas, Herod, and Pilate; and the telon bundok, depicting mountain peaks for scenes of Christ’s recollection, transfiguration, and crucifixion. Bastidor or flats are hung or stood on either side of the stage to mask lateral exits and entrances, while bambalina or short curtains hang from the ceiling to conceal the lights and rolled-up telon.

article.value: Props are often functional but anachronistic, like pansit (noodles) on plastic plates and Coca-Cola in bottles for the Last Supper, a plastic basin for the washing of the feet, and a papag (bamboo bed) for the Virgin’sdeath. Most sinakulo are now lighted by naked electric bulbs orby sophisticated, computerized lighting gadgets, while microphones—hanging, standing, or lapel—are used in town and country. The direktor are the unquestioned masters of the sinakulo. They teach young and old alike how to chant the punto or chanted melody proper to a character, how to deliver their lines in the correct dicho,how to make the various mustra or gestures and aksiyon or actions. They keep the orihinal (script) and, as apuntador or prompters during performances, feed each line to all the characters; blow the whistle to signify to the band of musikero what kind of march (slow punebre or fast paso doble) to play for exits and entrances; liaise with sponsors and barrio leaders who support the sinakulo; act as chief counselor for all problems—personal or professional; and pull together the work of the persons in charge of the backdrops, the props, the band, and all other assistants.

Actors who act for commercial troupes are paid per performance, while those who act for the barrio do so in fulfillment of a panata or holy vow. Acting styles of the sinakulo are of two types: the style for the Kristo and the banal (the holy ones), who march to slow punebre beat, chant their lines in lamenting fashion, and move their hands and headswith meekness and humility; and the style for the hudyo (Jews), who swagger to the paso doble beat, sing ordeliver lines snappily, and act proud and fierce.

In general, sinakulo characters are costumed like the images of Lenten processions: Christ in maroon velvet with gold embroidery, wearing white lace around His neck and wrists, a brunette wig, and three tin rays called potensiya;the Virgin in a blue and purple gown with a white or purple veil tucked under a rostrillo (thin rays around her face), and the heart with seven daggers traced in sequins on her breast; San Juan in red and green; San Pedro in green and yellow; Magdalene in purple and yellow; and Veronica in blue and white. Characters without corresponding images in church may be dressed by the folk imagination, thus Claudia, Herod’s wife, in the Philippine Carnival Queen’s terno with train, collar, and crown; Barabbas in knee-length pants, a T-shirt, and balanggot (farmer’s hat); and Roman soldiers in knee-length salawal (pants) and puff-sleeved, waisted shirts, with Viking headgear and Roman helmets as seen in various movies.

Important for all sinakulo are the artipisyo (artifices), which create special effects like galaxies of stars, suns, and moons that come in and out of the stage on a mechanism of strings and pulleys at the Creation of the World; special fireworks for the Resurrection; and machines to raise the Virgin up to heaven for the scene of the Assumption.

The staging of the sinakulo may be as basic as the kalbaryuhan, the Marinduque dramatization of the pasyon, which is as basic as it is charming (e.g., to portray the Three Kings, three old men in civilian clothes don farmer’s hats garlanded with bougainvillea blooms) or as technically sophisticated as the sinakulo of Cainta, Rizal, which has hundreds of spots and dimmers, boulders that roll aside to reveal the resurrected Christ, and a heavenly sky studded with the cherubic heads of real children on wings that actually flap.

In recent years, the shortened sinakulo of Barrio Cutud in San Fernando, Pampanga, has attracted hordes of local and foreign tourists. Here, on Good Friday, devotees fulfill their panata or vow to undergo physical suffering to ask God for personal favors or to thank him for blessings received. The ritual begins with devotees flagellating themselves and then carrying the cross, and culminates in the reenactment of the crucifixion, where the devotee playing Christ is stripped of his robe down to a piece of cloth that hides his nakedness and laid on the cross on which he is nailed with actual long construction nails. Then the cross and devotee are raised to stand from the ground for all to see for a few minutes, after which other devotees may also have themselves nailed to the cross in fulfillment of their own vows (Tiatco 2006). This type of crucifixion of devotees in fulfillment of religious vows has been practiced for many decades in Kapitangan, Paombong, Bulacan, where both male and female Christs are literally nailed to the cross on Good Friday.

Today, the full-length sinakulo survives in towns and places where the community or community organizations have taken over the play and supported it with generous funding. It has disappeared, however, in many other places, either because industrialization has turned farmers into workers who now no longer have time for the sinakulo, or because modernization and mass media have successfully robbed the sinakulo of its avid audiences and participants.

As the traditional sinakulo dramatizes the struggle of good and evil and the final triumph of the good, so the modern sinakulo now dramatizes the struggle between classes and sectors in Philippine society. Earliest of the modern passion plays is Aurelio V. Tolentino’s Bagong Cristo (New Christ), 1907, a “drama socialista” (socialist drama) that portrays Christ as the labor leader organizing city and countryside workers to demand better wages from factory owners and landlords. In 1977, Christ was likewise interpreted by the Dulaang Babaylan Sinakulo as a farmer whose cross is the plow and whose oppressors are landlords and capitalists (the modern Annas, Caiaphas, and Herod). In 1983, Virgilio Vitug’s Sinakulo Ning Balen (Passion Play of the Country), presented in Lubao, Pampanga, exposed fiscals who can be bribed to dismiss capital crimes, fake overseas recruiters who victimize helpless peasants, and candle sellers who commercialize religion. Here Jesus Macabalen dies, but his struggle for justice is carried on by teachers, workers, farmers, and the ethnic minorities. In 1988, an organization of the urban poor in Manila produced Al Santos’s Kalbaryo ng Maralitang Tagalungsod (Calvary of the Urban Poor), and staged its first scene on Smokey Mountain and then marched to Mendiola, where the 13 Christs (representing 13 organizations of the urban poor) wearing huge masks inspired by the face of the Quiapo Nazareno were accused of seven sins/infractions of urban law by the three Pilates who represent the establishment. After the Christs were condemned to carry the cross, the procession, which also featured seven huge murals interpreting Christ’s Seven Last Words according to contemporary social realities, moved on to Quiapo where the crucifixion was held. To this day, the passion of Christ continues to be interpreted by many progressive groups according to the social issues and concerns of the times.
Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
Soledad, meaning “solitude” or “loneliness” in Spanish, is a late-night procession that depicts the loneliness of the Virgin Mary after she buries her son, Jesus. After the Good Friday procession of the Santo Entierro or Holy Burial, the image of the Mater Dolorosa or Sorrowful Mother in black comes out of the church at about 10:00 pm, preceded by the images of San Pedro, Maria Jacobe, Maria Salome, Maria Magdalena, and San Juan (also in mourning clothes), and accompanied by a brass band, or, as in Baao, Camarines Sur, an estudiantina or group of young students wearing cardboard tricorne (three-cornered) hats playing brass and percussion (including panderetas) instruments.

As it winds its sorrowful way around town, the Virgin’s karo (float) stops in front of designated houses, from whose windows or balconies young women sing the “Ave Maria” and other songs in Latin or Spanish to ease the pain and grief of the Virgin. After stopping at about 10 houses, the procession ends up in church after midnight.

 

In some towns, there are no bands, no songs or other images. There is only the image of a grieving Mary “roaming” the dark streets of the town, in absolute and painful silence. The soledad may also be held on Black Saturday, with the procession ending a few hours before the salubong or Easter Sunday morning. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
Stand-up comedy is a theater form that features a comedian, also called a comic, stand-up comic, stand-up comedian, or simply stand-up, performing in front of a live audience, usually speaking directly to them. Usually called a monologue, routine, or act, the material presented is composed of humorous stories, jokes, and one-liners. Stand-up comedy is commonly performed in comedy clubs, bars, and small theaters.

Stand-up comedy is one of the legacies of the American occupation of the Philippines. After the Philippine-American War, along with the establishment of the Insular Government of the Philippine Islands, came the unimpeded Americanization of the Philippines, which included the onslaught of the teaching Thomasites, English as the medium of instruction, and the invasion of American commercial culture. Rather swiftly, vaudeville, later known as bodabil or stage show, replaced the traditional Filipino sarsuwela as the primary form of live theater in the islands and became the much-welcomed jazzed up entertainment for the elite and the masses.

 

American-type bodabil acts were first performed by visiting troupes in sarsuwela venues such as the famous Teatro Zorrilla. During the beginnings of the “Jazz Age” from 1920 to 1929, a Filipino entertainer named Luis Borromeo returned from North America in 1921, renamed himself “Borromeo Lou,” dubbed the emerging theater form “vod-a-vil” (later Filipinized into “bodabil”) and, subsequently, organized what became the first Filipino bodabil company.

The popularity of bodabil was not confined to Manila stages; it also kept the audiences entertained in fiestas and carnivals with stage show routines: musical numbers (songs and social dances), acrobatic acts, dramatic sketches, magic acts, and, very likely, the comic monologist/humorist or duo—the precursor of the modern stand-up comedian. The Filipinos were quick to appropriate the variety show elements of bodabil, including the American theater circuit system of having live performances in between the screening of films.

Through the years, in contemporary variety format incarnations, live shows inevitably highlighted the bodabil quick-hit and interactive crowd-pleaser in modern dress: the stand-up comedian/host, a curious mix of part-bodabil monologist, and part burlesque emcee. The stand-up/comic monologue was a new performing art showcasing a solo comedian who, without props or costuming, and using only his wit, his mouth, and his worldview, directly addressed an audience and attempted to make them laugh. In a sense, it was a comic solo; a verbal “tightrope act” where, in showbiz parlance, the inevitable outcome for the comedian is to either “kill” (become a hit) or “bomb” (fail, or “die”).

Filipinos lapped up the new form and mirrored the Americans’ penchant for satire, applauding the unique point of view and comedic flair, especially in not-so-subtle digs at everything political or social through seemingly off-the-cuff casual humor. To this day, traveling comedians in the Philippines performing in town fiestas on makeshift stage platforms, town halls, and even cockpits echo comedy routines that can be traced in one form or another to turn-of-the century bodabil.

The burlesque mold triumphed with stand-up comedians, and singer-comedians (who offered a double treat) were expected to keep the crowds entertained and cackling, from the time of the Japanese occupation in 1941-45 to the disco decade of the 1970s—from Pugo and Togo to Dolphy, Chiquito to Bert Marcelo, Apeng Daldal to Babalu, Chichay to Mitch Valdes, and Pepe Pimentel to Rico Puno. The expectations remained the same for generations of Filipino audiences who flocked to familiar venues: from the Manila Opera House to the Gala Theater; from Clover Theater to Cusco Lounge; and from Rizal Theater to the Folk Arts Theater.

In the late 1970s, Filipino audiences gradually embraced the modern concept of American style stand-up comedy, ostensibly inspired by the success of filmed stand-up comedy specials in the United States, among them the legendary Eddie Murphy, Robin Williams, Lenny Bruce, Steve Martin, and Whoopi Goldberg. However, these were martial law years in the Philippines; what blossomed on performance venues was radically different from the classic American stand-up culture. There was none of the improvised, one-mic setup, brick wall, and at least 10 minutes of hopefully inspired madness.

What emerged in the local version was more of a hybrid: a theatricalized monologist showcase (“dressed up stand-up”) most of the time, with scripted anthologies of riotous comedy sketches, such as Mitch Valdes and Nanette Inventor’s highly successful Tit-for Tat, or Allan K. and Lenard Obal in the long-running Nura at Velma (Nura and Velma). It could also be hilarious celebrity drag parodies by Jon Santos (as “Star for All Seasons” Vilma Santos), politically savvy satire dished out by Tessie Tomas (as Imelda Marcos-inspired Meldita), or the standout comic impersonations by critically acclaimed comedian Willie Nepomuceno (as President Ferdinand Marcos, or iconic comedian Dolphy).

With the advent of the 1980s, the unexpected game-changer turned out to be Andrew de Real of Malate’s The Library, a hole-in-the wall sing-along bar near the famous Remedios Circle. In 1986, de Real’s comedy club ideas and the varied talents of his sing-along master/hosts and stand-up comedians (Allan K, Arnell Ignacio, Ai Ai de las Alas, Vice Ganda, et al.) provided the impetus for an alternative comedy revolution. The result was a hybrid, a marriage of the traditional gay bar variety show with an aggressively audience-interactive and decidedly burlesque-oriented karaoke bar culture where sexual humor, politics, and religion were no longer sacred cows. The success of The Library spawned several other karaoke comedy clubs, such as Punchline, Laffline, Klownz, and Zirkoh where social satire, often criticized as confrontational and abrasive, reigned supreme. The signature Library humor was pushing the envelope, as it were, expanding both language and boundaries close to bursting.

In attempts to deviate from the “new normal” in stand-up comedy set by The Library, other groups cropped up to offer a new comedy form alternative. After TV actor Gabe Mercado trained with legendary Second City founder Paul Sills at the Wisconsin Theater Games Center, he came back to the Philippines in 2002 to form SPIT (Silly People’s Improv Theater). The company, composed of thespians, teachers, commercial models, and professionals from varied fields, packed audiences in entertainment spots throughout Metro Manila and has been a staple of corporate functions for the last 12 years. Other improv groups came along, such as the Bacolod-based Kinenkoy, Comedy Express, Kidlat, Comedy Cebu (the only Filipino and international point-of-view stand-up comedy group in Cebu), and the Philippine Players. They achieved relative success in the elite fringes of Philippine entertainment.

In 2003, ace comedians Jon Santos and Candy Pangilinan, along with some investors, formed The Comfort Room Bar in Makati in a concerted effort to offer shows more cerebral than “the usual sex-oriented jokes, insulting comedy acts and crass impersonations.” With Jon and Candy as regular Main Acts, Comfort Room featured stand-up acts such as Rex Navarrete and Tim Tayag, and improv groups such as Gabe Mercado’s SPIT, the Philippine Playhouse Players, and the Big Bang Cheery. Unfortunately, Comfort Room closed after a year.

It was in 2007 that Tim Tayag and Allan Manalo founded The Comedy Cartel, described as “a guild of professional comic artists whose aim is to expand and master the art of comedy beyond the usual definitions through the practice of the classic monologue form of standup and through sketch comedy.” Comedy Cartel aims to offer Pinoy comedy in a more professional, artistic, and essentially dignifying avenue. More to the point, to Patrick Cruz, manager of Comedy Cartel, the aim is to become Asia’s comedy central. Navarrete, Tayag, and Manalo were based in the United States, where they performed stand-up acts in a number of clubs and other venues.

To attain this objective, Comedy Cartel tries to instill in each artist, professionalism, mastery, and respect for the art of comedy by providing training and building resources to further the craft. In this regard, they hold regular competitions and workshops for the group’s talents, which underscores Comedy Cartel’s role as the country’s only point-of-view stand-up comedy group. Outreach activities in the past include its first ever Stand-Up Comedy Campus Tour in 2011.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson
