text:
Street theater refers to theater performed mainly on the streets or in open air and outside the theater structure or building, and without the entablado or elevated stage area. Ethnic rituals, songs, and dances enacted in backyards, riverbanks, and rice fields, and the Spanish-influenced religious plays performed in the streets may be considered as street theater, as well as the political theater performed in the street from the late 1960s to the 2010s.

Open-Air Indigenous Performances. Rituals, through the centuries and to the present, have been performed for various purposes, such as healing the sick, a good harvest, hunting, and rites of passage. These rituals, usually led by the babaylan, also called baylan or shaman, and participated in by the community, are performed in backyards, open fields, riverbanks, and seashores. In the atang-atang healing ritual of Isabela performed near a river, two women dance around a small raft filled with offerings. The raft is then set afloat. To give thanks for a bountiful harvest, Bukidnon groups perform the hinaklaran, erecting a shelf of bamboo and dongla in an open field. The shelf is laden with offerings of betel nut, rice wine, cakes, candles, and red cloth pleasing to the gods.

 

Mimetic dances, considered as proto-dramas, may depict important tribal activities, imitate the movements of animals, or dramatize episodes from the epic of the tribe. Among the Badjao, the silat (also called by this name along with kuntao, lima, and pansak among the Tausug and Sama), which enacts fierce fights, is performed out at sea on a boat or by the seashore. In a dance of the Camarines Aeta, a woman goes to a stream to “dig” and gather gabi (taro), represented by round stones.

Hispanic Plays on the Streets. During the Spanish colonial period, religious plays were introduced, performed mainly during the Christmas and Lenten seasons.

The search for an inn by Mary and Joseph is reenacted in the panunuluyan, done on the town’s streets during Christmas Eve. It has many versions: the scene may be played by two singers; the singers and a brass band may accompany the images of the saints on top of two karo or floats, as in Malolos, Bulacan; or the actors may ride on floats, accompanied by 13 other floats featuring characters from the Bible, as in the Kawit maytinis. Leaving the church at around seven in the evening, the procession goes to about three or more houses in different parts of the barrio, where the performers stop to sing a mournful plea. Shortly before midnight Mass, the couple returns to the church where they ascend the stairs to a Bethlehem scene on the altar.

The pastores, which dramatizes the shepherds’ adoration of the Infant Jesus, used to be performed during Christmas on stage or the church patio in Cavite and Bulacan. It is performed today in Bicol by “shepherdesses” dancing and singing Spanish villancicos and Bikol carols on the street in front of different houses.

 

The entry of Christ into Jerusalem on Palm Sunday, reenacted in the osana, is performed in most Catholic and Aglipayan parishes in the country. The ritual begins inside the church, where the priest blesses the palm fronds. The priest then leads the procession of the “apostles” through the streets into the patio where a kubol, an elevated wooden balcony, stands on each corner. Young girls in white sing while showering flower petals on the priest as he walks to each kubol. The procession then goes back to the church where the priest has to rap on the closed door three times before all can enter.

In the via crucis held during the seven days of Lent, the candle procession starts from the church at about five or six in the afternoon and proceeds to the church patio or the town’s main streets. The procession winds through the streets of the town, stopping at each of the 14 estasyon (Stations of the Cross) for prayers and a brief reflection. The procession then goes back to the church after about three hours.

The loneliness of the Virgin Mary after she buries her son, Jesus, is depicted in the soledad. The image of the Mater Dolorosa (Sorrowful Mother) comes out of the church after the Good Friday procession of the Santo Entierro, and goes around the streets of the town, accompanied by images of San Pedro, Maria, Jacobe, Maria Salome, Maria Magdalena, and San Juan. The Virgin’s karo stops in front of designated houses, where young women sing to her from a window or a balcony.

In the salubong, which dramatizes the meeting of the Mater Dolorosa and the Risen Christ, two processions start from opposite ends of town at the crack of dawn on Easter Sunday. The two processions wind through the streets on opposite sides of town, then meet outside the church in a space called galilea, a colorful four-posted structure of bamboo and cement in the open air. Here, the sayaw ng pagbati (dance of greeting) is performed before the aleluya (singing of angels). It is a celebratory ritual dance where dancers wave flags for the Virgin Mary, to transform the Virgin Mary’s lumbay (sorrow) to galak (joy).There are many bati (greeting) versions danced in the Philippines.

The moriones, a playlet about the beheading of the Roman soldier and first Christian martyr Longhino, is performed in the towns of Boac, Gasan, Mogpog, and Santa Cruz in Marinduque during Good Friday. The traditional pugutan (beheading) featured the search for Longhino through the town’s streets, up coconut trees, and on the seashore. However, a stage and its adjacent grounds has been used since the 1970s when the playlet was replaced by a longer scripted play, although the chase of Longhino is still performed on the streets of the town.

The sinakulo, staged during the Holy Week, dramatizes the life and sufferings of Jesus Christ. Today, it continues to be performed by the barrio-based samahan or organization in front of the barrio chapel in the open air, while short scenes of the sinakulo may also be presented on the streets of the barrio like the centurion of Paete, Laguna, performed during Holy Thursday; the grand penitensiya of Cainta, Rizal, performed on Good Friday; and the pagdakip of Malolos, Bulacan.

The moros y cristianos, which depicts the battle between the Moros (Moors) and Cristianos (Christians) with dialogue and dances on the streets or in the open field, has many names and variations, among them: moro-moro in Tagalog; sayaw in Aklanon; bakahan, also in Tagalog; mardikas in Ternateño; palo-palo in Ivatan; sambali in Ibanag; sinulog in Waray; and kinabayo in Dapitan Cebuano. In Ibajay, Aklan, the moro-moro or sayaw is performed in the morning of the third Sunday of January in honor of the Santo Niño. The dance is performed by the warring factions starting from opposite ends of a half kilometer long street, marching toward each other and back while exchanging lines, and finally moving toward the altar of the Santo Niño in front of the church. The kinabayo performed in Dapitan, Zamboanga del Norte, dramatizes the Battle of Covadonga, said to have occurred in 718 AD between the Christian general Pelayo and the Moro Alkamah. The battle, enacted on the 24th of July, has since changed venues through the years: from the streets, as part of the morning procession; to a bamboo stage in the church patio, when revised in 1952; and finally, to the grounds of the provincial high school in the 1980s. The bakahan, of San Antonio, Kalayaan, Laguna, is performed by boys dressed in mask-headdresses, capes, bands, and swords. Dramatizing the sword fight between San Miguel Arcangel and the hudyo or Jews, it is performed in the churchyard from 2:00 to 3:00 pm on Good Friday.

In Bicol, a komedya performance in the form of pilgrimage is also enacted on the street. The dotoc is a religious devotion to the Holy Cross. Every year in April and May, communities in the Bicol region of the Philippines perform the dotoc for nine days. The performance involves the singing of a text by women cantors called paradotoc, who, as pilgrims, journey to the Holy Land to visit the Holy Cross. The text has various forms with varying narratives and manner of performance. Dotoc is an archaic Bikol word for pilgrimage—an action of the komedya to find the Cross of Jesus undertaken by Elena when she was already 80 years old.

Although rituals and mimetic dances continued to be performed in the ethnic communities, and the religious playlets remained popular in many towns throughout the Philippines, the term “theater” became associated more and more with plays performed within the theater structure. The sarsuwela and the drama, introduced during the Spanish colonial period, retained their popularity during the first three decades of the 20th century. American colonial rule introduced the bodabil, or stage show, and the one-act play in English. After World War II, playwrights and directors developed works in the styles of modern theater, employing realism and expressionism in their plays. No longer sustained by the community, play productions depended on a producer for financing. Since production costs had to be recovered, the theater structure became necessary to ensure a paying audience.

Street Theater as Political Protest. A new kind of street theater, later called dulansangan, flourished in the period of activism between 1970 and 1972, and the escalating mass movement in the 1980s preceding the 1986 fall of Marcos. Street theater draws its material from the experiences of the streets, and is presented outside of theater structures, both indoors (churches, building lobbies, marketplaces) and outdoors (plazas, roads, assembly points for rallies). The term thus refers to issue-oriented plays performed during pickets, rallies, symposia, strikes, demonstrations, and marches, where people are brought together by their unity on issues and problems confronting Philippine society.

National, sectoral, and specific issues supplied the themes generally carried in the plays. To present these issues, various theater forms and styles have been used by the theater groups in the 1980s until the present: tula-dula, choral recitation, bodabil, improvisation, pantomime, the effigy-lantern play, the radio play, the allegorical play, kilos-awit (movement-song), kilos-sayaw (ranging from banner dance to the indigenous war dance kuntao), newspaper theater, traditional forms such as salubong and sinakulo, and forms introduced in Augusto Boal’s theater of the oppressed, such as image and forum theaters.

Costumes usually consisted of a white T-shirt and denims. To suggest character, a military cap could be added to signify an officer, a towel around the neck to identify a worker, a straw hat to portray a peasant, or books to indicate students. Masks served to show character, to make actors seem larger onstage, and to hide the faces of actors evading arrest. Props and sets were usually convertible: a hula-hoop becoming a magnifying glass, a box a chair, a platform a mountain, placards together a mural. Pantomime, the use of a narrator, songs, dances, comedy, and satire were also used. Brecht’s epictheater and the Cultural Revolution plays of China have also influenced political theater performances.

The plays of the First Quarter Storm in 1970, performed during rallies, demonstrations, and marches at venues such as Plaza Miranda, Mendiola, Liwasang Bonifacio, and numerous school grounds and factories, depicted the plight of the workers, the Diliman Commune, the life of the lumpen proletariat, and the need for armed struggle. During the late 1960s and the 1970s, many artists involved in the national democratic revolution performed plays in the streets. These street plays were important not only as a means to dramatize issues during mass actions but also as a political choice for artists who wanted to change the “exclusivity” of theater and reach a larger audience.

An outstanding example is Masaker sa Araw ng Paggawa (Massacre on Labor Day), 1970, written by Bonifacio Ilagan, directed by Leo Rimando, and performed by Panday Sining, the cultural arm of Kabataang Makabayan. First performed at Plaza Miranda, lines on the workers’ struggle were recited in chorus, and precise movements simultaneously executed by the huge cast who wore red silk kerchiefs on their wrists. Seen from afar by the crowd, the kerchiefs blown by the wind and the precise movements of the cast created color, line, and movement. The play was later restaged by various school chapters of Panday Sining at universities and urban poor communities.

In Tanghalang Bayan’s Ang Kalbaryo ni Juan de la Cruz (The Calvary of Juan de la Cruz), 1970, performed during Holy Week, Christ represented the Filipino Juan whipped by truncheon-wielding fascists. The procession of the Tondo-based artists, led by Levy Balgos dela Cruz, started at Pritil Street, passed through Juan Luna, and ended at Plaza Moriones. The play had subsequent performances at Balic-Balic and the university belt.

Full-length plays were first staged at theaters, like Philamlife Theater, the Philippine College of Commerce Auditorium, University of the East (UE) Auditorium, and Abelardo Hall at the University of the Philippines (UP), and then performed in the streets. At times, these plays were first performed in the communities or factories before being staged in the auditoriums. Examples from the early 1970s are Kamanyang’s Pakikibaka (The Struggle), on the plight of workers; Gintong Silahis’s Barikada (Barricades) and Tanging Paraan (The Only Way), directed by Behn Cervantes; Panday Sining’s Tunggalian; and Tanghalang Bayan’s Hukumang Bayan (People’s Court), written collectively and directed by Anton Juan Jr.

After martial law was declared in 1972, lightning plays were staged in marketplaces. These plays lasted only for a few minutes to enable the actors to avoid arrest. Actors positioned themselves into a tableau, shouted slogans, and left immediately. From 1972 onward, many theater artists were arrested and detained while others focused on organizing work.

In 1975, Jose F. Lacaba’s poem “Ang mga Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Juan de la Cruz” (The Amazing Adventures of Juan de la Cruz) was staged as a play by the UP Repertory Company. First directed by Ces de Joya, Ang Kagila-gilalas … explored a new theater form called tula-dula (poem-play). The play was staged mainly at school lobbies during student rallies and at urban poor communities. It was performed by a reader and two actors, one playing the main character, and the other, known as Ms. Ellaneous, playing all the other characters. Other plays in the tula-dula form are Richie Valencia’s Iskolar ng Bayan (National Scholar), 1976, and Juan Obrero (Juan the Worker), 1977, both directed by Behn Cervantes.

The 1978 elections and the renewed strength of the protest movement in the late 1970s led to more mass actions, which resulted in the need for street plays. Two other groups were formed: Dulaang Kayumanggi, based in Tondo; and a group with no name, whose members wore cloth masks while performing. The latter first performed in Oct 1979 in a rally protesting tuition hike at the steps of the Arts and Sciences building of UP. Wearing red and black masks similar to that of the movie character Zorro, the group performed a movement play with the narration interpreted through gestures and action influenced by martial arts. The group continued to perform for multi-sectoral assemblies until 1981.

From 1981 to 1986, the protest movement grew stronger, with the people becoming more outraged by the Aquino assassination in 1983. New theater groups were formed, many of them based in their sectors and regions. Among the student-based groups in Manila were Peryante (formerly known as UP Tropang Bodabil) of UP Diliman; Dugong Silangan of UE; ENTABLADO of Ateneo de Manila University; Tamanaba of UP Manila; and Kapilas of De La Salle University. The two active community-based groups were Dulaang Palayag, based in Parañaque; and Dulampasigan, based in Pasig. Groups working for their respective sectors were Moog ng Lahi, the cultural group of the Alliance of Concerned Teachers; Tambisan and the Social Samarians Cultural Groups of Artex Malabon, among the workers; and Dulaang Habagat of Malabon, among the urban poor.

National problems were found in Peryante’s Ilokula: Ang Ilokanong Drakula I and II (Ilocula: The Ilocano Dracula), 1980 and 1983, written by Chris Millado. Ilokula was performed in the vaudeville style, using songs, dances, and comedy routines, and employed a barker serving as narrator. Referring to Marcos as a Dracula hungry for the blood of the Filipino people, the first version focused on the wealth and power of his family; the second, on his cronies. Masks, props, and costumes were designed by Paeng Altavas for mobility: Ilocula’s black cape had pockets that contained props; the papier-mâché masks resembling Marcos and Imelda were light, body parts made of rubber; inflatable huge syringes could be reassembled to become a missile. This enabled the performers to stage the play anywhere from the Palma Hall steps at UP Diliman to the Luneta Grandstand.

Sectoral issues focused on Mindanao peasants and minorities, as in the Mindanao Alliance’s Mindanao: Lupang Pangako (Mindanao: Land of Promise), 1984; workers in Dulaang Palanyag’s Pabrika (The Factory), 1983; and the plight of teachers in Moog ng Lahi’s Titser ng Bayan (People’s Teacher), 1984. A specific issue, the United States (US) bases, was the topic of Rene O. Villanueva’s Siyam na Raang Milyong Dolyar (Nine Hundred Million Dollars), 1983, presented by Tuklas.

During this period, street theater became synonymous with political theater, creating its own aesthetics in order to meet the demands of the times. At the heart of each play was the issue; plot, form, and production elements followed. The structure of the street play was mainly divided into three parts: first, an exposition on the conditions of the main character/s, which usually represented a sector; second, the onset of difficulties, problems, and oppression; and third, the need for unity and struggle. In some plays, this structure was more complex, but essentially remained the same. There were only two types of main character: the protagonists, such as the peasants, workers, and other oppressed sectors; and the antagonists, such as the dictator, the fascist military, corrupt officials, and the imperialist nations.

As in the previous period, mobility became the main characteristic of the street play, as shown in costumes, sets, props, music, and sound. Guitars accompanied songs while indigenous bamboo instruments, used mainly as percussion, provided rhythm and signified scene changes. The mobility of the actors enabled them to perform anywhere: on makeshift stages hastily built before a rally; on top of trucks; on top of huge street flowerpots; inside marketplaces and factories; and on the sidewalk while following an ongoing march.

Performers learned how to adapt to all kinds of conditions: venue of the assembly, the number of cast available, the time allotted for preparation, security measures, and the type of audience. Blocking was instantly adjusted to adapt to the space available. At a large venue, such as Liwasang Bonifacio, huge effigies were created or large masks worn by the actors. Actors played multiple roles so that a play could be easily mounted. When there was no time for preparation, playwrights wrote radio scripts that could be performed with only one rehearsal. Masks served two purposes: to show character, and to hide the actor’s identity from the military. Rock musicals and vaudeville plays were performed especially for student audiences, which could be considered generally apolitical.

Several outstanding street plays were produced not only from 1981 to 1986 but also in the years immediately following the 1986 change of government. These plays employed a variety of forms from the traditional to the popular and drew influences from Asia, Latin America, and South Africa.

Transforming the traditional salubong into a political street play, Salubong sa Maynila (Meeting in Manila), 1984, was performed by the members of UP Repertory Company, Dulaang UP, Peryante, and Inang Laya. Performing on top of a truck in Liwasang Bonifacio, the actors wore brown papier-mâché masks and black veils. At the center was the Virgin Mary in an Inang Bayan costume. The script, recited by readers as the performers moved, included prayer chants and songs.

In 1983, an effigy play titled Babala ng Lawin (The Hawk’s Warning), directed by Cris Gosalvez, was performed by the League of Filipino Students Cultural Group in front of the Embassy of the United States. The narration read by an actor holding a microphone was interpreted by two effigies, the hawk and the eagle, representing the Philippines and the United States.

The Artex Cultural Group reenacted in 1985 the strike they had staged the previous year. Faithful to the incident, workers playing the role of hired goons walked from the far end of the street toward the picket line, where the other actors were playing themselves as strikers. They then proceeded to reenact how the goons destroyed the picket, resulting in bloodshed. Performed by those who actually participated or witnessed the event, and staged during the anniversary of the strike, the reenactment became a ritual.

Similar to the play by the Artex performers were those performed by groups such as the Negros Theater League and Dulaang Katilingban. Their improvisational plays were performed to immediately reenact an event, such as the arrest of a sacada (seasonal cane worker), or the massacre of workers staging a demonstration. Students of colleges usually performed during rallies held in the streets of Bacolod while sugarcane workers and their children staged their improvisations inside the haciendas.

Other plays were influenced by theater in Latin America and South Africa. Techniques from Augusto Boal’s image theater proved to be an effective means to discuss the boycott campaign during the Batasang Pambansa elections in May 1984. The play, performed in front of Isetann Department Store by a volunteer cultural team led by Joi Barrios and Malou Maniquis, urged the audience to become participants. The actors first presented to the crowd three images: the present, the ideal, and the transitional. Volunteers were then asked to change the images as they wished, adding or subtracting characters; changing the blocking or movement of the cast; or acting the roles themselves.

In the first decade of the 21st century, the street plays were similar to those of the Marcos years (Barrios 2014). They used traditional rituals, rites, and cultural forms; featured confrontation with trauma through reenactments; used horror, romance, and humor; had an indefinite spatial location between audience and actors; and highlighted “the need for both actors and audience to envision and ‘perform’ victory so that they might have the will to struggle on” (Barrios 2014, 91).

In Oct 2003, when US President George W. Bush visited the Philippines, the Congress of Teachers and Educators for Nationalism and Democracy performed Romansang Horror (A Horrifying Romance). The play portrayed the Arroyo-Bush alliance as a love story, referring to Arroyo’s repeated declarations of support for the United States’ “war on terror.” A protest action, Hatol ng Bayan sa Kaso ng Hacienda Luisita (The People’s Verdict on the Hacienda Luisita Case), was held to express condemnation of the violent dispersal of the picket lines on 16 Nov 2004, when seven workers were killed and 181 wounded, and 110 arrested.

On 1 May 2005, a street play was staged by young actors from the Kilusang Mayo Uno at the Liwasang Bonifacio. As the oppressors or “evil” characters, actors wore masks representing the president, Uncle Sam as US imperialism, and the soldiers that safeguard the power of the status quo. On the other hand, “good” characters, such as the workers, peasants, and other oppressed sectors in Philippine society, played themselves.

Street theater continues to reach a large audience. Rituals and dances continue to be an essential part of the everyday life of ethnic groups. During Lent and Christmas, community members become actors in various religious plays. In Metro Manila, political street theater continues to be an essential part of rallies and demonstrations, while in the regions, plays continue to be performed wherever the people may be assembled: from town plazas to seashores and basketball courts. In all of these, street theater continues to be defined not by venue but by its goals and the audience it performs for.  Written by Joi Barrios with Nicanor G. Tiongson, updated by Bryan L. Viray

The moros y cristianos, which depicts the battle between the Moros (Moors) and Cristianos (Christians) with dialogue and dances on the streets or in the open field, has many names and variations, among them: moro-moro in Tagalog; sayaw in Aklanon; bakahan, also in Tagalog; mardikas in Ternateño; palo-palo in Ivatan; sambali in Ibanag; sinulog in Waray; and kinabayo in Dapitan Cebuano. In Ibajay, Aklan, the moro-moro or sayaw is performed in the morning of the third Sunday of January in honor of the Santo Niño. The dance is performed by the warring factions starting from opposite ends of a half kilometer long street, marching toward each other and back while exchanging lines, and finally moving toward the altar of the Santo Niño in front of the church. The kinabayo performed in Dapitan, Zamboanga del Norte, dramatizes the Battle of Covadonga, said to have occurred in 718 AD between the Christian general Pelayo and the Moro Alkamah. The battle, enacted on the 24th of July, has since changed venues through the years: from the streets, as part of the morning procession; to a bamboo stage in the church patio, when revised in 1952; and finally, to the grounds of the provincial high school in the 1980s. The bakahan, of San Antonio, Kalayaan, Laguna, is performed by boys dressed in mask-headdresses, capes, bands, and swords. Dramatizing the sword fight between San Miguel Arcangel and the hudyo or Jews, it is performed in the churchyard from 2:00 to 3:00 pm on Good Friday.

In Bicol, a komedya performance in the form of pilgrimage is also enacted on the street. The dotoc is a religious devotion to the Holy Cross. Every year in April and May, communities in the Bicol region of the Philippines perform the dotoc for nine days. The performance involves the singing of a text by women cantors called paradotoc, who, as pilgrims, journey to the Holy Land to visit the Holy Cross. The text has various forms with varying narratives and manner of performance. Dotoc is an archaic Bikol word for pilgrimage—an action of the komedya to find the Cross of Jesus undertaken by Elena when she was already 80 years old.

Although rituals and mimetic dances continued to be performed in the ethnic communities, and the religious playlets remained popular in many towns throughout the Philippines, the term “theater” became associated more and more with plays performed within the theater structure. The sarsuwela and the drama, introduced during the Spanish colonial period, retained their popularity during the first three decades of the 20th century. American colonial rule introduced the bodabil, or stage show, and the one-act play in English. After World War II, playwrights and directors developed works in the styles of modern theater, employing realism and expressionism in their plays. No longer sustained by the community, play productions depended on a producer for financing. Since production costs had to be recovered, the theater structure became necessary to ensure a paying audience.

Street Theater as Political Protest. A new kind of street theater, later called dulansangan, flourished in the period of activism between 1970 and 1972, and the escalating mass movement in the 1980s preceding the 1986 fall of Marcos. Street theater draws its material from the experiences of the streets, and is presented outside of theater structures, both indoors (churches, building lobbies, marketplaces) and outdoors (plazas, roads, assembly points for rallies). The term thus refers to issue-oriented plays performed during pickets, rallies, symposia, strikes, demonstrations, and marches, where people are brought together by their unity on issues and problems confronting Philippine society.

National, sectoral, and specific issues supplied the themes generally carried in the plays. To present these issues, various theater forms and styles have been used by the theater groups in the 1980s until the present: tula-dula, choral recitation, bodabil, improvisation, pantomime, the effigy-lantern play, the radio play, the allegorical play, kilos-awit (movement-song), kilos-sayaw (ranging from banner dance to the indigenous war dance kuntao), newspaper theater, traditional forms such as salubong and sinakulo, and forms introduced in Augusto Boal’s theater of the oppressed, such as image and forum theaters.

Costumes usually consisted of a white T-shirt and denims. To suggest character, a military cap could be added to signify an officer, a towel around the neck to identify a worker, a straw hat to portray a peasant, or books to indicate students. Masks served to show character, to make actors seem larger onstage, and to hide the faces of actors evading arrest. Props and sets were usually convertible: a hula-hoop becoming a magnifying glass, a box a chair, a platform a mountain, placards together a mural. Pantomime, the use of a narrator, songs, dances, comedy, and satire were also used. Brecht’s epictheater and the Cultural Revolution plays of China have also influenced political theater performances.

The plays of the First Quarter Storm in 1970, performed during rallies, demonstrations, and marches at venues such as Plaza Miranda, Mendiola, Liwasang Bonifacio, and numerous school grounds and factories, depicted the plight of the workers, the Diliman Commune, the life of the lumpen proletariat, and the need for armed struggle. During the late 1960s and the 1970s, many artists involved in the national democratic revolution performed plays in the streets. These street plays were important not only as a means to dramatize issues during mass actions but also as a political choice for artists who wanted to change the “exclusivity” of theater and reach a larger audience.

An outstanding example is Masaker sa Araw ng Paggawa (Massacre on Labor Day), 1970, written by Bonifacio Ilagan, directed by Leo Rimando, and performed by Panday Sining, the cultural arm of Kabataang Makabayan. First performed at Plaza Miranda, lines on the workers’ struggle were recited in chorus, and precise movements simultaneously executed by the huge cast who wore red silk kerchiefs on their wrists. Seen from afar by the crowd, the kerchiefs blown by the wind and the precise movements of the cast created color, line, and movement. The play was later restaged by various school chapters of Panday Sining at universities and urban poor communities.

In Tanghalang Bayan’s Ang Kalbaryo ni Juan de la Cruz (The Calvary of Juan de la Cruz), 1970, performed during Holy Week, Christ represented the Filipino Juan whipped by truncheon-wielding fascists. The procession of the Tondo-based artists, led by Levy Balgos dela Cruz, started at Pritil Street, passed through Juan Luna, and ended at Plaza Moriones. The play had subsequent performances at Balic-Balic and the university belt.

Full-length plays were first staged at theaters, like Philamlife Theater, the Philippine College of Commerce Auditorium, University of the East (UE) Auditorium, and Abelardo Hall at the University of the Philippines (UP), and then performed in the streets. At times, these plays were first performed in the communities or factories before being staged in the auditoriums. Examples from the early 1970s are Kamanyang’s Pakikibaka (The Struggle), on the plight of workers; Gintong Silahis’s Barikada (Barricades) and Tanging Paraan (The Only Way), directed by Behn Cervantes; Panday Sining’s Tunggalian; and Tanghalang Bayan’s Hukumang Bayan (People’s Court), written collectively and directed by Anton Juan Jr.

After martial law was declared in 1972, lightning plays were staged in marketplaces. These plays lasted only for a few minutes to enable the actors to avoid arrest. Actors positioned themselves into a tableau, shouted slogans, and left immediately. From 1972 onward, many theater artists were arrested and detained while others focused on organizing work.

In 1975, Jose F. Lacaba’s poem “Ang mga Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Juan de la Cruz” (The Amazing Adventures of Juan de la Cruz) was staged as a play by the UP Repertory Company. First directed by Ces de Joya, Ang Kagila-gilalas … explored a new theater form called tula-dula (poem-play). The play was staged mainly at school lobbies during student rallies and at urban poor communities. It was performed by a reader and two actors, one playing the main character, and the other, known as Ms. Ellaneous, playing all the other characters. Other plays in the tula-dula form are Richie Valencia’s Iskolar ng Bayan (National Scholar), 1976, and Juan Obrero (Juan the Worker), 1977, both directed by Behn Cervantes.

The 1978 elections and the renewed strength of the protest movement in the late 1970s led to more mass actions, which resulted in the need for street plays. Two other groups were formed: Dulaang Kayumanggi, based in Tondo; and a group with no name, whose members wore cloth masks while performing. The latter first performed in Oct 1979 in a rally protesting tuition hike at the steps of the Arts and Sciences building of UP. Wearing red and black masks similar to that of the movie character Zorro, the group performed a movement play with the narration interpreted through gestures and action influenced by martial arts. The group continued to perform for multi-sectoral assemblies until 1981.

From 1981 to 1986, the protest movement grew stronger, with the people becoming more outraged by the Aquino assassination in 1983. New theater groups were formed, many of them based in their sectors and regions. Among the student-based groups in Manila were Peryante (formerly known as UP Tropang Bodabil) of UP Diliman; Dugong Silangan of UE; ENTABLADO of Ateneo de Manila University; Tamanaba of UP Manila; and Kapilas of De La Salle University. The two active community-based groups were Dulaang Palayag, based in Parañaque; and Dulampasigan, based in Pasig. Groups working for their respective sectors were Moog ng Lahi, the cultural group of the Alliance of Concerned Teachers; Tambisan and the Social Samarians Cultural Groups of Artex Malabon, among the workers; and Dulaang Habagat of Malabon, among the urban poor.

National problems were found in Peryante’s Ilokula: Ang Ilokanong Drakula I and II (Ilocula: The Ilocano Dracula), 1980 and 1983, written by Chris Millado. Ilokula was performed in the vaudeville style, using songs, dances, and comedy routines, and employed a barker serving as narrator. Referring to Marcos as a Dracula hungry for the blood of the Filipino people, the first version focused on the wealth and power of his family; the second, on his cronies. Masks, props, and costumes were designed by Paeng Altavas for mobility: Ilocula’s black cape had pockets that contained props; the papier-mâché masks resembling Marcos and Imelda were light, body parts made of rubber; inflatable huge syringes could be reassembled to become a missile. This enabled the performers to stage the play anywhere from the Palma Hall steps at UP Diliman to the Luneta Grandstand.

Sectoral issues focused on Mindanao peasants and minorities, as in the Mindanao Alliance’s Mindanao: Lupang Pangako (Mindanao: Land of Promise), 1984; workers in Dulaang Palanyag’s Pabrika (The Factory), 1983; and the plight of teachers in Moog ng Lahi’s Titser ng Bayan (People’s Teacher), 1984. A specific issue, the United States (US) bases, was the topic of Rene O. Villanueva’s Siyam na Raang Milyong Dolyar (Nine Hundred Million Dollars), 1983, presented by Tuklas.

During this period, street theater became synonymous with political theater, creating its own aesthetics in order to meet the demands of the times. At the heart of each play was the issue; plot, form, and production elements followed. The structure of the street play was mainly divided into three parts: first, an exposition on the conditions of the main character/s, which usually represented a sector; second, the onset of difficulties, problems, and oppression; and third, the need for unity and struggle. In some plays, this structure was more complex, but essentially remained the same. There were only two types of main character: the protagonists, such as the peasants, workers, and other oppressed sectors; and the antagonists, such as the dictator, the fascist military, corrupt officials, and the imperialist nations.

As in the previous period, mobility became the main characteristic of the street play, as shown in costumes, sets, props, music, and sound. Guitars accompanied songs while indigenous bamboo instruments, used mainly as percussion, provided rhythm and signified scene changes. The mobility of the actors enabled them to perform anywhere: on makeshift stages hastily built before a rally; on top of trucks; on top of huge street flowerpots; inside marketplaces and factories; and on the sidewalk while following an ongoing march.

Performers learned how to adapt to all kinds of conditions: venue of the assembly, the number of cast available, the time allotted for preparation, security measures, and the type of audience. Blocking was instantly adjusted to adapt to the space available. At a large venue, such as Liwasang Bonifacio, huge effigies were created or large masks worn by the actors. Actors played multiple roles so that a play could be easily mounted. When there was no time for preparation, playwrights wrote radio scripts that could be performed with only one rehearsal. Masks served two purposes: to show character, and to hide the actor’s identity from the military. Rock musicals and vaudeville plays were performed especially for student audiences, which could be considered generally apolitical.

Several outstanding street plays were produced not only from 1981 to 1986 but also in the years immediately following the 1986 change of government. These plays employed a variety of forms from the traditional to the popular and drew influences from Asia, Latin America, and South Africa.

Transforming the traditional salubong into a political street play, Salubong sa Maynila (Meeting in Manila), 1984, was performed by the members of UP Repertory Company, Dulaang UP, Peryante, and Inang Laya. Performing on top of a truck in Liwasang Bonifacio, the actors wore brown papier-mâché masks and black veils. At the center was the Virgin Mary in an Inang Bayan costume. The script, recited by readers as the performers moved, included prayer chants and songs.

In 1983, an effigy play titled Babala ng Lawin (The Hawk’s Warning), directed by Cris Gosalvez, was performed by the League of Filipino Students Cultural Group in front of the Embassy of the United States. The narration read by an actor holding a microphone was interpreted by two effigies, the hawk and the eagle, representing the Philippines and the United States.

The Artex Cultural Group reenacted in 1985 the strike they had staged the previous year. Faithful to the incident, workers playing the role of hired goons walked from the far end of the street toward the picket line, where the other actors were playing themselves as strikers. They then proceeded to reenact how the goons destroyed the picket, resulting in bloodshed. Performed by those who actually participated or witnessed the event, and staged during the anniversary of the strike, the reenactment became a ritual.

Similar to the play by the Artex performers were those performed by groups such as the Negros Theater League and Dulaang Katilingban. Their improvisational plays were performed to immediately reenact an event, such as the arrest of a sacada (seasonal cane worker), or the massacre of workers staging a demonstration. Students of colleges usually performed during rallies held in the streets of Bacolod while sugarcane workers and their children staged their improvisations inside the haciendas.

Other plays were influenced by theater in Latin America and South Africa. Techniques from Augusto Boal’s image theater proved to be an effective means to discuss the boycott campaign during the Batasang Pambansa elections in May 1984. The play, performed in front of Isetann Department Store by a volunteer cultural team led by Joi Barrios and Malou Maniquis, urged the audience to become participants. The actors first presented to the crowd three images: the present, the ideal, and the transitional. Volunteers were then asked to change the images as they wished, adding or subtracting characters; changing the blocking or movement of the cast; or acting the roles themselves.

In the first decade of the 21st century, the street plays were similar to those of the Marcos years (Barrios 2014). They used traditional rituals, rites, and cultural forms; featured confrontation with trauma through reenactments; used horror, romance, and humor; had an indefinite spatial location between audience and actors; and highlighted “the need for both actors and audience to envision and ‘perform’ victory so that they might have the will to struggle on” (Barrios 2014, 91).

In Oct 2003, when US President George W. Bush visited the Philippines, the Congress of Teachers and Educators for Nationalism and Democracy performed Romansang Horror (A Horrifying Romance). The play portrayed the Arroyo-Bush alliance as a love story, referring to Arroyo’s repeated declarations of support for the United States’ “war on terror.” A protest action, Hatol ng Bayan sa Kaso ng Hacienda Luisita (The People’s Verdict on the Hacienda Luisita Case), was held to express condemnation of the violent dispersal of the picket lines on 16 Nov 2004, when seven workers were killed and 181 wounded, and 110 arrested.

On 1 May 2005, a street play was staged by young actors from the Kilusang Mayo Uno at the Liwasang Bonifacio. As the oppressors or “evil” characters, actors wore masks representing the president, Uncle Sam as US imperialism, and the soldiers that safeguard the power of the status quo. On the other hand, “good” characters, such as the workers, peasants, and other oppressed sectors in Philippine society, played themselves.

Street theater continues to reach a large audience. Rituals and dances continue to be an essential part of the everyday life of ethnic groups. During Lent and Christmas, community members become actors in various religious plays. In Metro Manila, political street theater continues to be an essential part of rallies and demonstrations, while in the regions, plays continue to be performed wherever the people may be assembled: from town plazas to seashores and basketball courts. In all of these, street theater continues to be defined not by venue but by its goals and the audience it performs for.
Written by Joi Barrios with Nicanor G. Tiongson, updated by Bryan L. Viray

photos.desc: Tatlong hari in Gasan, Marinduque, 1990 (CCP Collection)

text:
Tatlong hari —literally, “Three Kings” in Tagalog—is a Christmastide custom centering on the Three Magi who, according to tradition, traveled from the East to adore the Infant Jesus in Bethlehem.

In towns like Floridablanca, Pampanga, three adult males in royal costumes attend the Epiphany mass and walk with the procession of the Virgin through the streets.

In Cavinti, Laguna, three boys in crowns and capes attend mass, then ride on horses followed by beautiful sagala (young ladies) carrying images of the Three Kings. The group heads for the town hall, goes up the stairs, and from the balcony showers the crowds below with candies and coins.

 

In Gasan, Marinduque, on the first Sunday of January, the play of the Three Kings begins after the morning mass with a parade featuring Herod, Herodias, Herod’s soldiers, a pair of angels, and a male and female higante (giant figures made of bamboo and cloth that are carried by persons underneath) and the Three Kings riding on their horses, following a man carrying a parol (star lantern) hoisted on a long pole. The parade ends in front of a stage with a set representing Herod’s palace. The play begins with the kings going up the stage to talk to Herod, who welcomes them but cannot tell them where the Messiah has been born. The Kings go down the stage, walk around the little square and end up adoring the image of the Infant Jesus, enthroned on an altar in one corner of the patio and guarded by angels and the higante couple. Tired of waiting, Herod sends his soldiers after the kings but the soldiers come back empty-handed. In anger, Herod orders the massacre of all baby boys below two years of age and ends the play with mad laughter.Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
Tubong, meaning “crown” or “to crown,” is a coronation ritual practiced in the island of Marinduque. It is performed by the manunubong (initiator), usually, elder women and men, before a punsyon (initiate, celebrant, or honoree), together with invited bisita (guests). Its primary intention is to “heal” spiritual maladies, like the sickness of the kaluluwa or soul, or illnesses like fever, cholera, convulsion believed to be caused by supernatural elements, and other unknown reasons. It is also a way to celebrate special events, such as birthdays (namely, the 1st, 7th, 18th, 21st, and 60th), weddings, baptisms, anniversaries, and other life-cycle events. It has also become a welcome ceremony of the locals for the visitors of the island. At present, the ritual is also called putong.

Tubong in general is composed of musikang pantinig or vocal music, consisting of singing or chanting; playing of musical instruments, such as guitar, banjo, and tambourine; and movements or dance. The whole ritual follows 2/4, 3/4, and 4/4 rhythmic patterns, which may correspond to the musical qualities of martsa, balse, and lento, respectively. Its performance has several versions depending on the town, the community of manunubong that performs it, and the source of the narrative being chanted.

 

Brief descriptions of various tubong versions with their own narratives come from oral accounts of local practitioners who inherited the tradition. Tubong Banahaw is based on the mystical Banahaw Mountain in Tayabas, Quezon. Tubong Herarkias features the hierarchies of the Christian Holy Trinity— Diyos Ama (the Father), Diyos Anak (the Son), and Diyos Espiritu Santo (the Holy Spirit). During the ritual, the Holy Trinity, together with several cherubims, are believed to visit tao (human being, the celebrant) who is the lowest in the hierarchy. Tubong Kalagyo is associated with angel de la guardia (guardian angel) or kaluluwa (human spirit or soul). Based on Pasyon Genesis, Tubong sa Pasyon is enacted only on Ash Wednesdays, the beginning of the cuaresma or Catholic Lent, and onward until Sabado de Gloria (Black Saturday). The coronation is offered to the Virgin Mary. Tubong habanera may have come from the movement motif of habanera, which is an element of this version. Putong Bangbang is practiced by two manunubong groups in Bangbang, Gasan, Marinduque, which are the Senior Putong Group and Junior Putong Group.

The punsyon being regarded as a Saint, who shares veneration with the Diyos Ama, Anak, and Espiritu Santo (Holy Trinity), together with Birheng Maria (Virgin Mary), may imply its highly Catholic religious context and narrative. Below is an excerpt of the chant from the Kinse Misteryos/Putong Bangbang:

Ito’y ang koronang binatbat ng ginto

O mahal na Santa’y/Santo’y tanggapin mo na po

narito’t kalakip ang aming pagsuyo

nanggaling at buhat sa atay ko’t puso.

 

Labas magmadali ang isa sa inyo

ang dalang korona’y iputong sa ulo

Ang ngalan ng Ama, Espiritu Santo

suma’atin nawa ang personang tatlo.

 

Yamang nariyan ka na sa mahal mong trono

at kokoronahan ng personang tatlo

Ang palma’y sa kamay korona’y sa ulo

kasabay ay sabog asusena’t liryo.

 

(This is a crown made of gold

Oh, beloved Saint, please accept it

given to you with love

that comes from our liver and heart.

 

Hurry, one of you

put on the crown that you are carrying

In the name of the Father, the Holy Spirit

May the Holy Trinity be with us.

 

Since you are seated in your holy throne

the Holy Trinity will crown you

The scepter is for the hands, and the crown,

on the head as we throw white lily and lily bulb.)

Its folk essence can be attributed to its practice outside the Catholic Church. Hence, the performance narrative can be both sacred and secular. The tubong may consist of five or six sections—namely, “Sa Labas ng Tarangkahan” (Outside the Gate); “Pagsusunson” (Picking Up) or “Panawagan” (Calling Out); “Sa Loob ng Bahay” (Inside the House); Presentation of regalia in the Coronation; “Puri” (Praise) and “Berso” (Verse) and the “Hunot-Boronot” (Taking-Out), a unique section in Putong Bangbang; and “Viva Mabuhay” (Long Live) or “Sabugan” (Showering).

Ten to fifteen manunubong, commissioned by the sponsor (usually relatives of the celebrant) or the punsyon himself/herself, start outside the gate or house of the invitee announcing their presence. Usually in a standing position, they execute pahagod (hesitation side step) movement motif. They continue chanting “Tao po kami, tao po” (You have visitors, anybody home?), the usual Filipino greeting upon entering a house, while doing sulong-lakad (frontal walk) slowly toward the hagdan na may baitang (stairs with steps). This section, called pagsusunson, announces their intention to perform the sunson (literally, to pick up) toward the punsyon and ask his/her permission to enter the bahay na marikit (pretty house) or the symbolic Jerusalem. Some call this section the panawagan, from the word tawag or call. As they enter the house, the punsyon is seated in between two “angels” holding lit candles. Young members of the family usually perform as angels. On some occasions, the punsyon is initially covered with white cloth. They greet the punsyon who is treated like a blessed saint. Presentation of regalia for the punsyon follows this order: crown, scepter, flowers, sensilyo or coins, and sometimes palara (paper foil), luminarya mayor (paper-made moon), labindalawang bituin (12 stars), and alampay (shawl, for female celebrant). Then, a manunubong crowns the punsyon, sometimes inside a kubol, a makeshift altar that serves as the celebrant’s holy throne. This is the most significant motif of the ritual, with sulong (advancing) and yuko (sinking) as body movements. In the Kinse Misteryos (Fifteen Mysteries)/Putong Bangbang, the coronation is followed by poetry renditions called puri (praise) and berso (verse), and the hunot-boronot (taking-out), a magical act that features long strips of paper coming out from the mouth of a manunubong. The manunubong execute a combination of movement motifs: pahagod or hesitation step; matsar, a movement with head slightly down and done as though searching for a bird in the rice field; balse or waltz; hakbang na may sadsad or step with a brush; sulong-lakad or frontal walk; pagluhod or kneeling; and other gestures such as the kampay, an arm movement in lateral/sideward directions done left-right interchangeably, and sabugan. Everyone shouts “Viva! Mabuhay!” (Long live, long live!). Then, the kainan (feast) ends the celebration when everybody shares the banquet prepared by the punsyon. Dishes and drinks are served. The banquet depends on how big or small the event is, or how financially capable the sponsors (usually relatives of the celebrant) and punsyon are. The quantity of food does not matter much. What is important for the manunubong is how the sponsors and punsyon regard them. This regard is called estima—a combination of expressive, affective, and gestural approach toward others.

Transformations. Transformations happenedin the 1960s when outside influences started to affect the cultural activities in Marinduque, particularly the moriones, and eventually the tubong tradition. The popularity of the moriones paved the way for Marinduque province to become a tourist destination. It attracted many visitors who helped bring about a change in the tubong tradition’s social function. From its intentions of communal healing and Catholic-influenced veneration, the tubong became a welcome ceremony for visitors from outside the province. In the 1960s, Mr Julian Mogol, Schools Division superintendent of Marinduque, and Mrs Iluminada Nepomuceno, a music teacher, convened public teachers to gather, document, and study the music and dance of tubong versions practiced in the towns of Boac, Gasan, and Mogpog. The result of this initiative was a new and shortened (30-45 min) version of the performance. It is a mixture of tubong versions from the three towns called Putong ng mga Maestra (Putong of the Teachers), which was performed for guests and visitors of the teachers. Eventually, this version became popular in Boac, thus the name Putong ng mga Taga-Bayan (Putong of the Capital Town). Marching band player, tubong practitioner, and Mogpog town mayor Senen Livelo, quoting the old members of the community, calls this version sinalampakutan, or an amalgam of all the tubong versions practiced in Marinduque. The term has a derogatory tone.

The local government officially calls it Marinduque Putong .As part of the institutionalization of the tubong, the provincial government under the administration of Jose Antonio Carrion approved an ordinance declaring 11 Feb as the Putong Festival day of Marinduque. The Marinduque provincial government has its own putong group, which usually performs for official functions. Carmencita O. Reyes herself, governor and former congresswoman of the province, played a part in transforming the putong’s elements. article.value: Tubong in general is composed of musikang pantinig or vocal music, consisting of singing or chanting; playing of musical instruments, such as guitar, banjo, and tambourine; and movements or dance. The whole ritual follows 2/4, 3/4, and 4/4 rhythmic patterns, which may correspond to the musical qualities of martsa, balse, and lento, respectively. Its performance has several versions depending on the town, the community of manunubong that performs it, and the source of the narrative being chanted.

article.value: Brief descriptions of various tubong versions with their own narratives come from oral accounts of local practitioners who inherited the tradition. Tubong Banahaw is based on the mystical Banahaw Mountain in Tayabas, Quezon. Tubong Herarkias features the hierarchies of the Christian Holy Trinity— Diyos Ama (the Father), Diyos Anak (the Son), and Diyos Espiritu Santo (the Holy Spirit). During the ritual, the Holy Trinity, together with several cherubims, are believed to visit tao (human being, the celebrant) who is the lowest in the hierarchy. Tubong Kalagyo is associated with angel de la guardia (guardian angel) or kaluluwa (human spirit or soul). Based on Pasyon Genesis, Tubong sa Pasyon is enacted only on Ash Wednesdays, the beginning of the cuaresma or Catholic Lent, and onward until Sabado de Gloria (Black Saturday). The coronation is offered to the Virgin Mary. Tubong habanera may have come from the movement motif of habanera, which is an element of this version. Putong Bangbang is practiced by two manunubong groups in Bangbang, Gasan, Marinduque, which are the Senior Putong Group and Junior Putong Group.

The punsyon being regarded as a Saint, who shares veneration with the Diyos Ama, Anak, and Espiritu Santo (Holy Trinity), together with Birheng Maria (Virgin Mary), may imply its highly Catholic religious context and narrative. Ito’y ang koronang binatbat ng ginto

O mahal na Santa’y/Santo’y tanggapin mo na po

narito’t kalakip ang aming pagsuyo

nanggaling at buhat sa atay ko’t puso.

 

Labas magmadali ang isa sa inyo

ang dalang korona’y iputong sa ulo

Ang ngalan ng Ama, Espiritu Santo

suma’atin nawa ang personang tatlo.

 

Yamang nariyan ka na sa mahal mong trono

at kokoronahan ng personang tatlo

Ang palma’y sa kamay korona’y sa ulo

kasabay ay sabog asusena’t liryo.

 

(This is a crown made of gold

Oh, beloved Saint, please accept it

given to you with love

that comes from our liver and heart.

 

Hurry, one of you

put on the crown that you are carrying

In the name of the Father, the Holy Spirit

May the Holy Trinity be with us.

 

Since you are seated in your holy throne

the Holy Trinity will crown you

The scepter is for the hands, and the crown,

on the head as we throw white lily and lily bulb.)

Its folk essence can be attributed to its practice outside the Catholic Church. Hence, the performance narrative can be both sacred and secular. The tubong may consist of five or six sections—namely, “Sa Labas ng Tarangkahan” (Outside the Gate); “Pagsusunson” (Picking Up) or “Panawagan” (Calling Out); “Sa Loob ng Bahay” (Inside the House); Presentation of regalia in the Coronation; “Puri” (Praise) and “Berso” (Verse) and the “Hunot-Boronot” (Taking-Out), a unique section in Putong Bangbang; and “Viva Mabuhay” (Long Live) or “Sabugan” (Showering).

Ten to fifteen manunubong, commissioned by the sponsor (usually relatives of the celebrant) or the punsyon himself/herself, start outside the gate or house of the invitee announcing their presence. Usually in a standing position, they execute pahagod (hesitation side step) movement motif. They continue chanting “Tao po kami, tao po” (You have visitors, anybody home?), the usual Filipino greeting upon entering a house, while doing sulong-lakad (frontal walk) slowly toward the hagdan na may baitang (stairs with steps). This section, called pagsusunson, announces their intention to perform the sunson (literally, to pick up) toward the punsyon and ask his/her permission to enter the bahay na marikit (pretty house) or the symbolic Jerusalem. Some call this section the panawagan, from the word tawag or call. As they enter the house, the punsyon is seated in between two “angels” holding lit candles. Young members of the family usually perform as angels. On some occasions, the punsyon is initially covered with white cloth. They greet the punsyon who is treated like a blessed saint. Presentation of regalia for the punsyon follows this order: crown, scepter, flowers, sensilyo or coins, and sometimes palara (paper foil), luminarya mayor (paper-made moon), labindalawang bituin (12 stars), and alampay (shawl, for female celebrant). Then, a manunubong crowns the punsyon, sometimes inside a kubol, a makeshift altar that serves as the celebrant’s holy throne. This is the most significant motif of the ritual, with sulong (advancing) and yuko (sinking) as body movements. In the Kinse Misteryos (Fifteen Mysteries)/Putong Bangbang, the coronation is followed by poetry renditions called puri (praise) and berso (verse), and the hunot-boronot (taking-out), a magical act that features long strips of paper coming out from the mouth of a manunubong. Everyone shouts “Viva! Mabuhay!” (Long live, long live!). Then, the kainan (feast) ends the celebration when everybody shares the banquet prepared by the punsyon. Dishes and drinks are served. The banquet depends on how big or small the event is, or how financially capable the sponsors (usually relatives of the celebrant) and punsyon are. The quantity of food does not matter much. What is important for the manunubong is how the sponsors and punsyon regard them. This regard is called estima—a combination of expressive, affective, and gestural approach toward others.

text:
Tula-dula —literally, “poem-play”—refers to a minimalist form of theater developed in the mid-1970s by the University of the Philippines Repertory Company (UPRC). It consists of a poem that is dramatized by the use of a narrator, who reads out all the parts and provides all the sounds and special effects, and one, two, or more actors who mime all the roles.

The first poem to be performed as a tula-dula was Jose F. Lacaba’s “Ang mga Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Juan de la Cruz” (The Amazing Adventures of Juan de la Cruz), 1975. As the narrator read out the poem, one actor played ordinary citizen Juan de la Cruz—walking the streets, looking for a job, looking for a girl, getting hungry, being frustrated at every turn, eventually feeling so angry he turns despair into defiance and runs off to the mountains to join the rebels. The other actor played all the other characters: a bus conductor, a street, a wall, a ticket seller, a gardener, a soldier, a pimp, the sea waves, a bishop, and finally a Philippine Constabulary soldier. Props and bits of costume, such as a police officer’s hat and nightstick, a skirt, and a bandanna, were laid out on the floor and picked up by the actor when needed.

The form was convenient because it required a minimum of personnel and equipment, and especially because it was economical (in a theater beset by endemic poverty), portable (it could go to town plazas, classrooms, school auditoriums, large or small spaces), and completely adaptable to budgets, costumes, props, and actors available. It could use one microphone to perform before big rallies.

 

Other poems and scripts were later written especially for the tula-dula form, such as Richie Valencia’s Iskolar ng Bayan (People’s Scholar), 1976, about one day in the life of a UP student, and Juan Obrero (Juan the Worker), 1977, about the travails of a worker in a factory. In the late 1970s and early 1980s, teachers’ organizations wrote and acted out Titser ng Bayan (People’s Teacher), which exposed the life of an overworked and underpaid teacher under the dictatorship, while media people expounded on their lives with Juan Peryodista (Juan the Journalist), 1984. Up to the years of the 21st century in the UP Diliman campus, the UPRC would continue to dramatize in the tula-dula form Isko (short for scholar) experiences and concerns.

The theater form tula-dula, mainly associated with UPRC, may have similarities with the dula-tula, dramatized poetry, evolved from the Basic Integrated Theater Arts Workshop module of the Philippine Educational Theater Association, circa 1980s, the dula-tula module. This module, usually the first module after the initial orientation process, emphasized release and improvisatory skills as learning processes for participants’ awareness of basic artistic elements and composition for theater. As a release module, the participants, usually numbering 20-30, plunged into exercises that tapped into their artistic selves, at the same time that they encouraged the sharing of ideas, collective spontaneous creative improvisations, and interactions.

The final showcase of the module, also called a dula-tula, exuded a variety of dramatic and staging possibilities, including improvisations by actors with dialogues on given situations (e.g., characters seen and heard on a Quiapo church sidewalk), or the use of actors’ bodies as props and set-props (e.g., a group of actors forming the shape and movement of a helicopter or the facade of a church. Very often, these improvisations were strung together in a poem, usually evolved by the participants themselves, with the poetic lines integrated into the other elements of the staging. In some cases, the dula-tula approximated the sabayang pagbigkas (simultaneous group recitation) of many Philippine high school Filipino classes, and that of the more defined dramatic convention, the chorus. An example of dula-tula as chorus would be scenes from Juan Tamban, where the chorus recited in unison a poetic stanza or two, even perhaps set to music, but the chorus would eventually also be characters in the dramatizations that preceded or followed.

Seen in the context of that period, poetry was indeed being integrated into the theater syntax, regardless of labels. The revolutionary atmosphere particularly in the student and youth sector influenced their theater arts, freed from the conventions of realist staging, and attuned to the demands of organized political agendas. To a certain degree, theater was free to innovate, and theater welcomed poetry.

Almost at the same time as the UPRC, in 1975, the Metropolitan Teen Theater League mounted Rosalie Matilac’s Kasi Babae Raw (Because They Are Women), which used two women narrators exchanging dialogues in verse, one dressed in old generation attire, the other in the modern style of denims and T-shirts. It dramatized the status of women from the Spanish colonization to the contemporary period. Scenes of many manang (women devotees) in churches were recreated, as well as a beauty contest, the wet look of bomba films, and sexy product endorsers of brandy. There were also scenes of women workers in factories, from whose sector change would be initiated. In the end, the two narrators agreed on the need for women to fight for their freedom and their rights. A song on the new identity of women closed the play.

The tula-dula innovations were invariably political in content, a product of the revolutionary movement of the 1970s, as well as of the economics of Philippine theater, the assortment of venues for theater, and the agile inventiveness of writers and theater groups. Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, Joi Barrios, and Nicanor G. Tiongson, updated by Apolonio B. Chua, with notes from Rosalie Matilac

text:
The Spanish term velada refers to a program of assorted musical and nonmusical numbers, usually staged by schools or amateur groups on such occasions as college or foundation days, school or religious feasts, and civic occasions like Rizal Day.

The standard fare often included songs (solos, duets, choruses), piano numbers, dances (solo or otherwise), recitations of poetry, declamations, and skits or scenes from plays. It was easily put together by gathering performers and performances that had already been prepared for, with no special training necessary. In the days of the sarsuwela —the 1920s and 1930s—the piano and voice numbers were predictably pasacalles and solos from the popular Spanish zarzuela, like El Anillo de Hierro (Ring of Iron), La Tela de Araña (The Spider’s Web), and Marcha de Cadiz (Cadiz March); the dances Spanish; and the poems and declamations from Spanish literature. After American colonization, the repertoires were gradually infiltrated by American song and dance (e.g., jazz), skit, and magic acts, and the new styles in bodabil.

 

Today the programs are no longer called velada, but partake of the nature of stage and variety shows: songs, dances, stand-up acts, skits, mime—in the modern idiom. In the past the velada prepared amateur performers and their audiences for staged dramas. Those who performed parts of zarzuelas might in time perform in full-length pieces. These nonprofessional actors might become interested enough to perform regularly, or at least to become leaders of the societies of aficionados—for example, the Iloilo Sociedad Lirico Dramatica, which gave dinners, dances, benefits, and especially funciones de teatro, both amateur (mounted by themselves) and professional (hired by them). The velada were in effect a step toward professionalism, but also an obstacle that had to be hurdled, since their amateur (putting “acts” together) mentality was a long leap away from that of the professional performer. Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
Via crucis, which means “Way of the Cross” in Latin, is also known as estasyon, from Spanish estacion or “station”; estasyon heneral, from Spanish estacion general or “general station”; or, in Paete, Laguna, salubong, from Tagalog “meeting,” to be distinguished from the Easter Sunday salubong. This procession outside the church commemorates the “Way of the Cross” or the events in Christ’s passion, from Pilate’s Condemnation of Christ, to the carrying of the Cross on the Via Dolorosa; the Three Falls; Christ’s meeting with the Virgin, Veronica, Simon of Cyrene, the Women of Jerusalem; the Stripping, Nailing, and Lancing of Jesus; His Death; the Deposition from the Cross; the Pieta; and the Burial.

Usually held in the late afternoon and early evening of the seven Sundays of Lent, this candle procession of the faithful is led by a priest and accompanied by the karo (float) of the Nazareno (Christ carrying the cross). Starting from the church at about five or six in the afternoon, it winds its way around the church patio or the town’s main streets, as the faithful sing the “Perdon” (Pardon), stopping for prayers and a brief reflection at each of the 14 estasyon, where a picture of one of the Stations of the Cross is enthroned on an altar and decorated with candles and flowers by the sponsor family. After about three hours, the procession goes back to the church.

In Paete, Laguna, a special Via Crucis called the salubong, held on Wednesday (by Catholics) and Thursday (by Aglipayans) of Holy Week, features on karos or floats the image of the Nazareno (Jesus on His feet, carrying the cross and wearing a long velvet or maroon robe and the three potensiya or powers on His head), the Mater Dolorosa (dressed in red and blue, with rostrillo or facial halo, and wearing on her chest a heart pierced with seven daggers), Veronica (dressed in yellow and red, wearing a coronet, and holding a white kerchief in her folded hands), and images of other saints of the Passion, including San Pedro, San Juan, and Maria Magdalena. At the plaza beside the church, the statue of the Virgin is removed from her karo and carried to the karo of the Nazarene. With a group of men and women eerily chanting the dialogue and the narration, the Nazarene “meets” his mother whose hands (through a mechanism manipulated from inside and under her) reach out to Jesus. Later, at another street corner, the statue of Veronica is also carried from its karo to the float of the Nazareno. The merciful Veronica then wipes Jesus’s face with a white towel as her dialogue is chanted by women. Finally, at the big plaza near the old crossroads and several streets away, the Virgin asks Veronica if she has seen Jesus. Veronica then opens her towel, on which is imprinted the three faces of Christ. The Virgin recognizes her son and blesses Veronica in gratitude. After this, all the images join the long procession around town. In Paete, no altars are erected for the stations of the cross.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson
